docTitle.titlePart: SECOND PLAYS by A. A. MILNE

titlePage.docImprint: New YorkALFRED A. KNOPF Printed in Great Britain by R. & R. Clark , Limited , Edinburgh . To D. M . SO LITTLE IN RETURN FOR SO MUCH

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Encouraged by the reviewer who announced that the Introduction to my previous collection of plays was the best part of the book , I venture to introduce this collection in a similar manner . But I shall be careful not to overdo it this time , in the hope that I may win from my critic some such tribute as , “ Mr. Milne has certainly improved as a dramatist , in that his plays are now slightly better than his Introduction . ”

Since , then , I am trying to make this preface as distasteful as possible , in order that the plays may shine out the more pleasantly , I shall begin ( how better ? ) with an attack on the dramatic critics . I will relate a little conversation which took place , shortly after the publication of “ First Plays , ” between myself and a very much more eminent dramatist .
EMINENT DRAMATIST ( kindly ) Your book seems to have been well reviewed .

MYSELF ( ungratefully ) . Not bad — by those who reviewed it . But I doubt if it was noticed by more than three regular dramatic critics . And considering that two of the plays in it had never been produced —
EMINENT DRAMATIST ( amused by my innocence ) . My dear fellow , you need n't complain . I published an unproduced play a little while ago , and it did n't get a single notice from anybody .

Now I hope that , however slightly the conversations in the plays which follow may move the dramatic critic , he will at least be disturbed by this little dialogue . All of us who are interested in the theatre are accustomed to read , and sometimes to make , ridiculous accusations against the Theatrical Manager . We condemn the mercenary fellow because he will not risk a loss of two or three thousand pounds on the intellectual masterpiece of a promising young dramatist , preferring to put on some contemptible but popular rubbish which is certain to fill his theatre . But now we see that the dramatic critic , that stern upholder of the best interests of the British Drama , will not himself risk six shillings ( and perhaps two or three hours of his time ) in order to read the intellectual masterpiece of the promising young dramatist , and so to be able to tell us with authority whether the Manager really is refusing masterpieces or no . He will not risk six shillings in order to encourage that promising young dramatist — discouraged enough already , poor devil , in his hopes of fame and fortune — by telling him that he is right , and that his plays are worth something , or ( alternatively ) to prevent him from wasting any more of his youth upon an art-form to which he is not suited . No , he will not risk his shillings ; but he will write an important ( and , let us hope , well-rewarded ) article , informing us that the British Drama is going to the dogs , and that no promising young dramatist is ever given a fair chance .
Let us consider this young dramatist for a moment , and ask ourselves why he goes on writing his masterpieces . I give three reasons — in their order of importance .
( 1 ) The pleasure of writing ; or , more accurately , the hell of not writing . He gets this anyhow .

titlePage.docImprint: ( 2 ) The appreciation of his peers ; his hope of immortality ; the criticism of the experts ; fame , publicity , notoriety , swank , réclame — call it what you will . But it is obvious that he cannot have it unless the masterpiece is given to the world , either by manager or publisher . ( 3 ) Money . If the masterpiece is published only , very little ; if produced , possibly a great deal . As I say , he gets his first reward anyhow . But let us be honest with ourselves . How many of us would write our masterpieces on a desert island , with no possibility of being rescued ? Well , perhaps all of us ; for we should feel that , even if not rescued ourselves , our manuscripts — written on bark with a burnt stick — clutched in a skeleton hand — might be recovered later by some literary sea-captain . ( As it might be , Conrad . ) But how many of us would write masterpieces if we had to burn them immediately afterwards , or if we were alone upon the world , the last survivors of a new flood ? Could we bear to write ? Could we bear not to write ? It is not fair to ask us . But we can admit this much without reserve ; it is the second reward which tears at us , and , lacking it , we should lose courage . So when the promising young dramatist has his play refused by the Managers — after what weeks , months , years of hope and fear , uncertainty and bitter disappointment — he has this great consolation : “ Anyway , I can always publish it . ” Perhaps , after a dozen refusals , a Manager offers to put on his play , on condition that he alters the obviously right ( and unhappy ) ending into the obviously foolish , but happy , ending which will charm the public . Does he , the artist , succumb ? How easy to tell himself that he must get his play before the public somehow , and that , even if it is not his play now , yet the first two acts are as he wrote them , and that , if only to feel the thrill of the audience at that great scene between the Burglar and the Bishop ( his creations ! ) he must deaden his conscience to the absurdity of a happy ending . But does he succumb ? No . Heroically he tells himself : “ Anyway , I can publish it ; and I 'm certain that the critics will agree with me that —— ” But the critics are too busy to bother about him . They are busy informing the world that the British Drama is going to the dogs , and that no promising young dramatist ever gets a fair chance . Let me say here that I am airing no personal grievance . I doubt if any dramatist has less right to feel aggrieved against the critics , the managers , the public , the world , than I ; and whatever right I have I renounce , in return for the good things which I have received from them . But I do not renounce the grievance of our craft . I say that , in the case of all dramatists , it is the business of the dramatic critics to review their unacted plays when published . Some of them do ; most of them do not . It is ridiculous for those who do not to pretend that they take any real interest in the British Drama . But I say “ review , ” not “ praise . ” Let them damn , by all means , if the plays are unworthy ; and , by damning , do so much of justice to the Managers who refused them . We can now pass on safely to the plays in this volume . We begin with a children 's play . The difficulty in the way of writing a children 's play is that Barrie was born too soon . Many people must have felt the same about Shakespeare . We who came later have no chance . What fun to have been Adam , and to have had the whole world of plots and jokes and stories at one 's disposal . Possibly , however , one would never have thought of the things . Of course , there are still others to come after us , but our works are not immortal , and they will plagiarise us without protest . Yet I have hopes of Make-Believe , for it had the honour of inaugurating Mr. Nigel Playfair 's management at the Lyric , Hammersmith . It is possible that the historians will remember this , long after they have forgotten my plays ; more likely ( alas ! ) that their history will be dated A. D. ( After Drinkwater ) and that the honour will be given to “ Abraham Lincoln . ” I like to think that in this event my ghost will haunt them . Make-Believe appeared with a Prologue by the Manager , lyrics by C. E . Burton , and music by Georges Dorlay . As the title-page states that this book is , in the language of children 's competitions , “ my own unaided work , ” I print the play with a new Prologue , and without the charming lyrics . But the reader is told when he may burst into an improvisation of his own , though I warn him that he will not make such a good show of it as did my collaborators .

front.performance: Mr. Pim Passes By appeared at several theatres . Let us admit cheerfully that it was a success — in spite of the warning of an important gentleman in the theatrical world , who told me , while I was writing it , that the public would n't stand any talk of bigamy , and suggested that George and Olivia should be engaged only , not married . ( Hence the line , “ Bigamy ! . . . It is an ugly word , ” in the Second Act . ) But , of course , nobody sees more clearly than I how largely its success was due to Mr. Dion Boucicault and Miss Irene Vanbrugh . The Romantic Age appeared first at the Comedy , and ( like Mr. Pim ) found , in its need , a home at The Playhouse . Miss Gladys Cooper has a charming way of withdrawing into a nursing home whenever I want a theatre , but I beg her not to make a habit of it . My plays can be spared so much more easily than she . By the way , a word about Melisande . Many of the critics said that nobody behaved like that nowadays . I am terrified at the thought of arguing with them , for they can always reduce me to blushes with a scornful , “ My dear man , you can n't do that in a play ! ” And when they tell me to remember what Strindberg said in ‘ 93 ( if he were alive then ; I really do n't know ) or what Aristotle wrote in — no , I sha n't even guess at Aristotle , well , then , I want to burst into tears , my ignorance is so profound . So , very humbly , I just say now that , when Melisande talks and behaves in a certain way , I do not mean that a particular girl exists ( Miss Jones , of 999 Bedford Park ) who talks and behaves like this , but I do mean that there is a type of girl who , in her heart , secretly , thinks like this . If , from your great knowledge of the most secret places of a young girl 's heart , you tell me that there is no such type , then I shall only smile . But if you inform me sternly that a dramatist has no business to express an attitude in terms of an actress , then you reduce me to blushes again . For I really know nothing about play-writing , and I am only sustained by two beliefs . The first is that rules are always made for the other people ; the second is that , if a play by me is not obviously by me , and as obviously not by anybody else , then ( obviously ) I had no business to write it . Of the one-act plays , The Camberley Triangle and The Stepmother , nothing much need be said . The former was played at the Coliseum ; the latter , written for Miss Winifred Emery , was deemed by the management too serious for that place of amusement . This , however , was to the great advantage of the play , for now it has appeared only at Charity matinées with an “ all-star ” cast .

titlePage.docImprint: As before , the plays are printed in the order in which they were written ; in this case between October1918and June1920. May the reader get as much enjoyment from them as I had in their writing . But no ; that is plainly impossible . A. A. MILNE .

sp.speaker: MAKE-BELIEVE
sp.p: A CHILDREN 'S PLAY IN A PROLOGUE AND THREE ACTS Make-Believe was first produced at the Lyric Theatre , Hammersmith , on December 24 , 1918 . The chief parts were played by Marjory Holman , Jean Cadell , Rosa Lynd , Betty Chester , Roy Lennol , John Barclay , Kinsey Peile , Stanley Drewitt , Ivan Berlyn , and Herbert Marshall — several parts each .

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.stage: The playroom of the HUBBARD FAMILY — nine of them . Counting MR. and MRS. HUBBARD , we realize that there are eleven HUBBARDS in all , and you would think that one at least of the two people we see in the room would be a HUBBARD of sorts . But no . The tall manly figure is JAMES , the HUBBARDS ’ butler , for the HUBBARDS are able to afford a butler now . How different from the time when Old Mother Hubbard — called “ old ” because she was at least twenty-two , and “ mother ” because she had a passion for children — could not even find a bone for her faithful terrier ; but , of course , that was before HENRY went into work . Well , the tall figure is JAMES , the butler , and the little one is ROSEMARY , a friend of the HUBBARD FAMILY . ROSEMARY is going in for literature this afternoon , as it 's raining , and JAMES is making her quite comfortable first with pens and ink and blotting-paper — always so important when one wants to write . He has even thought of a stick of violet sealing-wax ; after that there can be no excuse .
ROSEMARY . Thank you , James . ( She sits down . ) If any one calls I am not at home .
JAMES . Yes , Miss .
ROSEMARY . You may add that I am engaged in writing my auto — autobiography .
JAMES . Yes , Miss .
ROSEMARY . It 's what every one writes , is n't it , James ?
JAMES . I believe so , Miss .
ROSEMARY . Thank you . ( He goes to the door . ) Oh , James ?
JAMES . Yes , Miss ?
ROSEMARY . What is an autobiography ?
JAMES . Well , I could n't rightly say , Miss — not to explain it properly .
ROSEMARY ( dismayed ) . Oh , James ! . . . I thought you knew everything .
JAMES . In the ordinary way , yes , Miss , but every now and then ——
ROSEMARY . It 's very upsetting .
JAMES . Yes , Miss . . . . How would it be to write a play instead ? Very easy work , they tell me .
ROSEMARY ( nodding ) . Yes , that 's much better . I 'll write a play . Thank you , James .
JAMES . Not at all , Miss . [ He goes out .
( ROSEMARY bites her pen , and thinks deeply . At last the inspiration comes . )

ROSEMARY ( as she writes ) . Make-Believe . M-a-k-e hyphen B-e-l —— ( she stops and frowns ) Now which way is it ? ( She tries it on the blotting-paper ) That looks wrong . ( She tries it again ) So does that . Oh , dear ! ( She rings the bell . . . JAMES returns . )
JAMES . Yes , Miss ?
ROSEMARY . James , I have decided to call my play Make-Believe .
JAMES . Yes , Miss .
ROSEMARY ( carelessly ) . When you spell “ believe , ” it is “ i-e , ” is n't it ?
JAMES . Yes , Miss .
ROSEMARY . I thought at first it was “ e-i . ”
JAMES . Now you mention it , I think it is , Miss .
ROSEMARY ( reproachfully ) . Oh , James ! Are n't you certain ?
JAMES . M-a-k-e , make , B-e-l —— ( He stops and scratches his whiskers . )
ROSEMARY . Yes . I got as far as that .
JAMES . B-e-l ——
ROSEMARY . You see , James , it spoils the play if you have an accident to the very first word of it .

JAMES . Yes , Miss . B-e-l —— I 've noticed sometimes that if one writes a word careless-like on the blotting-paper , and then looks at it with the head on one side , there 's a sort of instinct comes over one , as makes one say ( with a shake of the head ) “ Rotten . ” One can then write it the other way more hopeful .
ROSEMARY . I 've tried that .
JAMES . Then might I suggest , Miss , that you give it another name altogether ? As it might be , “ Susan 's Saturday Night , ” all easy words to spell , or “ Red Revenge , ” or ——
ROSEMARY . I must call it Make-Believe , because it 's all of the play I 've thought of so far .
JAMES . Quite so , Miss . Then how would it be to spell it wrong on purpose ? It comes funnier that way sometimes .
ROSEMARY . Does it ?
JAMES . Yes , Miss . Makes ‘ em laugh .
ROSEMARY . Oh ! . . . Well , which is the wrong way ?
JAMES . Ah , there you 've got me again , Miss .
ROSEMARY ( inspired ) . I know what I 'll do . I 'll spell it “ i-e ” ; and if it 's right , then I 'm right , and if it 's wrong , then I 'm funny .
JAMES . Yes , Miss . That 's the safest .
ROSEMARY . Thank you , James .
JAMES . Not at all , Miss . [ He goes out .
ROSEMARY ( writing ) . Make-Believe . A Christmas Entertainment —— ( She stops and thinks , and then shakes her head . ) No , play — a Christmas Play in three acts . Er —— ( She is stuck . )
Enter JAMES .
JAMES . Beg pardon , Miss , but the Misses and Masters Hubbard are without , and crave admittance .
ROSEMARY . All nine of them ?
JAMES . Without having counted them , Miss , I should say that the majority of them were present .
ROSEMARY . Did you say that I was not at home ?
JAMES . Yes , Miss . They said that , this being their house , and you being a visitor , if you had been at home , then you would n't have been here . Yumour on the part of Master Bertram , Miss .
ROSEMARY . It 's very upsetting when you 're writing a play .
JAMES . Yes , Miss . Perhaps they could help you with it . The more the merrier , as you might say .
ROSEMARY . What a good idea , James . Admit them .

JAMES . Yes , Miss . ( He opens the door and says very rapidly ) The Misses Ada , Caroline , Elsie , Gwendoline , and Isabel Hubbard , The Masters Bertram , Dennis , Frank , and Harold Hubbard . ( They come in . )
ROSEMARY . How do you do ?
ADA . Rosemary , darling , what are you doing ?
BERTRAM . It 's like your cheek , bagging our room .
CAROLINE ( primly ) . Hush , Bertram . We ought always to be polite to our visitors when they stay with us . I am sure , if Rosemary wants our room ——
DENNIS . Oh , chuck it !
ADA ( at ROSEMARY 'S shoulder ) . Oh , I say , she 's writing a play !
( Uproar and turmoil , as they all rush at ROSEMARY . )
{ THE BOYS . Coo ! I say , shove me into it . What 's { it about ? Bet it 's awful rot . { { THE GIRLS . Oh , Rosemary ! Am I in it ? Do tell us { about it . Is it for Christmas ?
ROSEMARY ( in alarm ) . James , could you ——?

JAMES ( firmly ) . Quiet , there , quiet ! Down , Master Dennis , down ! Miss Gwendoline , if you would n't mind —— ( He picks her up and places her on the floor . ) Thank you . ( Order is restored . )
ROSEMARY . Thank you , James . . . . Yes , it 's a play for Christmas , and it is called “ Make-Believe , ” and that 's all I 'm certain about yet , except that we 're all going to be in it .
BERTRAM . Then I vote we have a desert island ——
DENNIS . And pirates ——
FRANK . And cannibals ——
HAROLD ( gloatingly ) . Cannibals eating people — Oo !
CAROLINE ( shocked ) . Harold ! How would you like to be eaten by a cannibal ?
DENNIS . Oh , chuck it ! How would you like to be a cannibal and have nobody to eat ? ( CAROLINE is silent , never having thought of this before . )
ADA . Let it be a fairy-story , Rosemary , darling . It 's so much prettier .
ELSIE . With a lovely princess ——
GWENDOLINE . And a humble woodcutter who marries her ——
ISABEL ( her only contribution ) . P'itty P'incess .
BERTRAM . Princesses are rot .
ELSIE ( with spirit ) . So are pirates ! ( Deadlock . )
CAROLINE . I should like something about Father Christmas , and snow , and waits , and a lovely ball , and everybody getting nice presents and things .
DENNIS ( selfishly , I 'm afraid ) . Bags I all the presents .
( Of course , the others are n't going to have that . They all say so together . )
ROSEMARY ( above the turmoil ) . James , I must have silence .
JAMES . Silence , all !
ROSEMARY . Thank you . . . . You will be interested to hear that I have decided to have a Fairy Story and a Desert Island and a Father Christmas .
ALL . Good ! ( Or words to that effect )

ROSEMARY ( biting her pen ) . I shall begin with the Fairy Story . ( There is an anxious silence . None of them has ever seen anybody writing a play before . How does one do it ? Alas , ROSEMARY herself does n't know . She appeals to JAMES . ) James , how do you begin a play ? I mean when you 've got the title .
JAMES ( a man of genius ) . Well , Miss Rosemary , seeing that it 's to be called “ Make-Believe , ” why not make-believe as it 's written already ?
ROSEMARY . What a good idea , James !
JAMES . All that is necessary is for the company to think very hard of what they want , and — there we are ! Saves all the bother of writing and spelling and what not .
ROSEMARY ( admiringly . ) James , how clever you are !
JAMES . So-so , Miss Rosemary .
ROSEMARY . Now then , let 's all think together . Are you all ready ?
ALL . Yes ! ( They clench their hands . )
ROSEMARY . Then one , two , three — Go !
( They think . . . . The truth is that JAMES , who was n't really meant to be in it , thinks too . If there is anything in the play which you do n't like , it is JAMES thinking . )

div.head: ACT I .— THE PRINCESS AND THE WOODCUTTER
div.stage: The WOODCUTTER is discovered singing at his work , in a glade of the forest outside his hut . He is tall and strong , and brave and handsome ; all that a woodcutter ought to be . Now it happened that the PRINCESS was passing , and as soon as his song is finished , sure enough , on she comes .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Good morning , Woodcutter .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Good morning .But he goes on with his work .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: after a pauseGood morning , Woodcutter .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Do n't you ever say anything except good morning ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Sometimes I say good-bye .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You are a cross woodcutter to-day .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I have work to do .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You are still cutting wood ? Do n't you ever do anything else ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Well , you are still a Princess ; do n't you ever do anything else ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: reproachfullyNow , that 's not fair , Woodcutter . You can n't say I was a Princess yesterday , when I came and helped you stack your wood . Or the day before , when I tied up your hand where you had cut it . Or the day before that , when we had our meal together on the grass . Was I a Princess then ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Somehow I think you were . Somehow I think you were saying to yourself , “ Is n't it sweet of a Princess to treat a mere woodcutter like this ? ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I think you 're perfectly horrid . I 've a good mind never to speak to you again . And — and I would , if only I could be sure that you would notice I was n't speaking to you .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: After all , I 'm just as bad as you . Only yesterday I was thinking to myself how unselfish I was to interrupt my work in order to talk to a mere Princess .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , but the trouble is that you do n't interrupt your work .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: interrupting it and going up to her with a smileMadam , I am at your service .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I wish I thought you were .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Surely you have enough people at your service already . Princes and Chancellors and Chamberlains and Waiting Maids .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , that 's just it . That 's why I want your help . Particularly in the matter of the Princes .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Why , has a suitor come for the hand of her Royal Highness ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Three suitors . And I hate them all .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: And which are you going to marry ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I do n't know . Father has n't made up his mind yet .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: And this is a matter which father — which His Majesty decides for himself ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why , of course ! You should read the History Books , Woodcutter . The suitors to the hand of a Princess are always set some trial of strength or test of quality by the King , and the winner marries his daughter .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Well , I do n't live in a Palace , and I think my own thoughts about these things . I 'd better get back to my work .He goes on with his chopping .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: gently , after a pauseWoodcutter !

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: looking upOh , are you there ? I thought you were married by this time .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: meeklyI do n't want to be married .HastilyI mean , not to any of those three .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: You can n't help yourself .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I know . That 's why I wanted you to help me .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: going up to herCan a simple woodcutter help a Princess ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , perhaps a simple one could n't , but a clever one might .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: What would his reward be ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: His reward would be that the Princess , not being married to any of her three suitors , would still be able to help him chop his wood in the mornings . . . . I am helping you , are n't I ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: smilingOh , decidedly .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: noddingI thought I was .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: It is kind of a great lady like yourself to help so humble a fellow as I .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: meeklyI 'm not very great .And she is n't . She is the smallest , daintiest little Princess that ever you saw .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: There 's enough of you to make a hundred men unhappy .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: And one man happy ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: And one man very , very happy .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: innocentlyI wonder who he 'll be . . . . Woodcutter , if you were a Prince , would you be my suitor ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: scornfullyOne of three ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: excitedlyOo , would you kill the others ? With that axe ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I would not kill them , in order to help His Majesty make up his mind about his son-in-law . But if the Princess had made up her mind — and wanted me ——

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Then I would marry her , however many suitors she had .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , she 's only got three at present .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: What is that to me ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Oh , I just thought you might want to be doing something to your axe .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: My axe ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes . You see , she has made up her mind .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: amazedYou mean — But — but I 'm only a woodcutter .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: That 's where you 'll have the advantage of them , when it comes to axes .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Princess !He takes her in his armsMy Princess !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Woodcutter ! My woodcutter ! My , oh so very slow and uncomprehending , but entirely adorable woodcutter !

div.stage: They sing together . They just happen to feel like that

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: the song finishedBut what will His Majesty say ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: All sorts of things . . . . Do you really love me , woodcutter , or have I proposed to you under a misapprehension ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I adore you !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: noddingI thought you did . But I wanted to hear you say it . If I had been a simple peasant , I suppose you would have said it a long time ago ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I expect so .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: noddingYes . . . . Well , now we must think of a plan for making Mother like you .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Might I just kiss you again before we begin ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , I do n't quite see how I am to stop you .

div.stage: The WOODCUTTER picks her up in his arms and kisses her .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: There !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: in his armsOh , Woodcutter , woodcutter , why did n't you do that the first day I saw you ? Then I need n't have had the bother of proposing to you .He puts her down suddenlyWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: listeningSomebody coming .He peers through the trees and then says in surpriseThe King !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Oh ! I must fly !

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: But you 'll come back ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Perhaps .

div.stage: She disappears quickly through the trees .
The WOODCUTTER goes on with his work and is discovered at it a minute later by the KING and QUEEN .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: puffingAh ! and a seat all ready for us . How satisfying .They sit down , a distinguished couple — reading from left to right , “ KING , QUEEN ” — on a bench outside the WOODCUTTER 'S hut .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: crossly — she was like thatI do n't know why you dragged me here .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: As I told you , my love , to be alone .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Well , you are n't alone .She indicates the WOODCUTTER .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Pooh , he does n't matter . . . . Well now , about these three Princes . They are getting on my mind rather . It is time we decided which one of them is to marry our beloved child . The trouble is to choose between them .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: As regards appetite , there is nothing to choose between them . They are three of the heartiest eaters I have met for some time .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: You are right . The sooner we choose one of them , and send the other two about their business , the better .ReflectivelyThere were six peaches on the breakfast-table this morning . Did I get one ? No .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Did I get one ? No .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Did our darling child get one — not that it matters ? No .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: It is a pity that the seven-headed bull died last year .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Yes , he had a way of sorting out competitors for the hand of our beloved one that was beyond all praise . One could have felt quite sure that , had the three competitors been introduced to him , only one of them would have taken any further interest in the matter .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: always the housekeeperAnd even he might n't have taken any interest in his meals .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: with a sighHowever , those days are over . We must think of a new test . Somehow I think that , in a son-in-law , moral worth is even more to be desired than mere brute strength . Now my suggestion is this : that you should disguise yourself as a beggar woman and approach each of the three princes in turn , supplicating their charity . In this way we shall discover which of the three has the kindest heart . What do you say , my dear ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: An excellent plan . If you remember , I suggested it myself yesterday .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: annoyedWell , of course , it had been in my mind for some time . I do n't claim that the idea is original ; it has often been done in our family .Getting upWell then , if you will get ready , my dear , I will go and find our three friends and see that they come this way .

div.stage: They go out together .
As soon as they are out of sight the PRINCESS comes back .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , Woodcutter , what did I tell you ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: What did you tell me ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Did n't you listen to what they said ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I did n't listen , but I could n't help hearing .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , I could n't help listening . And unless you stop it somehow , I shall be married to one of them to-night .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Which one ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: The one with the kindest heart — whichever that is .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Supposing they all three have kind hearts ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: confidentlyThey wo n't . They never have . In our circles when three Princes come together , one of them has a kind heart and the other two have n't .SurprisedHave n't you read any History at all ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I have no time for reading . But I think it 's time History was altered a little . We 'll alter it this afternoon .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Leave this to me . I 've got an idea .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: clapping her handsOh , how clever of you ! But what do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: pointingYou know the glade over there where the brook runs through it ? Wait for me there .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I obey my lord 's commands .

div.stage: She blows him a kiss and runs off
The WOODCUTTER resumes his work . By and by the RED PRINCE comes along . He is a — well , you will see for yourself what he is like .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: Ah , fellow . . . . Fellow ! . . . I said fellow !Yes , that sort of man .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: looking up .Were you speaking to me , my lord ?

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: There is no other fellow here that I can see .

div.stage: The WOODCUTTER looks round to make sure , peers behind a tree or two , and comes back to the PRINCE .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Yes , you must have meant me .

lg.l: Yes , of course I meant you , fellow . Have you seen the
Princess come past this way ? I was told she was waiting for me here .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: She is not here , my lord .Looking round to see that they are aloneMy lord , are you one of the Princes who is seeking the hand of the Princess .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: complacentlyI am , fellow .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: His Majesty the King was here a while ago . He is to make his decision between you this afternoon .MeaninglyI think I can help you to be the lucky one , my lord .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: You suggest that I take an unfair advantage over my fellow-competitors ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I suggest nothing , my lord . I only say that I can help you .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: magnanimouslyWell , I will allow you to help me .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Thank you . Then I will give you this advice . If a beggar woman asks you for a crust of bread this afternoon , remember — it is the test !

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: staggeredThe test ! But I have n't got a crust of bread !

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Wait here and I will get you one .

div.stage: He goes into the hut

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: speaking after him as he goesMy good fellow , I am extremely obliged to you , and if ever I can do anything for you , such as returning a crust to you of similar size , or even lending you another slightly smaller one , or ——The WOODCUTTER comes back with the crust .Ah , thank you , my man , thank you .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I would suggest , my lord , that you should take a short walk in this directionpointing to the opposite direction to that which the PRINCESS has taken, and stroll back casually in a few minutes ’ time when the Queen is here .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: Thank you , my man , thank you .

div.stage: He puts the crust in his pocket and goes off . ) ( The WOODCUTTER goes on with his work . The BLUE PRINCE comes in and stands watching him in silence for some moments . ) WOODCUTTER ( looking up ) . Hullo !

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Hullo !

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: The Princess .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: She 's not here .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: The WOODCUTTER goes on with his work and the PRINCE goes on looking at him .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: struck with an ideaAre you one of the Princes who is wooing the Princess ?

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: coming towards himI believe I could help your Royal Highness .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: DO .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: doubtfullyIt would perhaps be not Quite fair to the others .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Do n't mind .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Well then , listen .He pauses a moment and looks round to see that they are alone .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: I 'm listening .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: If you come back in five minutes , you will see a beggar woman sitting here . She will ask you for a crust of bread . You must give it to her , for it is the way His Majesty has chosen of testing your kindness of heart .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: feeling in his pocketsNo bread .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: I will give you some .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Do .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: taking a piece from his pocketHere you are .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Thanks .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Not at all , I 'm very glad to have been able to help you .

div.stage: He goes on with his work . The BLUE PRINCE remains looking at him .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: with a great effortThanks .

div.stage: He goes slowly away . A moment later the YELLOW PRINCE makes a graceful and languid entry .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Ah , come hither , my man , come hither .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: stopping his work and looking upYou want me , sir ?

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Come hither , my man . Tell me , has her Royal Highness the Princess passed this way lately ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: The Princess ?

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Yes , the Princess , my bumpkin . But perhaps you have been too much concerned in your own earthy affairs to have noticed her . You — ah — cut wood , I see .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Yes , sir , I am a woodcutter .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: A most absorbing life . Some day we must have a long talk about it . But just now I have other business waiting for me . With your permission , good friend , I will leave you to your faggots .He starts to go .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Beg your pardon , sir , but are you one of those Princes that want to marry our Princess ?

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: I had hoped , good friend , to obtain your permission to do so . I beg you not to refuse it .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: You are making fun of me , sir .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Discerning creature .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: All the same , I can help you .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Then pray do so , log-chopper , and earn my everlasting gratitude .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: The King has decided that whichever of you three Princes has the kindest heart shall marry his daughter .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Then you will be able to bear witness to him that I have already wasted several minutes of my valuable time in condescending to a mere faggot-splitter . Tell him this and the prize is mine .Kissing the tips of his fingersPrincess , I embrace you .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: The King will not listen to me . But if you return here in five minutes , you will find an old woman begging for bread . It is the test which their Majesties have arranged for you . If you share your last crust with her —

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Yes , but do I look as if I carried a last crust about with me ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: But see , I will give you one .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: taking it between the tips of his fingersYes , but —

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Put it in your pocket , and when —

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: But , my dear bark-scraper , have you no feeling for clothes at all ? How can I put a thing like this in my pocket ?Handing it back to himI beg you to wrap it up . Here take this .Gives him a scarfNeatly , I pray you .Taking an orange ribbon out of his pocketPerhaps a little of this round it would make it more tolerable . You think so ? I leave it to you . I trust your taste entirely . . . . Leaving a loop for the little finger , I entreat you . . . so .He hangs it on his little fingerIn about five minutes , you said ? We will be there .With a bowWe thank you .

div.stage: He departs delicately . The WOODCUTTER smiles to himself , puts down his axe and goes off to the PRINCESS . And just in time . For behold ! the KING and QUEEN return . At least we think it is the QUEEN , but she is so heavily disguised by a cloak which she wears over her court dress , that for a moment we are not quite sure .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Now then , my love , if you will sit down on that log there —placing her— excellent — I think perhaps you should remove the crown .Removes itThere ! Now the disguise is perfect .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: You 're sure they are coming ? It 's a very uncomfortable seat .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I told them that the Princess was waiting for them here . Their natural disappointment at finding I was mistaken will make the test of their good nature an even more exacting one . My own impression is that the Yellow Prince will be the victor .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Oh , I hate that man .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: soothinglyWell , well , perhaps it will be the Blue one .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: If anything , I dislike him more intensely .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Or even the Red .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Ugh ! I can n't bear him .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Fortunately , dear , you are not called upon to marry any of them . It is for our darling that we are making the great decision . Listen ! I hear one coming . I will hide in the cottage and take note of what happens .

div.stage: He disappears into the cottage as the BLUE PRINCE comes in .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Oh , sir , can you kindly spare a crust of bread for a poor old woman ! Please , pretty gentleman !

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: standing stolidly in front of her and feeling in his pocketBread . . . Bread . . . Ah ! Bread !He offers it .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Oh , thank you , sir . May you be rewarded for your gentle heart .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: He stands gazing at her . There is an awkward pause .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: A blessing on you , sir .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Thank you .He indicates the crustBread .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Ah , you have saved the life of a poor old woman ——

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Eat it .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: embarrassedI — er — you — er — -She takes a bite and mumbles something .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: swallowing with great difficultyI 'm almost too happy to eat , sir . Leave a poor old woman alone with her happiness , and — -

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Not too happy . Too weak . Help you eat .He breaks off a piece and holds it to her mouth . With a great effort the QUEEN disposes of it .Good ! . . . Again !She does it again .Now !She swallows another piece .Last piece !She takes it in . He pats her kindly on the back , and she nearly chokes .Good . . . . Better now ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: weaklyMuch .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Good day .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: with an effortGood day , kind gentleman .

div.stage: He goes out .
The KING is just coming from the cottage , when he returns suddenly . The KING slips back again .

sp.speaker: BLUE PRINCE
sp.p: Small piece left over .He gives it to her . She looks hopelessly at him .Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: throwing the piece down violentlyUgh ! What a man !

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: coming outWell , well , my dear , we have discovered the winner .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: from the heartDetestable person !

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: The rest of the competition is of course more in the nature of a formality —

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Thank goodness .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: However , I think that it will prevent unnecessary discussion afterwards if we — Take care , here is another one .He hurries back .

div.stage: Enter the RED PRINCE .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: with not nearly so much convictionCould you spare a crust of bread , sir , for a poor hungry old woman ?

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: A crust of bread , madam ? Certainly . As luck will have it , I have a crust on me . My last one , but — your need is greater than mine . Eat , I pray .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Th-thank you , sir .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: Not at all . Come , eat . Let me have the pleasure of seeing you eating .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: M-might I take it home with me , pretty gentleman ?

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: firmlyNo , no . I must see you eating . Come ! I will take no denial .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Th-thank you , sir .HopefullyWo n't you share it with me ?

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: No , I insist on your having it all . I am in the mood to be generous . Oblige me by eating it now for I am in a hurry ; yet I will not go until you have eaten .She does her best .You eat but slowly .SternlyDid you deceive me when you said you were hungry ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: N-no . I 'm very hungry .She eats

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: That 's better . Now understand — however poor I am , I can always find a crust of bread for an old woman . Always ! Remember this when next you are hungry . . . . You spoke ?She shakes her head and goes on eating .Finished ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: with great difficultyYes , thank you , pretty gentleman .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: There 's a piece on the ground there that you dropped .She eats it in dumb agonyFinished ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: huskilyYes , thank you , pretty gentleman .

sp.speaker: RED PRINCE
sp.p: Then I will leave you , madam . Good morning .

div.stage: He goes out .

The QUEEN rises in fury . The KING is about to come out of the cottage , when the YELLOW PRINCE enters . The QUEEN sits down again and mumbles something . It is certainly not an appeal for bread , but the YELLOW PRINCE is not to be denied .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: gallantlyMy poor woman , you are in distress . It pains me to see it , madam , it pains me terribly . Can it be that you are hungry ? I thought so , I thought so . Give me the great pleasure , madam , of relieving your hunger . Seeholding up his finger, my own poor meal . Take it ! It is yours .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: with difficultyI am not hungry .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Ah , madam , I see what it is . You do not wish to deprive me . You tell yourself , perchance , that it is not fitting that one in your station of life should partake of the meals of the highly born . You are not used , you say , to the food of Princes . Your rougher palate ——

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: hopefullyDid you say food of princes ?

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Where was I , madam ? You interrupted me . No matter — eat .She takes the scarf and unties the ribbon .Ah , now I remember . I was saying that your rougher palate — -

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: discovering the worstNo ! No ! Not bread !

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: Bread , madam , the staff of life . Come , madam , will you not eat ?She tries desperately .What can be more delightful than a crust of bread by the wayside ?

div.stage: The QUEEN shrieks and falls back in a swoon . The KING rushes out to her .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: to YELLOW PRINCEQuick , quick , find the Princess .

sp.speaker: YELLOW PRINCE
sp.p: The Princess — find the Princess !He goes vaguely off and we shall not see him again . But the WOODCUTTER and the PRINCESS do not need to be found . They are here .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: to PRINCESSGo to her , but do n't show that you know me .

div.stage: He goes into the cottage , and the PRINCESS hastens to her father .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Father !

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Ah , my dear , you 're just in time . Your mother — -

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: My mother ?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Yes , yes . A little plan of mine — of hers — your poor mother . Dear , dear !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: She is suffering from a surfeit of bread , and — -

div.stage: The WOODCUTTER comes up with a flagon of wine

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Poor old woman ! She has fainted from exhaustion . Let me give her some — -

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: shriekingNo , no , not bread ! I will not have any more bread .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Drink this , my poor woman .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: opening her eyesDid you say drink ?She seizes the flagon and drinks

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Oh , sir , you have saved my mother 's life !

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I thank you , my man , I thank you .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: My deliverer ! Tell me who you are !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: It is my mother , the Queen , who asks you .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: amazed , as well he may beThe Queen !

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Yes , yes . Certainly , the Queen .

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: taking off his hatPardon , your Majesty . I am a woodcutter , who lives alone here , far away from courts .

lg.l: Well , you 've got more sense in your head than any of the
Princes that I 've seen lately . You 'd better come to court .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: shylyYou will be very welcome , sir .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: And you 'd better marry the Princess .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Is n't that perhaps going a little too far , dear ?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Well , you wanted kindness of heart in your son-in-law , and you 've got it . And he 's got common sense too .To WOODCUTTERTell me , what do you think of bread as — as a form of nourishment ?

sp.speaker: WOODCUTTER
sp.p: cautiouslyOne can have too much of it .

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Exactly my view .To KINGThere you are , you see .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Well , if you insist . The great thing , of course , is that our darling child should be happy .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I will do my best , father .She takes the WOODCUTTER 'S hand .

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Then the marriage will take place this evening .With a wave of his wandLet the revels begin .

div.stage: They begin

div.head: SCENE I .— The Schoolroom ( Ugh ! )

stage.stage: ( OLIVER is discovered lying flat on his — well , lying flat on the floor , deep in a book . The CURATE puts his head in at the door . )

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: Ah , our young friend , Oliver ! And how are we this morning , dear lad ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: mumblingAll right , thanks .

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: That 's well , that 's well . Deep in our studies , I see , deep in our studies . And what branch of Knowledge are we pursuing this morning ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: without looking up“ Marooned in the Pacific , ” or “ The Pirate 's Bride . ”

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: Dear , dear , what will Miss Pinniger say to this interruption of our studies ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Silly old beast .

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: Tut-tut , dear lad , that is not the way to speak of our mentors and preceptors . So refined and intelligent a lady as Miss Pinniger . Indeed I came here to see her this morning on a little matter of embroidered vestments . Where is she , dear lad ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: It is n't nine yet .

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: looking at his watchPast nine , past nine .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: jumping upJe-hoshaphat !

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: Oliver ! Oliver ! My dear lad ! Swearing at your age ! Really , I almost feel it my duty to inform your aunt — -

lg.l: Fat lot of swearing in just mentioning one of the Kings of
Israel .

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: Of Judah , dear boy , of Judah . To be ignorant on such a vital matter makes it even more reprehensible . I cannot believe that our dear Miss Pinniger has so neglected your education that ——

div.stage: Enter our dear MISS PINNIGER , the Governess .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Ah , Mr. Smilax ; how pleasant to see you !

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: My dear Miss Pinniger ! You will forgive me for interrupting you in your labours , but there is a small matter of — ah !— -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Certainly , Mr. Smilax . I will walk down to the gate with you . Oliver , where is Geraldine ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Aunt Jane wanted her .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Well , you should be at your lessons . It 's nine o'clock . The fact that I am momentarily absent from the room should make no difference to your zeal .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: without convictionNo , Miss Pinniger .He sits down at his desk , putting “ Marooned in the Pacific ” inside it .

sp.speaker: CURATE
sp.p: playfullyThey go out .For men must work , Oliver , men must work . How doth the little busy bee — Yes , Miss Pinniger , I am with you .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: opening his poetry book and saying it to himselfIt was a summer evening — It was a summer evening —He stops , refers to the book , and then goes on to himselfOld Kaspar 's work was done . It was a summer evening , Old Kaspar 's work was done — -

div.stage: Enter GERALDINE — or JILL .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Where 's Pin ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Hallo , Jill . Gone off with Dearly Belovéd . Her momentary absence from the room should make no difference to your zeal , my dear Geraldine . And what are we studying this morning , dear child ?To himselfIt was a summer evening , Old Kaspar 's work was done .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: gigglingIs that Pin ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Pin and Dearly Belovéd between them . She 's a bit batey this morning .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: at her deskAnd all my sums have done themselves wrong .Hard at it with paper and pencilWhat 's nine times seven , Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Fifty-six . Old Kaspar 's work was done . Jolly well wish mine was . And he before his cottage door . Fat lot of good my learning this stuff if I 'm going to be a sailor . I bet Beatty did n't mind what happened to rotten old Kaspar when he saw a German submarine .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Six and carry five . Aunt Jane has sent for the doctor to look at my chest .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: What 's the matter with your chest ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I blew my nose rather loud at prayers this morning .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I say , Jill , you are going it !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: It was n't my fault , Oliver . Aunt Jane turned over two pages at once and made me laugh , so I had to turn it into a blow .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Bet you what you like she knew .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Of course she did , and she 'll tell the doctor , and he 'll be as beastly as he can . What did she say to you for being late ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I said somebody had bagged my sponge , and she would n't like me to come down to prayers all unsponged , and she said , “ Excuses , Oliver , always excuses ! Leave me . I will see you later . ” Suppose that means I 've got to go to bed this afternoon . Jill , if I do , be sporty and bring me up “ Marooned in the Pacific . ”

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: They 'll lock the door . They always do .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Then I shall jolly well go up for a handkerchief this morning , and shove it in the bed , just in case . Cavé — here 's Pin .

sp.speaker: MISS PINNIGER
sp.p: returns to find them full of zeal .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: sitting down at her deskWell , Oliver , have you learnt your piece of poetry ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: nervouslyI — I think so , Miss Pinniger .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Close the book , and stand up and say it .Oliver takes a last despairing look , and stands up .Well ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: It was a summer evening — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: The title and the author first , Oliver . Everything in its proper order .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oh , I say , I did n't know I had to learn the title .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: in a whisperAfter Blenheim .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Geraldine , kindly attend to your own work .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: After Blenheim . It was a summer evening .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: After Blenheim , by Robert Southey . One of our greatest poets .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: After Blenheim , by Robert Southey , one of our greatest poets . It was a summer evening , Old Kaspar 's work was done — er — Old Kaspar 's work was done — er — work was done , er . . .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: And he before — -

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oh yes , of course . And he before — er — and he before — er — It was a summer evening , Old Kaspar 's work was done , and he before — er — and he before — - Er , it was a summer evening — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: So you have already said , Oliver .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I just seem to have forgotten this bit , Miss Pinniger . And he before — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Well , what was he before ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: hopefullyBlenheim ? Oh no , it was after Blenheim .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: wearilyHis cottage door .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oo , yes . And he before his cottage door was sitting in the sun .He clears his throatWas sitting in the sun . Er —He coughs again— er — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: You have a cough , Oliver . Perhaps the doctor had better see you when he comes to see Geraldine .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: It was just something tickling my throat , Miss Pinniger . Er — it was a summer evening .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: You have n't learnt it , Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Yes , I have , Miss Pinniger , only I can n't quite remember it . And he before his cottage door — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Is it any good , Geraldine , asking you if you have got any of your sums right ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I 've got one , Miss Pinniger . . . nearly right . . . except for some of the figures .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Well , we shall have to spend more time at our lessons , that 's all . This afternoon — ah — er — -

div.stage: She stands up as AUNT JANE and the DOCTOR come in .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: I 'm sorry to interrupt lessons , Miss Pinniger , but I have brought the Doctor to see Geraldine .To DOCTORYou will like her to go to her room ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No , no , dear lady . There is no need . Her pulse —He feels it— - dear , dear ! Her tongue —She puts it out— tut-tut ! A milk diet , plenty of rice-pudding , and perhaps she would do well to go to bed this afternoon .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: I will see to it , doctor .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: mutinouslyI feel quite well .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: to AUNT JANEA dangerous symptom . Plenty of rice-pudding .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Oliver was coughing just now .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: to himselfShut up !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: turning to OLIVERAh ! His pulse —Feels it— tut-tut ! His tongue —OLIVER puts it outDear , dear ! The same treatment , dear lady , as prescribed in the other case .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: under his breathBeast !

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: Castor-oil , liquorice-powder , ammoniated quinine — anything of that nature , doctor ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: As necessary , dear lady , as necessary . The system must be stimulated . Nature must be reinforced .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: to GOVERNESSWhich do they dislike least ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: and JILLhastilyLiquorice-powder !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Then concentrate on the other two , dear lady .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: They go out .Thank you , doctor .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: We will now go on with our lessons . Oliver , you will have opportunities in your bedroom this afternoon of learning your poetry . By the way , I had better have that book which you were reading when I came in just now .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: trying to be surprisedWhich book ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: nobly doing her best to save the situationMiss Pinniger , if you 're multiplying rods , poles , or perches by nine , does it matter if — -

lg.l: I am talking to Oliver , Geraldine . Where is that book ,
Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oh , I know the one you mean . I must have put it down somewhere .He looks vaguely about the room .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Perhaps you put it in your desk .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: My desk ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: going up to MISS PINNIGER with her workYou see , it 's all gone wrong here , and I think I must have multiplied ——Moving in front of her as she movesI think I must have multiplied ——

div.stage: Under cover of this , OLIVER makes a great effort to get the book into JILL 'S desk , but it is no good .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: brushing aside JILL and advancing on OLIVERThank you , I will take it .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: looking at the titleOh yes , this is the one .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: She goes out .And I will speak to your aunt at once about the behaviour of both of you .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: gallantlyI do n't care .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I did try to help you , Oliver .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: You wait . Wo n't I jolly well bag something of hers one day , just when she wants it .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 'll find the afternoon rather tiring without your book . What will you do ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I suppose I shall have to think .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: What shall you think about ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I shall think I 'm on my desert island .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Which desert island ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: The one I always pretend I 'm on when I 'm thinking .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Is n't there any one else on it ever ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oo , lots of pirates and Dyaks and cannibals and — other people .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: What sort of other people ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I sha n't tell you . This is a special think I thought last night . As soon as I thought of it , I decided to keep it forimpressivelya moment of great emergency .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: silencedOh ! . . . Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER Y
sp.p: es ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Let me be on your desert island this time . Because I did try to help you .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Well — well ——GenerouslyWell , you can if you like .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , thank you , Oliver . Wo n't you tell me what it 's about , and then we can both think it together this afternoon .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I expect you 'll think all sorts of silly things that never happen on a desert island .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I 'll try not to , Oliver , if you tell me .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: coming close to himGo on .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Well , you see , I 've been wrecked , you see , and the ship has foundered with all hands , you see , and I 've been cast ashore on a desert island , you see .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Have n't I been cast ashore too ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Well , you will be this afternoon , of course . Well , you see , we land on the island , you see , and it 's a perfectly ripping island , you see , and — and we land on it , you see , and . . . .

div.stage: But we are getting on too fast . When the good ship crashed upon the rock and split in twain , it seemed like that all aboard must perish . Fortunately OLIVER was made of stern mettle . Hastily constructing a raft and placing the now unconscious JILL upon it , he launched it into the seething maelstrom of waters and pushed off . Tossed like a cockle-shell upon the mountainous waves , the tiny craft with its precious freight was in imminent danger of foundering . But OLIVER was made of stern mettle . With dauntless courage he rigged a jury-mast , and placed a telescope to his eye . “ Pull for the lagoon , JILL , ” cried the dauntless OLIVER , and in another moment . . . .

As the raft glides into the still waters beyond the reef , we can see it more clearly . Can it be JILL 'S bed , with OLIVER in his pyjamas perched on the rail , and holding up his bath-towel ? Does he shorten sail for a moment to thump his chest and say , “ But OLIVER was made of stern mettle ” ? Or is it ——

But the sun is sinking behind the swamp where the rattlesnakes bask . For a moment longer the sail gleams like copper in its rays , and then — fizz-z — we have lost it . See ! Is that speck on the inky black waters the dauntless Oliver ? It is . Let us follow to the island and see what adventures befall him .

div.head: SCENE II .— It is the island which we have dreamed about all our lives .

stage.stage: But at present we cannot see it properly , for it is dark . In one of those tropical darknesses which can be felt rather than seen OLIVER hands JILL out of the boat .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Tread carefully , Jill , there are lots of deadly rattlesnakes about .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: stepping hastily back into the boatOli-ver !

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: You hear the noise of their rattles sometimes when the sun is sinking behind the swamp .The deadly rattle of the rattlesnake is heardThere !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , Oliver , are they very deadly ? Because if they are , I do n't think I shall like your island .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Those are n't . I always have their teeth taken out when ladies are coming . Besides , it 's daylight now .

div.stage: With a rapidity common in the tropics — although it may just be OLIVER 'S gallantry — the sun climbs out of the sea , and floods the island , JILL , no longer frightened , steps out of the boat , and they walk up to the clearing in the middle .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: looking about herOh , what a lovely island ! I think it 's lovely , Oliver .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: modestlyIt 's pretty decent , is n't it ? Wo n't you lie down ? I generally lie down here and watch the turtles coming out of the sea to deposit their eggs on the sand .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: lying downHow many do they de-deposit usually , Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oh , three — or a hundred . Just depends how hungry I am . Have a bull'shYpppHeNeye , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: excitedlyOh , did you bring some ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: annoyedBring some ?Brightening upOh , you mean from the wreck ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: hastilyYes , from the wreck . I mean besides the axe and the bag of nails and the gunpowder .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Could n't . The ship sank with all hands before I could get them . But it does n't matter , becausegoing up to one of the treesI recognise this as the bull'shYpppHeNeye tree .He picks a couple of bull'shYpppHeNeyes and gives one to her .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , Oliver , how lovely ! Thank you .She puts it in her mouth .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: sucking hardThere was nothing but breadfruit trees here the first time I was marooned on it . Rotten things to have on a decent island . So I planted a bull'shYpppHeNeye tree , and a barley-sugar-cane grove , and one or two other things , and made a jolly ripping place of it .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: pointingWhat 's that tree over there ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: That one ? Rice-pudding tree .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: getting up indignantlyOliver ! Take me back to the boat at once .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I say , shut up , Jill . You did n't think I meant it for you , did you ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: But there 's only you and me on the island .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: What about the domestic animals ? I suppose they 've got to eat .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , how lovely ! Have we got a goat and a parrot , and a — a —

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Much better than that . Look in that cage there .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , is that a cage ? I never noticed it . What do I do ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: going to itHere , I 'll show youHe draws the blind , and the DOCTOR is exposed sitting on a stump of wood and blinking at the sudden lightWhat do you think of that ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oliver !

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: proudlyI thought of that in bed one night . Spiffing idea , is n't it ? I 've got some other ones in the plantation over there . Awfully good specimens . I feed ‘ em on rice-pudding .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Can this one talk ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I 'm teaching it .Stirring it up with a stickCome up there .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: mumblingNinety-nine , ninety-nine . . .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: That 's all it can say at present . I 'm going to give it a swim in the lagoon to-morrow . I want to see if there are any sharks . If there are n't , then we can bathe there afterwards .

div.stage: The DOCTOR shudders .

lg.l: Have you given it a name yet ? I think I should like to call it
Fluffkins .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Righto ! Good night , Fluffkins . Time little doctors were in bed .He pulls down the blind .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: lying down againWell , I think it 's a lovely island .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: lying beside herIf there 's anything you want , you know , you 've only got to say so . Pirates or anything like that . There 's a ginger-beer well if you 're thirsty .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: closing her eyesI 'm quite happy , Oliver , thank you .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: after a pause , a little awkwardlyJill , you did n't ever want to marry a pirate , did you ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: still on her back with her eyes shutI had n't thought about it much , Oliver dear .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Because I can get you an awfully decent pirate , if you like , and if I was his brother-in-law it would be ripping . I 've often been marooned with him , of course , but never as his brother-in-law .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Why do n't you marry his daughter and be his son-in-law ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: He has n't got a daughter .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Well , you could think him one .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I do n't want to . If ever I 'm such a silly ass as to marry , which I 'm jolly well not going to be , I shall marry a — a dusky maiden . Jill , be sporty . All girls have to get married some time . It 's different with men .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Very well , Oliver . I do n't want to spoil your afternoon .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Good biz .He stands up , shuts his eyes and waves his hands about .

div.stage: Enter the PIRATE CHIEF .

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: with a flourishGentles , your servant . Commodore Crookshank , at your service . Better known on the Spanish Main as One-eared Eric .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Glad to meet you , Commodore . I 'm — er — Two-toed Thomas , the Terror of the Dyaks . But you may call me Oliver , if you like . This is my sister Jill — the Pride of the Pampas .

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: with another bowCharmed !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: politelyDo n't mention it , Commodore .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: My sister wants to marry you . Er — carry on .He moves a little away from them and lies down .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: sitting down and indicating a place beside herWo n't you sit down , Commodore ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: Thank you , madam . The other side if I may . I shall hear better if you condescend to accept me .He sits down on the other side of her .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so sorry ! I was forgetting about your ear .

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: Do n't mention it . A little discussion in the La Plata river with a Spanish gentleman . At the end of it I was an ear short and he was a head short . It was considered in the family that I had won .

div.stage: There is an awkward pause .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: shylyWell , Commodore ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: Wo n't you call me Eric ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I am waiting , Eric .

sp.speaker: PIRATE CHIEF
sp.p: Madam , I am not a marrying man , not to any extent , but if you would care to be Mrs. Crookshank , I 'd undertake on my part to have the deck swabbed every morning , and to put a polish on the four-pounder that you could see your pretty face in .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Eric , how sweet of you . But I think you must speak to my brother in the library first . Oli-ver !

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: coming upHallo ! Settled it ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: It 's all settled , Oliver , between Eric and myself , but you will want to ask him about his prospects , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Yes , yes , of course .

lg.l: I shall be very glad to tell you anything I can , sir . I think
I may say that I am doing fairly well in my profession .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: What 's your ship ? A sloop or a frigate ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: A brigantine .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: excitedOh , that 's what Oliver puts on his hair when he goes to a party .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: annoyedShut up , Jill ! A brigantine ? Ah yes , a rakish craft , eh , Commodore ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: earnestlyExtremely rakish .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: And how many pieces of eight have you ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Nine thousand .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Ah !To JILLWhat 's nine times eight ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: to herselfNine times eight .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: to himselfNine times eight .

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: to himselfNine times eight .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Seventy-two .

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: I made it seventy-one , but I expect you 're right .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Then you 've seventy-two thousand pieces altogether ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Yes , sir , about that .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Any doubloons ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Hundreds of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Ingots of gold ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Lashings of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: And he 's going to polish up the four-pounder until I can see my face in it .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I was just going to ask you about your guns . You 've got ‘ em fore and aft of course ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Yes , sir . A four-pounder fore and a half-pounder haft .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: a little embarrassedAnd do you ever have brothers-in-law in your ship ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Well , I never have had yet , but I have always been looking about for one .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , Oliver , is n't Eric a nice man ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: casuallyI suppose the captain 's brother-in-law is generally the first man to board the Spaniard with his cutlass between his teeth ?

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: You might almost say always . Many a ship on the Spanish Main I 've had to leave unboarded through want of a brother-in-law . They 're touchy about it somehow . Unless the captain 's brother-in-law comes first they get complaining .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: bashfullyAnd there 's just one other thing . If the brigantine happened to put in at an island for water , and the captain 's brother-in-law happened — just happened — to be a silly ass and go and marry a dusky maiden , whom he met on the beach — -

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Bless you , it 's always happening to a captain 's brother-in-law .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: in a magnificent mannerThen , Captain Crookshank , you may take my sister !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Thank you , Oliver .

div.stage: It is not every day that one-eared ERIC , that famous chieftain , marries into the family of the TERROR OF THE DYAKS . Naturally the occasion is celebrated by the whole pirate crew with a rousing chorus , followed by a dance in which the dusky maidens of the Island join . At the end of it , JILL finds herself alone with TUA-HEETA , the Dusky Princess .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: fashionablyI 'm so pleased to meet my brother 's future wife . It 's so nice of you to come to see me . You will have some tea , wo n't you ?She puts out her hand and presses an imaginary bellI wanted to see you , because I can tell you so many little things about my brother , which I think you ought to know . You see , Eric — my husband —

sp.speaker: TUA-HEETA
sp.p: Ereec ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Yes . I wish you could see him . He 's so nice-looking . But I 'm afraid he wo n't be home to tea . That 's the worst of marrying a sailor . They are away so much . Well , I was telling you about Oliver . I think it would be better if you knew at once that — he does n't like rice-pudding .

sp.speaker: TUA-HEETA
sp.p: Rice-poodeeng ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Yes , he hates it . It is very important that you should remember that . Then there 's another thing —An untidy looking servant comes in . Can it be — can it possibly be AUNT JANE ? Horrors !He dislikes — Oh , there you are , Jane . You 've been a very long time answering the bell .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: I 'm so sorry ma'am , I was just dressing .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Excuses , Jane , always excuses . Leave me . Take a week 's notice .To TUA-HEETAYOU must excuse my maid . She 's very stupid . Tea at once , Jane .AUNT JANE sniffs and goes offWhat was I saying ? Oh yes , about Oliver . He does n't care for cod-liver oil in the way that some men do . You would be wise not to force it on him just at first . . . . Have you any idea where you are going to live ?

sp.speaker: TUA-HEETA
sp.p: Live ?These dusky maidens are no conversationalists .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I expect Oliver will wish to reside at Hammersmith , so convenient for the City . You 'll like Hammersmith . You 'll go to St. Paul 's Church , I expect . The Vicar will be sure to call .Enter AUNT JANE with small tea-table .Ah , here 's tea .To JANEYou 're very slow , Jane .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: I 'm sorry , ma'am .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: It 's no good being sorry . Take another week 's notice .To TUA-HEETAYou must forgive my talking to my maid . She wants such a lot of looking after .JANE puts down the tableThat will do , Jane ,JANE bumps against the tableDear , dear , how clumsy you are . What wages am I giving you now ?

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: A shilling a month , ma'am .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Well , we 'd better make it ninepence .JANE goes out in tears .Servants are a great nuisance , are n't they ? Jane is a peculiarly stupid person . She used to be aunt to my brother , and I have only taken her on out of charity .She pours out from an imaginary tea-potMilk ? Sugar ?She puts them in and hands the imaginary cup to TUA-HEETA .

sp.speaker: TUA-HEETA
sp.p: Thank you .Drinks .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: pouring herself a cupI hope you like China .She drinks , and then rings an imaginary bellWell , as I was saying — -Enter AUNT JANE .You can clear away , Jane .

sp.speaker: AUNT JANE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

div.stage: She clears away the tea and TUA-HEETA and — very quickly — herself , as OLIVER comes back . OLIVER has been discussing boarding-tactics with his brother-in-law . CAPTAIN CROOKSHANK belongs to the now old-fashioned Marlinspike School ; OLIVER is for well-primed pistols .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Oh , Oliver , I love your island . I 've been thinking things all by myself . You 're married to Tua-heeta . You do n't mind , do you ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Not at all , Jill . Make yourself at home . I 've just been trying the doctor in the lagoon . There were sharks there , after all , so we 'll have to find another place for bathing . Oh , and I shot an elephant . What would you like to do now ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Just let 's lie here and see what happens .What happens is that a cassowary comes along .Oh , what a lovely bird ! Is it an ostrich ?

div.stage: The cassowary sniffs the air , puts its beak to the ground and goes off again .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Silly ! It 's a cassowary , of course .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: What 's a cassowary ?

lg.l: Jill ! Do n't you remember the rhyme ?
I wish I were a cassowary
Upon the plains of Timbuctoo
And then I 'd eat a missionary —
And hat and gloves and hymn-book too !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Is that all they 're for ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Well , what else would you want them for ?

div.stage: A MISSIONARY , pith-helmet , gloves , hymn-book , umbrella , all complete — creeps cautiously up . He bears a strong likeness to the curate , the REVEREND SMILAX .

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: I am sorry to intrude upon your privacy , dear friends , but have you observed a cassowary on this island , apparently looking for something ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Yes , we saw one just now .

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: shudderingDear , dear , dear . You did n't happen to ask him what was the object of his researches ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: He went so quickly .

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: coming out of the undergrowth to themI wonder if you have ever heard of a little rhyme which apparently attributes to the bird in question , when residing in the level pastures of Timbuctoo , an unholy lust for the body and appurtenances thereto of an unnamed clerical gentleman ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: and JILLshouting togetherYes ! Rather !

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: Dear , dear ! Fortunately — I say fortunately — this is not Timbuctoo !OLIVER slips away and comes back with a notice-board “ Timbuctoo , ” which he places at the edge of the trees , unseen by the MISSIONARY , who goes on talking to JILLI take it that a cassowary residing in other latitudes is of a more temperate habit . His appetite , I venture to suggest , dear lady , would be under better restraint . That being so , I may perhaps safely ——He begins to move off , and comes suddenly up to the notice-boardDear , dear , dear , dear , dear ! This is terrible !
