You said , I think , that the — ah — bird in question was moving in this direction ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: That 's right .

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: Then I shall move , hastily yet with all due precaution , in that direction .He walks off on tiptoe , looking over his shoulder in case the cassowary should reappear . Consequently , he does not observe the enormous CANNIBAL who has appeared from the trees on the right , until he bumps into himI beg your ——He looks upDear , dear , dear , dear , dear !

sp.speaker: CANNIBAL
sp.p: Boria , boria , boo !

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: Yes , my dear sir , it is as you say , a beautiful morning .

sp.speaker: CANNIBAL
sp.p: Boria , boria , boo !

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: But I was just going a little walk — in this direction — if you will permit me .

sp.speaker: CANNIBAL
sp.p: threateninglyBoria , boria , boo !

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: I have noticed it , my dear sir , I have often made that very observation to my parishioners .

sp.speaker: CANNIBAL
sp.p: very threateninglyBoria , boria , boo !

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: Oh , what 's he saying ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: He says it 's his birthday to-morrow .

sp.speaker: CANNIBAL
sp.p: Wurra , wurra wug !

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: And will you come to the party ?

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: to CANNIBALMy dear sir , it is most kind of you to invite me , but a prior engagement in a different part of the country — a totally unexpected call upon me in another locality — will unfortunately ——

div.stage: While he is talking , the cassowary comes back , sidles up to him , and taps with his beak on the MISSIONARY 'S pith-helmet .

sp.speaker: MISSIONARY
sp.p: absently , without looking roundCome in ! . . . As I was saying , my dear sir ——The bird taps again . The MISSIONARY turns round annoyedCa n't you see I 'm engaged —— Oh dear , dear , dear , dear , dear !

div.stage: He clasps the CANNIBAL in his anguish , recoils from the CANNIBAL and clasps the cassowary . The three of them go off together , OLIVER and JILL following eagerly behind to see who gets most .
The PIRATES come back , each carrying a small wooden ammunition-box , and sit round in a semicircle , the PIRATE CHIEF in the middle .

sp.speaker: PIRATE
sp.p: Steward ! Steward !

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: hurrying inYes , sir , coming , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Now then , tumble up , my lad . I would carouse . Circulate the dry ginger .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: hurrying outYes , sir , going , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Look lively , my lad , look lively .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: hurrying inYes , sir , coming , sir .He hands round mugs to them all .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: risingGentlemen !They all stand upThe crew of the Cocktail will carouse ——They all take one step to the right , one back , and one left — which brings them behind their boxes — and then place their right feet on the boxes togetherOne !They raise their mugsTwo !They drinkThree !They bang down their mugsFour !They wipe their mouths with the backs of their handsSo ! . . . Steward !

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Yes , sir , here , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: The carouse is over .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .He collects the mugs and goes out .The PIRATES sit down again .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: addressing the menHaving passed an hour thus in feasting and song ——

div.stage: Hark ! is it the voice of our dear MISS PINNIGER ? It is .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: offOliver ! Oliver ! Jill ! You may get up now and come down to tea .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Having , as I say , slept off our carouse — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: offOliver ! Jill !She comes inOh , I beg your pardon , I — er — -

div.stage: All the PIRATES rise and draw their weapons

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Pray do not mention it .Polishing his pistol lovinglyYou were asking — -

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: I — I was l-looking for a small boy — Oliver —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Oliver ?To 1ST PIRATEHave we any Olivers on board ?

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE . NO , Captain . Only Bath Olivers .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to GOVERNESSYou cannot be referring to my brother-in-law , hight Two-Toed Thomas , the Terror of the Dyaks ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Oh no , no — Just a small boy and his sister — Jill .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 2ND PIRATEHave we any Jills on board ?

div.stage: 2ND PIRATE . No , Captain . Only gills of rum .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to GOVERNESSYou cannot be referring to Mrs. Crookshank , styled the Pride of the Pampas ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Oh no , no , I am so sorry . Perhaps I — er —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Wait , woman .to 6TH PIRATEErnest , offer your seat to the lady .

div.stage: The 6TH PIRATE stands up .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: nervouslyOh please do n't trouble , I 'm getting out at the next station — I mean I —

div.stage: 6TH PIRATE ( thunderously ) . Sit down !
She sits down tremblingly and he stands by her with his pistol .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Thank you .to 1ST PIRATECecil , have you your pencil and notebook with you ?

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( producing them ) . Ay , ay , Captain .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Then we will cross-examine the prisoner .to GOVERNESSName ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Pinniger .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . Pincher .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Christian names , if any ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Letitia .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . Letisher — how would you spell it , Captain ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Spell it like a sneeze . Age ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Twenty-three .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 1ST PIRATEHabits — untruthful . Appearance — against her . Got that ?

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE . Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to GOVERNESSAnd what are you for ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: I teach . Oliver and Jill , you know .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: And what do you teach them ?

lg.l: Oh , everything . Arithmetic , French , Geography , History ,
Dancing ——

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: holding up his handA moment ! I would take counsel with Percy .to 2ND PIRATEPercy , what shall we ask her in Arithmetic ?The 2ND PIRATE whispers to him .Excellent .To herIf you really are a teacher as you say , answer me this question . The brigantine Cocktail is in longitude 40 ° 39 ’ latitude 22 ° 50 ’ , sailing closehauled on the port tack at 8 knots in a 15-knot nor ’ - nor ’ westerly breeze — how soon before she sights the Azores ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: I — I — I 'm afraid I — - You see — I ——

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 1ST PIRATEArithmetic rotten .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . Arithmetic rotten .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 3RD PIRATEBasil , ask her a question in French .

div.stage: 3RD PIRATE . What would the mate of a French frigate say if he wanted to say in French , “ Avast there , ye lubbering swab ” to a friend like ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Oh , but I hardly — I — -

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 1ST PIRATEFrench futile .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . French futile .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 4TH PIRATEI do n't suppose it 's much use , Francis . But try her in Geography .

div.stage: 4TH PIRATE . Well now , lady . If you was wanting a nice creek to lay up cosy in , atween Dago Point and the Tortofitas , where would you run to ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: It-run to ? But that is n't — of course I — -

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 1ST PIRATEGeography ghastly .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . Geography ghastly .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to 5TH PIRATEGive her a last chance , Mervyn . See if she knows any history .

div.stage: 5TH PIRATE . I suppose you could n't tell me what year it was when old John Cann took the Saucy Codfish over Black Tooth Reef and laid her alongside the Spaniard in the harbour there , and up comes the Don in his nightcap . “ Shiver my timbers , ” he says in Spanish , “ but there 's only one man in the whole of the Spanish Main , ” he says , “ and that 's John Cann , ” he says , “ who could — - ”
The GOVERNESS looks dumbly at him .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: She could n't . History hopeless .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE . History hopeless .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to GOVERNESSWhat else do you teach ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Music , dancing — er — but I do n't think — -

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Steward !

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: coming inYes , sir , coming , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Concertina .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: going outYes , sir , going , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to GOVERNESSCan you dance a hornpipe ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: No , I — -

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Dancing dubious .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . Dancing dubious .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: coming inConcertina , sir .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Give it to the woman .He takes it to her .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: I 'm afraid I — -She produces one ghastly noise and drops the concertina in alarm .

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE ( writing ) . What shall I say , sir ? Music mouldy or music measly ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: standing upGentlemen , I think you will agree with me that the woman Pinniger has proved that she is utterly incapable of teaching anybody anything . Twenty-five years , man and boy , I have sailed the Spanish Main , and with the possible exception of a dumb and half-witted negro whom I shipped as cook in ‘ 64 , I have never met any one so profoundly lacking in intellect . I propose , therefore , that for the space of twenty-four hours the woman Pinniger should be incarcerated in the smuggler 's cave , in the company of a black beetle of friendly temperament .

sp.speaker: GOVERNESS
sp.p: Mercy ! Mercy !

div.stage: 1ST PIRATE . I should like to second that .

lg.l: Those in favour — ay !
Contrary — No !
The motion is carried .

div.stage: One of the Pirates opens the door of the cave . The GOVERNESS rushes to the CHIEF and throws herself at his feet . OLIVER and JILL appear in the nick of time .

lg.l: A maiden in distress ! I will rescue her .
lg.stage: She looks up and OLIVER recognises her
lg.l: Oh ! Carry on , Commodore .

div.stage: The GOVERNESS is lowered into the cave and the door is shut .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: to his menGo , find that black beetle , and having found it , introduce it circumspectly by the back door .

sp.speaker: PIRATES
sp.p: They go out .Ay , ay , sir .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: All the same , you know , I jolly well should like to rescue somebody .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: excitedlyOo , rescue me , Oliver .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: solemnlyTwo-toed Thomas , Terror of the Dyaks , and Pest of the North Pacific , truly thou art a well-plucked one . Wilt fight me for the wench ?He puts an arm round JILL .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Swords ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Pistols .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: At twenty paces ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Across a handkerchief .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Done !Feeling in his pocketsHave you got a handkerchief ? I think I must have left mine on the dressing-table .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: bringing out his and putting it hastily back againMine 's rather — Jill , have n't you got one ?

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: feelingI know I had one , but I ——

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: This is an ill business . Five-and-thirty duels have I fought — and never before been delayed for lack of a handkerchief .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Ah , here it is .She produces a very small one and lays it on the ground . They stand one each side of it , pistols ready .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Jill , you must give the word . JILL . Are you ready ?

div.stage: The sound of a gong is heard .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Listen !The gong is heard againThe Spanish Fleet is engaged !

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: I thought it was our tea gong .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Ah , perhaps you 're right .

lg.l: I say , we ought n't to miss tea .
lg.stage: Holding out his hand to her
lg.l: Come on , Jill .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: But you 'll come back ? We shall always be waiting here for you whenever you want us .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: Yes , we 'll come back , wo n't we , Oliver ?

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Oo , rather .

div.stage: The whole population of the Island , Animals , Pirates , and Dusky Maidens , come on . They sing as they wave good-bye to the children who are making their way to the boat .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: from the boatGood-bye , good-bye .

sp.speaker: OLIVER
sp.p: Good-bye , you chaps .

sp.speaker: JILL
sp.p: politelyAnd thank you all for a very pleasant afternoon .

div.stage: They are all singing as the boat pushes off . Night comes on with tropical suddenness . The singing dies slowly down .

div.head: ACT III .— FATHER CHRISTMAS AND THE HUBBARD FAMILY
SCENE I .— The drawing-room of the HUBBARDS before Fame and Prosperity

stage.stage: came to them . It is simply furnished with a deal table and two cane chairs .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: and MRS. HUBBARD , in faultless evening dress , are at home , MR. HUBBARD reading a magazine , MRS. HUBBARD with her hands in her lap . She sighs .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDimpetuously throwing down his magazineDearest , you sighed ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDquicklyNo , no , Henry . In a luxurious and well-appointed home such as this , why should I sigh ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . True , dear . Not only is it artistically furnished , as you say , but it is also blessed with that most precious of all things —he lifts up the magazine— a library .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Yes , yes , Henry , we have much to be thankful for .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . We have indeed . But I am selfish . Would you care to read ?He tears out a page of the magazine and hands it to her .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Thank you , thank you , Henry .

div.stage: They both sit in silence for a little . She sighs again .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Darling , you did sigh . Tell me what grieves you .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Little Isabel . Her cough troubles me .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDthoughtfullyIsabel ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Yes , dear , our youngest . Do n't you remember , she comes after Harold ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDcounting on his fingersA , B , C , D , E , F , G , H , I — dear me , have we got nine already ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDimploringlyDarling , say you do n't think it 's too many .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Oh no , no , not at all , my love . . . After all , it is n't as if they were real children .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDindignantlyHenry ! How can you say they are not real ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Well , I mean they 're only the children we thought we 'd like to have if Father Christmas gave us any .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . They are just as real to me as if they were here in the house . Ada , Bertram , Caroline , the high-spirited Dennis , pretty Elsie with the golden ringlets , dear little fair-haired Frank —

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDfirmlyDarling one , Frank has curly brown hair . It was an understood thing that you should choose the girls , and I should choose the boys . When we decided to take — A , B , C , D , E , F — a sixth child , it was my turn for a boy , and I selected Frank . He has curly brown hair and a fondness for animals .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . I daresay you 're right , dear . Of course it is a little confusing when you never see your children .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Well , well , perhaps some day Father Christmas will give us some .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Why does he neglect us so , Henry ? We hang up our stockings every year , but he never seems to notice them . Even a diamond necklace or a few oranges or a five-shilling postal order would be something .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . It is very strange . Possibly the fact that the chimney has not been swept for some years may have something to do with it . Or he may have forgotten our change of address . I cannot help feeling that if he knew how we had been left to starve in this way he would be very much annoyed .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . And clothes . I have literally nothing but what I am standing up in — I mean sitting down in .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Nor I , my love . But at least it will be written of us in the papers that the Hubbards perished in faultless evening dress . We are a proud race , and if Father Christmas deliberately cuts us off in this way , let us go down proudly . . . . Shall we go on reading or would you like to walk up and down the room ? Fortunately these simple pleasures are left to us .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . I 've finished this page .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDtearing out oneHave another , my love .They read for a little while , until interrupted by a knock at the door .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Some one at the door ! Who could it be ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDgetting upJust make the room look a little more homey , dear , in case it 's any one important .

div.stage: He goes out , leaving her to alter the position of the chairs slightly .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Well ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDcoming inA letter .He opens it .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Quick !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDwhistling with surpriseFather Christmas ! An invitation to Court !Reading“ Father Christmas at Home , 25th December . Jollifications , 11. 59 P. M . ” My love , he has found us at last !They embrace each other .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Henry , how gratifying !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Yes .Sadly , after a pauseBut we can n't go .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDsadlyNo , I have no clothes .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Nor I .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . How can I possibly go without a diamond necklace ? None of the Montmorency-Smythe women has ever been to Court without a diamond necklace .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . The Hubbards are a proud race . No male Hubbard would dream of appearing at Court without a gentleman 's gold Albert watch-chain . . . . Besides , there is another thing . There will be many footmen at Father Christmas 's Court , who will doubtless require coppers pressed into their palms . My honour would be seriously affected , were I compelled to whisper to them that I had no coppers .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . It is very unfortunate . Father Christmas may have hundreds of presents waiting for us .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . True . But how would it be to hang up our stockings again this evening — now that we know he knows we are here ? I would suggest tied on to the door-knocker , to save him the trouble of coming down the chimney .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDexcitedlyHenry , I wonder ! But of course we will .

div.stage: They begin to take off — the one a sock , the other a stocking .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . I almost wish now that my last suit had been a knickerbocker one . However , we must do what we can with a sock .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDholding up her stocking and looking at it a little anxiouslyI hope Father Christmas wo n't give me a bicycle . A stocking never sets so well after it has had a bicycle in it .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDtaking it from herNow , dear , I will go down and put them in position . Let us hope that fortune will be kind to us .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Let us hope so , darling . And quickly . Forpicking up her page of the magazineit is a trifle cold .

div.stage: He goes out and she is left reading .

div.head: SCENE II .— Outside the house the snow lies deep . The stocking and sock

stage.stage: are tied on to the door-knocker . There is a light in the window .
A party of carol-singers , with lanterns , come by and halt in the snow outside the house .

sp.speaker: PETER ABLEWAYS
sp.p: Friends , are we all assembled ?

sp.speaker: JONAS HUMPHREY
sp.p: Ay , ay , Peter Ableways , assembled and met together in a congregation , for the purpose of lifting up our voices in joyous thanksgiving , videlicet the singing of a carol or other wintry melody .

sp.speaker: JENNIFER LING
sp.p: Keep your breath for your song , Master Humphrey . That last “ Alleluia ” of yours was a poor windy thing , lacking grievously in substance .

sp.speaker: JONAS
sp.p: sadlyIt is so . I never made much of an Alleluia . It is not in my nature somehow . ‘ Tis a vain boastful thing an Alleluia .

sp.speaker: MARTHA PORRITT
sp.p: Are we to begin soon , Master Ableways ? My feet are cold .

sp.speaker: JONAS
sp.p: What matter the feet , Martha Porritt , if the heart be warm with loving-kindness and seasonable emotions ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Well , nothing of me will be warm soon .

sp.speaker: JENNIFER
sp.p: Ay , let 's begin , Peter Ableways , while we carry the tune in our heads . It is ill searching for the notes in the middle of the carol , as some singers do .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well spoken , Mistress Jennifer . Now listen all , while I unfold the nature of the entertainment . Item — A carol or birth song to draw the attention of all folk to the company here assembled and the occasion celebrated . Item — Applause and the clapping of hands . Item — A carol or song of thanksgiving . Item — A collection .

sp.speaker: JONAS
sp.p: An entertainment well devised , Master Ableways , sobeit the words of the second song remain with me after I am delivered of the first .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Are we to begin soon , Master Ableways ? My feet are cold .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Are we all ready , friends ? I will say one — two — three — and at “ three ” I pray you all to give it off in a hearty manner from the chest . One — two —

sp.speaker: JONAS
sp.p: Hold , hold , Master Ableways ! Does it begin — No , that 's the other one .JENNIFER whispers the first line to himAy , ay — I have it now — and bursting to get out of me . Proceed , Peter Ableways .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: One — two — three —They carol .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well sung , all .

sp.speaker: HUMPHREY
sp.p: The applause followed , good Master Peter , as ordained . Moreover , I have the tune of the second song ready within me . Likewise a la-la-la or two to replace such words as I have forgotten .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Do n't forget the collection , Master Ableways .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ay , the collection .He takes off his hat and places it on the ground .

sp.speaker: HUMPHREY
sp.p: Nay , not so fast , Master Peter . It would be ill if the good folk thought that our success this night were to be estimated by an empty hat . Place some of our money in it , Master Ableways . Where money is , money will come .

sp.speaker: JENNIFER
sp.p: Ay , it makes a pleasing clink .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: True , Mistress Jennifer . Master Humphrey speaks true .He pours some coppers from his pockets into his hat .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Are we to go on , Master Ableways ? My feet are cold .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: shaking the hatSo , a warming noise .

sp.speaker: HUMPHREY
sp.p: To it again , gentles .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Are all ready ? One — two — three !They carol .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well sung , all .

sp.speaker: HUMPHREY
sp.p: Have you the hat , Master Peter ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: picking it upAy , friend , all is ready .

div.stage: The door opens and MR. HUBBARD appears at the entrance .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Good evening , friends .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good evening , sir .He holds out the hat .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDlooking at itWhat is this ?PETER shakes itAha ! Money !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Remember the carol singers , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDhelping himselfMy dear friends , I will always remember you . This is most generous . I shall never forget your kindness . This is most unexpected . But not the less welcome , not the less — I think there 's a ha'penny down there that I missed — thank you . As I was saying , unexpected but welcome . I thank you heartily . Good evening , friends .

div.stage: He goes in and shuts the door .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: who has been too surprised to do anything but keep his mouth openWell ! . . . Well ! . . . Well , friends , let us to the next house . We have got all that we can get here .

div.stage: They trail off silently .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: as they go offMaster Ableways !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Ay , lass !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: My feet are n't so cold now .

div.stage: But this is to be an exciting night . As soon as they are gone , a Burglar and a Burglaress steal into view

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Wotcher get , Liz ?She holds up a gold watch and chain . He nods and holds up a diamond necklace‘ Ow 's that ?

sp.speaker: LIZ
sp.p: starting suddenlyH'st !

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: in a whisperWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: LIZ
sp.p: Copper !

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: desperately‘ Ere , quick , get rid of these . ‘ Ide ‘ em in the snow , or — -

sp.speaker: LIZ
sp.p: Bill !He turns roundLook !She points to the stocking and sock hanging upWe can come back for ‘ em as soon as ‘ e 's gone .

div.stage: BILL looks at them , and back at her , and grins . He drops the necklace into one and the watch into the other . As the POLICEMAN approaches they strike up , “ While shepherds watched their flock by night , ” with an air of great enthusiasm .

sp.speaker: POLICEMAN
sp.p: Now then , move along there .

div.stage: They move along . The POLICEMAN flashes his light on the door to see that all is well . The stocking and sock are revealed . He beams sentimentally at them .

div.head: SCENE III .— We are inside the house again . MRS. HUBBARD is still

stage.stage: reading a page of the magazine . In dashes MR. HUBBARD with the sock and stocking .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . My darling , what do you think ? Father Christmas has sent you a little present .He hands her the stocking .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Henry ! Has he sent you one too ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDholding up his sockObserve !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . How sweet of him ! I wonder what mine is . What is yours , darling ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . I have n't looked yet , my love . Perhaps just a few nuts or something of that sort , with a card attached saying , “ To wish you the old , old wish . ” We must try not to be disappointed , whatever it is , darling .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Of course , Henry . After all , it is the kindly thought which really matters .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Certainly . All the same , I hope — Will you look in yours , dear , first , or shall I ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . I think I should like to , darling .Feeling itIt feels so exciting .She brings out a diamond necklaceHenry !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . My love !They embraceNow you will be able to go to Court . You must say that your husband is unfortunately in bed with a bad cold . You can tell me all about it when you come home . I shall be able to amuse myself with —He is feeling in his sock while talking , and now brings out the watch and chain .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Henry ! My love !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . A gentleman 's gold hunter and Albert watch-chain . My darling !

div.stage: They put down their presents on the table and embrace each other again .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Let 's put them on at once , Henry , and see how they suit us .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Allow me , my love .He fastens her necklace .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDhappilyNow I feel really dressed again ! Oh , I wish we had a looking-glass .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDopening his gold watchTry in here , my darling .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDsurveying herselfHow perfectly sweet ! . . . Now let me put your watch-chain on for you , dear .She arranges it for him — HENRY very proud .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Does it suit me , darling ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . You look fascinating , Henry !

div.stage: They strut about the room with an air .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDtaking out his watch and-looking at it ostentatiouslyWell , well , we ought to be starting . My watch makes it 11. 58 .He holds it to her earHas n't it got a sweet tick ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Sweet ! But starting where , Henry ? Do you mean we can really — But you have n't any money .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Money ?Taking out a handfulHeaps of it .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Father Christmas ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Undoubtedly , my love . Brought round to the front door just now by some of his messengers . By the way , dear —indicating the sock and stocking— had n't we better put these on before we start ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Of course . How silly of me !

div.stage: They sit down and put them on .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Really this is a very handsome watch-chain .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . It becomes you admirably , Henry .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Thank you , dear . There 's just one little point . Father Christmas is sometimes rather shy about acknowledging the presents he gives . He hates being thanked . If , therefore , he makes any comment on your magnificent necklace or my handsome watch-chain , we must say that they have been in the family for some years .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Of course , dear .They get up .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Well , now we 're ready .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Darling one , do n't you think we might bring the children ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Of course , dear ! How forgetful of me ! . . . Children — ‘ shun !Listen ! Their heels click as they come to attentionNumber !Their voices — alternate boy and girl , one to nine — are heardRight turn !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Darling one , I almost seem to hear them !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Are you ready , my love ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Yes , Henry .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Quick march !

div.stage: The children are heard tramping off . Very proudly MR. and MRS. HUBBARD bring up the rear .

div.head: SCENE IV .— The Court of FATHER CHRISTMAS . Shall we describe it ? No .

stage.stage: But there is everything there which any reasonable person could want , from ices to catapults . And the decorations , done in candy so that you can break off a piece whenever you are hungry , are superb .

div.stage: 1ST USHER ( from the back ) . Father Christmas !

sp.speaker: SEVERAL USHERS
sp.p: from the frontFather Christmas !He comes in .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: geniallyGood evening , everybody .

div.stage: I ought to have said that there are already some hundreds of people there , though how some of them got invitations — but , after all , that is not our business . Wishing to put them quite at their ease , FATHER CHRISTMAS , who has a very creditable baritone , gives them a song . After the applause which follows it , he retires to the throne at the back , and awaits his more important guests . The USHERS take up their places , one at the entrance , one close to the throne .
1ST USHER . Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hubbard ! ( They come in .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDpressing twopence into his palmThank you , my man , thank you .

div.stage: 2ND USHER . Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hubbard .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDhanding out another twopenceNot at all , my man , not at all .

div.stage: MRS. HUBBARD curtsies and MR. HUBBARD bows to FATHER CHRISTMAS .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: I am delighted to welcome you to my Court . How are you both ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Very well , thank you , sir . My wife has a slight cold in one foot , owing to —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDhastilyA touch of gout , sir , inherited from my ancestors , the Montmorency-Smythes .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: Dear me , it wo n't prevent you dancing , I hope ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Oh no , sir .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: That 's right . We shall have a few more friends coming in soon . You have been giving each other presents already , I see . I congratulate you , madam , on your husband 's taste .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDtouching her necklaceOh no , this is a very old heirloom of the Montmorency-Smythe family .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . An ancestress of Mrs. Hubbard 's — a lady-in-waiting at the Tottenham Court — at the Tudor Court — was fortunate enough to catch the eye of — er —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Queen Elizabeth , and — er —

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: I see . You are lucky , madam , to have such beautiful jewels .Turning to MR. HUBBARDAnd this delightful gold Albert watch-chain —

lg.l: HUBBARD . Presented to an ancestor of mine , Sir Humphrey de
Hubbard , at the battle of — er —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Agincourt .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . As you say , dear , Agincourt . By King Richard the — I should say William the — well , by the King .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: How very interesting .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Yes . My ancestor clove a scurvy knave from the chaps to the chine . I do n't quite know how you do that , but I gather that he inflicted some sort of a scratch upon his adversary , and the King rewarded him with this handsome watch-chain .

sp.speaker: USHERS
sp.p: announcingMr. Robinson Crusoe !He comes in .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: bowingI 'm a little late , I 'm afraid , sir . My raft was delayed by adverse gales .

div.stage: FATHER CHRISTMAS introduces him to the HUBBARDS , who inform him that the weather is very seasonable .

sp.speaker: USHERS
sp.p: Miss Riding Hood !She comes in .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: curtseyingI hope I am in time , sir . I had to look in on my grandmother on the way here .

div.stage: FATHER CHRISTMAS makes the necessary introductions .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDto CRUSOEDo come and see me , Mr. Crusoe . Any Friday . I should like your advice about my parrot . He 's moulting in all the wrong places .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDto RED RIDING HOODI do n't know if you 're interested in wolves at all , Miss Hood . I heard a very good story about one the other day .He begins to tell it , but she has hurried away before he can remember whether it was Thursday or Friday .

sp.speaker: USHERS
sp.p: Baron Bluebeard !He comes in .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: bowingI trust you have not been waiting for me , sir . I had a slight argument with my wife before starting , which delayed me somewhat .

div.stage: FATHER CHRISTMAS forgives him .

sp.speaker: USHERS
sp.p: Princess Goldilocks !

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: curtseyingI brought the youngest bear with me — do you mind ?She introduces the youngest bear to FATHER CHRISTMAS and the other guestsSay , how do you do , darling ?To an USHERWill you give him a little porridge , please , and if you have got a nice bed where he could rest a little afterwards — he gets tired so quickly .

sp.speaker: USHER
sp.p: Certainly , your Royal Highness .

div.stage: Music begins .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: to FATHER CHRISTMASAre we going to dance ? How lovely !

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: to the HUBBARDSYou will dance , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . I think not just at first , thank you .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: to CRUSOECome along !

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: I am a little out of practice — er — but if you do n't mind — er —He comes .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: to RIDING HOODMay I have the pleasure ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDto RIDING HOODBe careful , dear ; he has a very bad reputation .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: to BLUEBEARDYou do n't eat people , do you ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: pained by this injusticeNever !

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Oh then , I do n't mind . But I do hate being eaten .

div.stage: Now we can n't possibly describe the whole dance to you , for in every corner of the big ballroom couples were revolving and sliding , and making small talk with each other . So we will just take two specimen conversations .

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: nervous , poor manPrincess Goldilocks , may I speak to you on a matter of some importance to me ?

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: I wish you would .

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: looking across at BLUEBEARD and RED RIDING HOOD , who are revolving close byAlone .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: to BLUEBEARDDo you mind ? You can have your turn afterwards .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: to RIDING HOODShall we adjourn to the Buffet ?

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: They adjourn .Oh , do let 's .

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: bravelyPrincess , I am a lonely man .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: encouraginglyYes , Robinson ?

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: I am not much of a one for society , and I do n't quite know how to put these things , but — er — if you would like to share my island , I — I should so love to have you there .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: Oh , Robbie !

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: warming to itI have a very comfortable house , and a man-servant , and an excellent view from the south windows , and several thousands of acres of good rough-shooting , and — oh , do say you 'll come !

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: May I bring my bears with me ?

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: Of course ! I ought to have said that . I have a great fondness for animals .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: How sweet of you ! But perhaps I ought to warn you that we all like porridge . Have you — -

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: I have a hundred acres of oats .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: Then , Robinson , I am yours .They embraceThere ! Now tell me — did you make all your clothes yourself ?

sp.speaker: CRUSOE
sp.p: proudlyAll of them .

sp.speaker: GOLDILOCKS
sp.p: going off with himHow wonderful of you ! Really you hardly seem to want a wife .

div.stage: They go out . Now it is the other couple 's turn .
Enter , then , BLUEBEARD and RIDING HOOD

lg.l: Perhaps I ought to tell you at once , Miss Riding Hood , that
I have been married before .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: My last wife unfortunately died just before I started out here this evening .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: calmlyDid you kill her ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: taken abackI — I — I —

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Are you quite a nice man , Bluebeard ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: W-what do you mean ? I am a very rich man . If you will marry me , you will live in a wonderful castle , full of everything that you want .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: That will be rather jolly .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: dramaticallyBut there is one room into which you must never go .Holding up a keyHere is the key of it .He offers it to her .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: indifferentlyBut if I 'm never to go into it , I sha n't want the key .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: upsetYou — you must have the key .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: The — the others all had it .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: coldlyBluebeard , you are n't going to talk about your other wives all the time , are you ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: N — no .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Then do n't be silly . And take this key , and go and tidy up that ridiculous room of yours , and when it 's nice and clean , and when you 've shaved off that absurd beard , perhaps I 'll marry you .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: furiously drawing his swordMadam !

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Do n't do it here . You 'll want some hot water .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: trying to put his sword backThis is too much , this is —

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: You 're putting it in the wrong way round .

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: stifflyThank you .He manages to get it in .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Well , do you want to marry me ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: Sure ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: admiringlyMore than ever . You 're the first woman I 've met who has n't been afraid of me .

sp.speaker: RIDING HOOD
sp.p: surprisedAre you very alarming ? Wolves frighten me sometimes , but not just silly men . . . .Giving him her handAll right then . But you 'll do what I said ?

sp.speaker: BLUEBEARD
sp.p: Beloved one , I will do anything for you .CRUSOE and GOLDILOCKS come back . Probably it will occur to the four of them to sing a song indicative of the happy family life awaiting them . On the other hand they may prefer to dance . . . .But enough of this . Let us get on to the great event of the evening . Ladies and gentlemen , are you all assembled ? Then silence , please , for FATHER CHRISTMAS .

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen , it gives me great pleasure to see you here at my Court this evening ; and in particular my friends Mr. and Mrs. Hubbard , of whom I have been too long neglectful . However , I hope to make up for it to-night .To an USHERDisclose the Christmas Tree !

div.stage: The Christmas Tree is disclosed , and — what do you think ? Children disguised as crackers are hanging from every branch ! Well , I never !

sp.speaker: FATHER CHRISTMAS
sp.p: quite calmlyDistribute the presents !

div.stage: An USHER takes down the children one by one and places them in a row , reading from the labels on them . “ MRS. HUBBARD , MR. HUBBARD ” alternately .

sp.speaker: USHER
sp.p: handing list to MR. HUBBARDHere is the nominal roll , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDlooking at it in amazementWhat 's this ?MRS. HUBBARD looks over his shoulderAda , Bertram , Caroline — My darling one !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARD . Henry ! Our children at last ! Oh , are they all — all there ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . We 'll soon see , dear . Ada !

sp.speaker: ADA
sp.p: springing to attentionFather !She stands at ease .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . Bertram ! . . .And so on up to ELSIEFrank !

sp.speaker: FRANK
sp.p: Father !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARD . There you are , darling , I told you he had curly brown hair . . . . Gwendoline !And so on .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HUBBARDto FATHER CHRISTMASOh thank you so much . It is sweet of you .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: HUBBARDto FATHER CHRISTMASWe are slightly overcome . Do you mind if we just dance it off .FATHER CHRISTMAS nods genially .Come on , children !

div.stage: He holds out his hands , and he and his wife and the children dance round in a ring singing , “ Here we go round the Christmas Tree , all on a Christmas evening . . . . ”

And then — But at this moment JAMES and ROSEMARY and the HUBBARD children stopped thinking , so of course the play came to an end . And if there were one or two bits in it which the children did n't quite understand , that was JAMES 'S fault . He never ought to have been thinking at all , really .

docTitle.titlePart: MR. PIM PASSES BY A COMEDY IN THREE ACTS

titlePage.docImprint: The first performance of this play inLondontook place at the New Theatre on January 5 ,1920, with the following cast :

body.stage: George Marden — BEN WEBSTER . Olivia — IRENE VANBRUGH . Dinah — GEORGETTE COHAN . Lady Marden — ETHEL GRIFFIES . Brian Strange — LESLIE HOWARD . Carraway Pim — DION BOUCICAULT . Anne — ETHEL WELLESLEY .

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: The morning-room at Marden House ( Buckinghamshire ) decided more than a hundred years ago that it was all right , and has not bothered about itself since . Visitors to the house have called the result such different adjectives as “ mellow ” “ old-fashioned , ” “ charming ” — even “ baronial ” and “ antique ” ; but nobody ever said it was “ exciting . ” Sometimes OLIVIA wants it to be more exciting , and last week she let herself go over some new curtains . At present they are folded up and waiting for her ; she still has the rings to put on . It is obvious that the curtains alone will overdo the excitement ; they will have to be harmonised with a new carpet and cushions . OLIVIA has her eye on just the things , but one has to go carefully with GEORGE . What was good enough for his great-great-grandfather is good enough for him . However , we can trust OLIVIA to see him through it , although it may take time .

There are two ways of coming into the room ; by the open windows leading from the terrace or by the door . On this pleasant July morning MR. PIM chooses the latter way — or rather ANNE chooses it for him ; and old MR. PIM , wistful , kindly , gentle , little MR. PIM , living in some world of his own whither we cannot follow , ambles after her .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'll tell Mr. Marden you 're here , sir . Mr. Pim , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: coming back to this worldYes — er — Mr. Carraway Pim . He does n't know me , you understand , but if he could just see me for a moment — er —He fumbles in his pocketsI gave you that letter ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , sir , I 'll give it to him .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: bringing out a letter which is not the one he was looking for , but which reminds him of something else he has forgottenDear me !

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , sir ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I ought to have sent a telegram , but I can do it on my way back . You have a telegraph office in the village ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh yes , sir . If you turn to the left when you get outside the gates , it is n't more than a hundred yards down the hill .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Thank you , thank you . Very stupid of me to have forgotten .

div.stage: ANNE goes out .

MR. PIM wanders about the room humming to himself , and looking vaguely at the pictures . He has his back to the door as DINAH comes in . She is nineteen , very pretty , very happy , and full of boyish high spirits and conversation .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Hullo !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: turning roundAh , good morning , Mrs. Marden . You must forgive my — er —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh I say , I 'm not Mrs. Marden . I 'm Dinah .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: with a bowThen I will say , Good morning , Miss Diana .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: reproachfullyNow , look here , if you and I are going to be friends you must n't do that . Dinah , not Diana . Do remember it , there 's a good man , because I get so tired of correcting people . Have you come to stay with us ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Well no , Miss — er — Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: noddingThat 's right . I can see I sha n't have to speak to you again . Now tell me your name , and I bet you I get it right first time . And do sit down .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: sitting downThank you . My name is — er — Pim , Carraway Pim —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Pim , that 's easy .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: And I have a letter of introduction to your father —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh no ; now you 're going wrong again , Mr. Pim . George is n't my father ; he 's my uncle . Uncle George — he does n't like me calling him George . Olivia does n't mind — I mean she does n't mind being called Olivia , but George is rather touchy . You see , he 's been my guardian since I was about two , and then about five years ago he married a widow called Mrs. Telworthy — that 's Olivia — so she became my Aunt Olivia , only she lets me drop the Aunt . Got that ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: a little alarmedI — I think so , Miss Marden .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: admiringlyI say , you are quick , Mr. Pim . Well , if you take my advice , when you 've finished your business with George , you will hang about a bit and see if you can n't see Olivia . She 's simply devastating . I do n't wonder George fell in love with her .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: It 's only the merest matter of business — just a few minutes with your uncle — I 'm afraid I shall hardly —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , you must please yourself , Mr. Pim . I 'm just giving you a friendly word of advice . Naturally , I was awfully glad to get such a magnificent aunt , because , of course , marriage is rather a toss up , is n't it , and George might have gone off with anybody . It 's different on the stage , where guardians always marry their wards , but George could n't marry me because I 'm his niece . Mind you , I do n't say that I should have had him , because between ourselves he 's a little bit old-fashioned .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: So he married — er — Mrs. Marden instead .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Mrs. Telworthy — do n't say you 've forgotten already , just when you were getting so good at names . Mrs. Telworthy . You see , Olivia married the Telworthy man and went to Australia with him , and he drank himself to death in the bush , or wherever you drink yourself to death out there , and Olivia came home to England , and met my uncle , and he fell in love with her and proposed to her , and he came into my room that night — I was about fourteen — and turned on the light and said , “ Dinah , how would you like to have a beautiful aunt of your very own ? ” And I said : “ Congratulations , George . ” That was the first time I called him George . Of course , I 'd seen it coming for weeks . Telworthy , is n't it a funny name ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Very singular . From Australia , you say ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Yes , I always say that he 's probably still alive , and will turn up here one morning and annoy George , because that 's what first husbands always do in books , but I 'm afraid there 's not much chance .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: shockedMiss Marden !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , of course , I do n't really want it to happen , but it would be rather exciting , would n't it ? However , things like that never seem to occur down here , somehow . There was a hay-rick burnt last year about a mile away , but that is n't quite the same thing , is it ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: No , I should say that that was certainly different .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Of course , something very , very wonderful did happen last night , but I 'm not sure if I know you well enough ——She looks at him hesitatingly .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: uncomfortablyReally , Miss Marden , I am only a — a passer-by , here to-day and gone to-morrow . You really must n't ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: And yet there 's something about you , Mr. Pim , which inspires confidence . The fact is —in a stage whisper— I got engaged last night !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Dear me , let me congratulate you .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I expect that 's why George is keeping you such a long time . Brian , my young man , the well-known painter — only nobody has ever heard of him — he 's smoking a pipe with George in the library and asking for his niece 's hand . Is n't it exciting ? You 're really rather lucky , Mr. Pim — I mean being told so soon . Even Olivia does n't know yet .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: getting upYes , yes . I congratulate you , Miss Marden . Perhaps it would be better ——

div.stage: ANNE comes in .

lg.l: Mr. Marden is out at the moment , sir —— Oh , I did n't see you ,
Miss Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: It 's all right , Anne . I 'm looking after Mr. Pim .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , Miss .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: excitedlyThat 's me . They can n't discuss me in the library without breaking down , so they 're walking up and down outside , and slashing at the thistles in order to conceal their emotion . You know . I expect Brian ——

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: looking at his watchYes , I think , Miss Marden , I had better go now and return a little later . I have a telegram which I want to send , and perhaps by the time I came back ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , but how disappointing of you , when we were getting on together so nicely . And it was just going to be your turn to tell me all about yourself .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I have really nothing to tell , Miss Marden . I have a letter of introduction to Mr. Marden , who in turn will give me , I hope , a letter to a certain distinguished man whom it is necessary for me to meet . That is all .Holding out his handAnd now , Miss Marden ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , I 'll start you on your way to the post office . I want to know if you 're married , and all that sort of thing . You 've got heaps to tell me , Mr. Pim . Have you got your hat ? That 's right . Then we 'll — hullo , here 's Brian .

div.stage: BRIAN STRANGE comes in at the windows . He is what GEORGE calls a damned futuristic painter-chap , aged twenty-four . To look at , he is a very pleasant boy , rather untidily dressed .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: noddingHow do you do ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: seizing himBrian , this is Mr. Pim . Mr. Carraway Pim . He 's been telling me all about himself . It 's so interesting . He 's just going to send a telegram , and then he 's coming back again . Mr. Pim , this is Brian — you know .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: smiling and shaking handsHow do you do ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: pleadinglyYou wo n't mind going to the post office by yourself , will you , because , you see , Brian and I —she looks lovingly at BRIAN

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: because they are so youngMiss Dinah and Mr .— er — Brian , I have only come into your lives for a moment , and it is probable that I shall now pass out of them for ever , but you will allow an old man ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , not old !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: chuckling happilyWell , a middle-aged man — to wish you both every happiness in the years that you have before you . Good-bye , good-bye .

div.stage: He disappears gently through the windows .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Brian , he 'll get lost if he goes that way .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: going to the windows and calling after himRound to the left , sir . . . . That 's right .He comes back into the roomRum old bird . Who is he ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Darling , you have n't kissed me yet .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: taking her in his armsI ought n't to , but then one never ought to do the nice things .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Why ought n't you ?

div.stage: They sit on the sofa together .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , we said we 'd be good until we 'd told your uncle and aunt all about it . You see , being a guest in their house ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: But , darling child , what have you been doing all this morning except telling George ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Trying to tell George .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: noddingYes , of course , there 's a difference .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I think he guessed there was something up , and he took me down to see the pigs — he said he had to see the pigs at once — I do n't know why ; an appointment perhaps . And we talked about pigs all the way , and I could n't say , “ Talking about pigs , I want to marry your niece —— ”

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: with mock indignationOf course you could n't .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: No . Well , you see how it was . And then when we 'd finished talking about pigs , we started talking to the pigs ——

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: eagerlyOh , how is Arnold ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: The little black-and-white one ? He 's very jolly , I believe , but naturally I was n't thinking about him much . I was wondering how to begin . And then Lumsden came up , and wanted to talk pig-food , and the atmosphere grew less and less romantic , and — and I gradually drifted away .

lg.l: Poor darling . Well , we shall have to approach him through
Olivia .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: But I always wanted to tell her first ; she 's so much easier . Only you would n't let me .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: That 's your fault , Brian . You would tell Olivia that she ought to have orange-and-black curtains .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: But she wants orange-and-black curtains .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Yes , but George says he 's not going to have any futuristic nonsense in an honest English country house , which has been good enough for his father and his grandfather and his great-grandfather , and — and all the rest of them . So there 's a sort of strained feeling between Olivia and George just now , and if Olivia were to — sort of recommend you , well , it would n't do you much good .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: looking at herI see . Of course I know what you want , Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: What do I want ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: You want a secret engagement , and notes left under door-mats , and meetings by the withered thorn , when all the household is asleep . I know you .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , but it is such fun ! I love meeting people by withered thorns .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , I 'm not going to have it .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: childishlyOh , George ! Look at us being husbandy !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: You babe ! I adore you .He kisses her and holds her away from him and looks at herYou know , you 're rather throwing yourself away on me . Do you mind ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Not a bit .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: We shall never be rich , but we shall have lots of fun , and meet interesting people , and feel that we 're doing something worth doing , and not getting paid nearly enough for it , and we can curse the Academy together and the British Public , and — oh , it 's an exciting life .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: seeing itI shall love it .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I 'll make you love it . You sha n't be sorry , Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: You sha n't be sorry either , Brian .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: looking at her lovinglyOh , I know I sha n't . . . . What will Olivia think about it ? Will she be surprised ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: She 's never surprised . She always seems to have thought of things about a week before they happen . George just begins to get hold of them about a week after they 've happened .Considering himAfter all , there 's no reason why George should n't like you , darling .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I 'm not his sort , you know .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: You 're more Olivia 's sort . Well , we 'll tell Olivia this morning .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: coming inAnd what are you going to tell Olivia this morning ?She looks at them with a smileOh , well , I think I can guess .

div.stage: Shall we describe OLIVIA ? But you will know all about her before the day is over .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: jumping upOlivia , darling !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: followingSay you understand , Mrs. Marden .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Mrs. Marden , I am afraid , is a very dense person , Brian , but I think if you asked Olivia if she understood ——

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Bless you , Olivia . I knew you 'd be on our side .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Of course she would .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do n't know if it 's usual to kiss an aunt-in-law , Brian , but Dinah is such a very special sort of niece that —she inclines her cheek and BRIAN kisses it

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I say , you are in luck to-day , Brian .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: going over to her chair by the work-table and getting to business with the curtainsAnd how many people have been told the good news ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Nobody yet .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Except Mr. Pim .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Oh , does he —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Who 's Mr. Pim ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , he just happened — I say , are those the curtains ? Then you 're going to have them after all ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: with an air of surpriseAfter all what ? But I decided on them long ago .to BRIANYou have n't told George yet ?

lg.l: I began to , you know , but I never got any farther than
“ Er — there 's just — er — ”

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: George would talk about pigs all the time .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , I suppose you want me to help you .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Do , darling .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: It would be awfully decent of you . Of course , I 'm not quite his sort really —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: You 're my sort .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: But I do n't think he objects to me , and —

div.stage: GEORGE comes in , a typical , narrow-minded , honest country gentleman of forty odd .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: at the windowsWhat 's all this about a Mr. Pim ?He kicks some of the mud off his bootsWho is he ? Where is he ? I had most important business with Lumsden , and the girl comes down and cackles about a Mr. Pim , or Ping , or something . Where did I put his card ?Bringing it outCarraway Pim . Never heard of him in my life .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: He said he had a letter of introduction , Uncle George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , you saw him , did you ? Yes , that reminds me , there was a letter —he brings it out and reads it

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: He had to send a telegram . He 's coming back .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Pass me those scissors , Brian .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: These ?He picks them up and comes close to her .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Thank you .She indicates GEORGE 'S back . “ Now ? ” says BRIAN with his eyebrows . She nods .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: readingAh well , a friend of Brymer 's . Glad to oblige him . Yes , I know the man he wants . Coming back , you say , Dinah ? Then I 'll be going back . Send him down to the farm , Olivia , when he comes .to BRIANHallo , what happened to you ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do n't go , George , there 's something we want to talk about .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hallo , what 's this ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: to OLIVIAShall I ——?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: stepping outI 've been wanting to tell you all this morning , sir , only I did n't seem to have an opportunity of getting it out .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , what is it ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I want to marry Dinah , sir .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You want to marry Dinah ? God bless my soul !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: rushing to him and putting her cheek against his coatOh , do say you like the idea , Uncle George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Like the idea ! Have you heard of this nonsense , Olivia ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: They 've just this moment told me , George . I think they would be happy together .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: to BRIANAnd what do you propose to be happy together on ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , of course , it does n't amount to much at present , but we sha n't starve .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Brian got fifty pounds for a picture last March !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: a little upset by thisOh !Recovering gamelyAnd how many pictures have you sold since ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , none , but —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: None ! And I do n't wonder . Who the devil is going to buy pictures with triangular clouds and square sheep ? And they call that Art nowadays ! Good God , man ,waving him to the windowsgo outside and look at the clouds !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: If he draws round clouds in future , George , will you let him marry Dinah ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What — what ? Yes , of course , you would be on his side — all this Futuristic nonsense . I 'm just taking these clouds as an example . I suppose I can see as well as any man in the county , and I say that clouds are n't triangular .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: After all , sir , at my age one is naturally experimenting , and trying to find one 'swith a laugh— well , it sounds priggish , but one 's medium of expression . I shall find out what I want to do directly , but I think I shall always be able to earn enough to live on . Well , I have for the last three years .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I see , and now you want to experiment with a wife , and you propose to start experimenting with my niece ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: with a shrugWell , of course , if you —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You could help the experiment , darling , by giving Dinah a good allowance until she 's twenty-one .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Help the experiment ! I do n't want to help the experiment .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: apologeticallyOh , I thought you did .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You will talk as if I was made of money . What with taxes always going up and rents always going down , it 's as much as we can do to rub along as we are , without making allowances to everybody who thinks she wants to get married .to BRIANAnd that 's thanks to you , my friend .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: surprisedTo me ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You never told me , darling . What 's Brian been doing ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: indignantlyHe has n't been doing anything .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's one of your Socialists who go turning the country upside down .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But even Socialists must get married sometimes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't see any necessity .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But you 'd have nobody to damn after dinner , darling , if they all died out .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Really , sir , I do n't see what my politics and my art have got to do with it . I 'm perfectly ready not to talk about either when I 'm in your house , and as Dinah does n't seem to object to them —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I should think she does n't .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , you can get round the women , I daresay .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , it 's Dinah I want to marry and live with . So what it really comes to is that you do n't think I can support a wife .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , if you 're going to do it by selling pictures , I do n't think you can .

lg.l: All right , tell me how much you want me to earn in a year , and
I 'll earn it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: hedgingIt is n't merely a question of money . I just mention that as one thing — one of the important things . In addition to that , I think you are both too young to marry . I do n't think you know your own minds , and I am not at all persuaded that , with what I venture to call your outrageous tastes , you and my niece will live happily together . Just because she thinks she loves you , Dinah may persuade herself now that she agrees with all you say and do , but she has been properly brought up in an honest English country household , and — er — she — well , in short , I cannot at all approve of any engagement between you .Getting upOlivia , if this Mr .— er — Pim comes , I shall be down at the farm . You might send him along to me .

div.stage: He walks towards the windows .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: indignantlyIs there any reason why I should n't marry a girl who has been properly brought up ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think you know my views , Strange .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: George , wait a moment , dear . We can n't quite leave it like this .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I have said all I want to say on the subject .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , darling , but I have n't begun to say all that I want to say on the subject .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , if you have anything to say , Olivia , I will listen to it ; but I do n't know that this is quite the time , or that you have chosen —looking darkly at the curtains— quite the occupation likely to — er — endear your views to me .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: mutinouslyI may as well tell you , Uncle George , that I have got a good deal to say , too .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I can guess what you are going to say , Dinah , and I think you had better keep it for the moment .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: meeklyYes , Aunt Olivia .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Brian , you might take her outside for a walk . I expect you have plenty to talk about .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Now mind , Strange , no love-making . I put you on your honour about that .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I 'll do my best to avoid it , sir .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: cheekilyMay I take his arm if we go up a hill ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I 'm sure you 'll know how to behave — both of you .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Come on , then , Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Righto .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: as they goAnd if you do see any clouds , Strange , take a good look at them .He chuckles to himselfTriangular clouds — I never heard of such nonsense .He goes back to his chair at the writing-tableFuturistic rubbish . . . . Well , Olivia ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What are you doing ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Making curtains , George . Wo n't they be rather sweet ? Oh , but I forgot — you do n't like them .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't like them , and what is more , I do n't mean to have them in my house . As I told you yesterday , this is the house of a simple country gentleman , and I do n't want any of these new-fangled ideas in it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Is marrying for love a new-fangled idea ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We 'll come to that directly . None of you women can keep to the point . What I am saying now is that the house of my fathers and forefathers is good enough for me .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do you know , George , I can hear one of your ancestors saying that to his wife in their smelly old cave , when the new-fangled idea of building houses was first suggested . “ The Cave of my Fathers is — ”

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's ridiculous . Naturally we must have progress . But that 's just the point .Indicating the curtainsI do n't call this sort of thing progress . It 's — ah — retrogression .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , anyhow , it 's pretty .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There I disagree with you . And I must say once more that I will not have them hanging in my house .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Very well , George .But she goes on working .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That being so , I do n't see the necessity of going on with them .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , I must do something with them now I 've got the material . I thought perhaps I could sell them when they 're finished — as we 're so poor .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What do you mean — so poor ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , you said just now that you could n't give Dinah an allowance because rents had gone down .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: annoyedConfound it , Olivia ! Keep to the point ! We 'll talk about Dinah 's affairs directly . We 're discussing our own affairs at the moment .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But what is there to discuss ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Those ridiculous things .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But we 've finished that . You 've said you would n't have them hanging in your house , and I 've said , “ Very well , George . ” Now we can go on to Dinah and Brian .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: shoutingBut put these beastly things away .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: rising and gathering up the curtainsVery well , George .She puts them away , slowly , gracefully . There is an uncomfortable silence . Evidently somebody ought to apologise .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: realising that he is the oneEr — look here , Olivia , old girl , you 've been a jolly good wife to me , and we do n't often have rows , and if I 've been rude to you about this — lost my temper a bit perhaps , what ?— I 'll say I 'm sorry . May I have a kiss ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: holding up her faceGeorge , darling !He kisses her .Do you love me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You know I do , old girl .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: As much as Brian loves Dinah ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: stifflyI 've said all I want to say about that .He goes away from her .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , but there must be lots you want to say — and perhaps do n't like to . Do tell me , darling .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What it comes to is this . I consider that Dinah is too young to choose a husband for herself , and that Strange is n't the husband I should choose for her .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You were calling him Brian yesterday .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yesterday I regarded him as a boy , now he wants me to look upon him as a man .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: He 's twenty-four .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And Dinah 's nineteen . Ridiculous !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: If he 'd been a Conservative , and thought that clouds were round , I suppose he 'd have seemed older , somehow .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's a different point altogether . That has nothing to do with his age .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: innocentlyOh , I thought it had .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What I am objecting to is these ridiculously early marriages before either party knows its own mind , much less the mind of the other party . Such marriages invariably lead to unhappiness .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of course , my first marriage was n't a happy one .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: As you know , Olivia , I dislike speaking about your first marriage at all , and I had no intention of bringing it up now , but since you mention it — well , that is a case in point .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: looking back at itWhen I was eighteen , I was in love . Or perhaps I only thought I was , and I do n't know if I should have been happy or not if I had married him . But my father made me marry a man called Jacob Telworthy ; and when things were too hot for him in England — “ too hot for him ” — I think that was the expression we used in those days — then we went to Australia , and I left him there , and the only happy moment I had in all my married life was on the morning when I saw in the papers that he was dead .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: very uncomfortableYes , yes , my dear , I know . You must have had a terrible time . I can hardly bear to think about it . My only hope is that I have made up to you for it in some degree . But I do n't see what bearing it has upon Dinah 's case .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , none , except that my father liked Jacob 's political opinions and his views on art . I expect that that was why he chose him for me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You seem to think that I wish to choose a husband for Dinah . I do n't at all . Let her choose whom she likes as long as he can support her and there 's a chance of their being happy together . Now , with regard to this fellow —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You mean Brian ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's got no money , and he 's been brought up in quite a different way from Dinah . Dinah may be prepared to believe that — er — all cows are blue , and that — er — waves are square , but she wo n't go on believing it for ever .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Neither will Brian .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , that 's what I keep telling him , only he wo n't see it . Just as I keep telling you about those ridiculous curtains . It seems to me that I am the only person in the house with any eyesight left .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Perhaps you are , darling ; but you must let us find out our own mistakes for ourselves . At any rate , Brian is a gentleman ; he loves Dinah , Dinah loves him ; he 's earning enough to support himself , and you are earning enough to support Dinah . I think it 's worth risking , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: stifflyI can only say the whole question demands much more anxious thought than you seem to have given it . You say that he is a gentleman . He knows how to behave , I admit ; but if his morals are as topsy-turvy as his tastes and — er — politics , as I 've no doubt they are , then — er — In short , I do not approve of Brian Strange as a husband for my niece and ward .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: looking at him thoughtfullyYou are a curious mixture , George . You were so very unconventional when you married me , and you 're so very conventional when Brian wants to marry Dinah . . . . George Marden to marry the widow of a convict !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Convict ! What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Jacob Telworthy , convict — I forget his number — surely I told you all this , dear , when we got engaged ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Never !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I told you how he carelessly put the wrong signature to a cheque for a thousand pounds in England ; how he made a little mistake about two or three companies he 'd promoted in Australia ; and how —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , but you never told me he was convicted !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What difference does it make ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My dear Olivia , if you can n't see that — a convict !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: So , you see , we need n't be too particular about our niece , need we ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think we had better leave your first husband out of the conversation altogether . I never wished to refer to him ; I never wish to hear about him again . I certainly had not realised that he was actually — er — convicted for his — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Mistakes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , we need n't go into that . As for this other matter , I do n't for a moment take it seriously . Dinah is an exceptionally pretty girl , and young Strange is a good-looking boy . If they are attracted to each other , it is a mere outward attraction which I am convinced will not lead to any lasting happiness . That must be regarded as my last word in the matter , Olivia . If this Mr .— er — what was his name , comes , I shall be down at the farm .

div.stage: He goes out by the door .
Left alone , OLIVIA brings out her curtains again , and gets calmly to work upon them .
DINAH and BRIAN come in by the windows .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Finished ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh no , I 've got all these rings to put on .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I meant talking to George .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: We walked about outside —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Until we heard him not talking to you any more —

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: And we did n't kiss each other once .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Brian was very George-like . He would n't even let me tickle the back of his neck .She goes up suddenly to OLIVIA and kneels by her and kisses herDarling , being George-like is a very nice thing to be — I mean a nice thing for other people to be — I mean — oh , you know what I mean . But say that he 's going to be decent about it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of course he is , Dinah .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: You mean he 'll let me come here as — as —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: As my young man ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , I think so .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Olivia , you 're a wonder . Have you really talked him round ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I have n't said anything yet . But I daresay I shall think of something .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: disappointedlyOh !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: making the best of itAfter all , Dinah , I 'm going back to London to-morrow —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You can be good for one more day , Dinah , and then when Brian is n't here , we 'll see what we can do .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Yes , but I did n't want him to go back to-morrow .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: sternlyMust . Hard work before me . Earn thousands a year . Paint the Mayor and Corporation of Pudsey , life-size , including chains of office ; paint slice of haddock on plate . Copy Landseer for old gentleman in Bayswater . Design antimacassar for middle-aged sofa in Streatham . Earn a living for you , Dinah .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: gigglingOh , Brian , you 're heavenly . What fun we shall have when we 're married .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: stifflySir Brian Strange , R. A ., if you please , Miss Marden . Sir Brian Strange , R. A ., writes : “ Your Sanogene has proved a most excellent tonic . After completing the third acre of my Academy picture ‘ The Mayor and Corporation of Pudsey ’ I was completely exhausted , but one bottle of Sanogene revived me , and I finished the remaining seven acres at a single sitting . ”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: looking about herBrian , find my scissors for me .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Scissors .Looking for themSir Brian Strange , R. A ., looks for scissors .Finding themAha ! Once more we must record an unqualified success for the eminent Academician . Your scissors .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Thank you so much .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Come on , Brian , let 's go out . I feel open-airy .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
