sp.p: Do n't be late for lunch , there 's good people . Lady Marden is coming .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Aunt Juli-ah ! Help !She faints in BRIAN 'S armsThat means a clean pinafore . Brian , you 'll jolly well have to brush your hair .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: feeling itI suppose there 's no time now to go up to London and get it cut ?

div.stage: Enter ANNE , followed by PIM .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Mr. Pim !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: delightedHullo , Mr. Pim ! Here we are again ! You can n't get rid of us so easily , you see .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I — er — dear Miss Marden —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: How do you do , Mr. Pim ? I can n't get up , but do come and sit down . My husband will be here in a minute . Anne , send somebody down to the farm —

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I think I heard the Master in the library , madam .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , will you tell him then ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , madam .

div.stage: ANNE goes out .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You 'll stay to lunch , of course , Mr. Pim ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , do !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: It 's very kind of you , Mrs. Marden , but —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , you simply must , Mr. Pim . You have n't told us half enough about yourself yet . I want to hear all about your early life .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Dinah !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Oh , we are almost , I might say , old friends , Mrs. Marden .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Of course we are . He knows Brian , too . There 's more in Mr. Pim than you think . You will stay to lunch , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: It 's very kind of you to ask me , Mrs. Marden , but I am lunching with the Trevors .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , well , you must come to lunch another day .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: The reason why we like Mr. Pim so much is that he was the first person to congratulate us . We feel that he is going to have a great influence on our lives .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: to OLIVIAI , so to speak , stumbled on the engagement this morning and — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I see . Children , you must go and tidy yourselves up . Run along .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Sir Brian and Lady Strange never run ; they walk .Offering his armMadam !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: taking itAu revoir , Mr. Pim .DramaticallyWe — shall — meet — again !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: chucklingGood morning , Miss Dinah .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Good morning .

div.stage: He and DINAH go out .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You must forgive them , Mr. Pim . They 're such children . And naturally they 're rather excited just now .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Oh , not at all , Mrs. Marden .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of course you wo n't say anything about their engagement . We only heard about it five minutes ago , and nothing has been settled yet .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Of course , of course !

div.stage: Enter GEORGE .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah , Mr. Pim , we meet at last . Sorry to have kept you waiting before .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: The apology should come from me , Mr. Marden for having — er —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Not at all . Very glad to meet you now . Any friend of Brymer 's . You want a letter to this man Fanshawe ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Shall I be in your way at all ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Oh , no , no , please do n't .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's only just a question of a letter .Going to his deskFanshawe will put you in the way of seeing all that you want to see . He 's a very old friend of mine .Taking a sheet of notepaperYou 'll stay to lunch , of course ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I 'm afraid I am lunching with the Trevors —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , well , they 'll look after you all right . Good chap , Trevor .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: to OLIVIAYou see , Mrs. Marden , I have only recently arrived from Australia after travelling about the world for some years , and I 'm rather out of touch with my — er — fellow-workers in London .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh yes . You 've been in Australia , Mr. Pim ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: disliking AustraliaI sha n't be a moment , Mr. Pim .He frowns at OLIVIA .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right , thank you .to OLIVIAOh yes , I have been in Australia more than once in the last few years .

lg.l: Really ? I used to live at Sydney many years ago . Do you know
Sydney at all ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: detesting SydneyH'r ' m ! Perhaps I 'd better mention that you are a friend of the Trevors ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Thank you , thank you .to OLIVIAIndeed yes , I spent several months in Sydney .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: How curious . I wonder if we have any friends in common there .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: hastilyExtremely unlikely , I should think . Sydney is a very big place .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: True , but the world is a very small place , Mr. Marden . I had a remarkable instance of that , coming over on the boat this last time .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah !Feeling that the conversation is now safe , he resumes his letter .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes . There was a man I used to employ in Sydney some years ago , a bad fellow , I 'm afraid , Mrs. Marden , who had been in prison for some kind of fraudulent company-promoting and had taken to drink and — and so on .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , yes , I understand .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Drinking himself to death I should have said . I gave him at the most another year to live . Yet to my amazement the first person I saw as I stepped on board the boat that brought me to England last week was this fellow . There was no mistaking him . I spoke to him , in fact ; we recognised each other .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: He was travelling steerage ; we did n't meet again on board , and as it happened at Marseilles , this poor fellow — er — now what was his name ? A very unusual one . Began with a — a T , I think .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: with suppressed feelingYes , Mr. Pim , yes ?She puts out a hand to GEORGE .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: in an undertoneNonsense , dear !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: triumphantlyI 've got it ! Telworthy !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Telworthy !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good God !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: a little surprised at the success of his storyAn unusual name , is it not ? Not a name you could forget when once you had heard it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: with feelingNo , it is not a name you could forget when once you had heard it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: hastily coming over to PIMQuite so , Mr. Pim , a most remarkable name , a most odd story altogether . Well , well , here 's your letter , and if you 're sure you wo n't stay to lunch —

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I 'm afraid not , thank you . You see , I —

lg.l: The Trevors , yes . I 'll just see you on your way —
Er — my dear —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: holding out her hand , but not looking at himGood-bye , Mr. Pim .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Good-bye , good-bye !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: leading the way through the windowsThis way , this way . Quicker for you .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Thank you , thank you .

div.stage: GEORGE hurries MR. PIM out .
OLIVIA sits there and looks into the past . Now and then she shudders .
GEORGE comes back .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good God ! Telworthy ! Is it possible ?Before OLIVIA can answer , LADY MARDEN is announced . They pull themselves together and greet her .

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: Lunch is over and coffee has been served on the terrace . Conversation drags on , to the satisfaction of LADY MARDEN , but of nobody else . GEORGE and OLIVIA want to be alone ; so do BRIAN and DINAH . At last BRIAN murmurs something about a cigarette-case ; and , catching DINAH 'S eye , comes into the house . He leans against the sofa and waits for DINAH .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: loudly as she comes inHave you found it ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Found what ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: in her ordinary voiceThat was just for their benefit . I said I 'd help you find it . It is your cigarette-case we 're looking for , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: taking it outYes . Have one ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: No , thank you , darling . Aunt Juli-ah still thinks it 's unladylike . . . . Have you ever seen her beagling ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: No . Is that very ladylike ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Very . . . . I say , what has happened , do you think ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Everything . I love you , and you love me .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Silly ! I meant between George and Olivia . Did n't you notice them at lunch ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I noticed that you seemed to be doing most of the talking . But then I 've noticed that before sometimes . Do you think Olivia and your uncle have quarrelled because of us ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Of course not . George may think he has quarrelled , but I 'm quite sure Olivia has n't . No , I believe Mr. Pim 's at the bottom of it . He 's brought some terribly sad news about George 's investments . The old home will have to be sold up .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Good . Then your uncle wo n't mind your marrying me .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Yes , darling , but you must be more dramatic about it than that . “ George , ” you must say , with tears in your eyes , “ I cannot pay off the whole of the mortgage for you . I have only two and ninepence ; but at least let me take your niece off your hands . ” Then George will thump you on the back and say gruffly , “ You 're a good fellow , Brian , a damn good fellow , ” and he 'll blow his nose very loudly , and say , “ Confound this cigar , it wo n't draw properly . ”She gives us a rough impression of GEORGE doing it .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Dinah , you 're a heavenly idiot . And you 've simply got to marry me , uncles or no uncles .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: It will have to be “ uncles , ” I 'm afraid , because , you see , I 'm his ward , and I can get sent to Chancery or Coventry or somewhere beastly , if I marry without his consent . Have n't you got anybody who objects to your marrying me ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Nobody , thank Heaven .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , that 's rather disappointing of you . I saw myself fascinating your aged father at the same time that you were fascinating George . I should have done it much better than you . As a George-fascinator you are n't very successful , sweetheart .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: What am I like as a Dinah-fascinator ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Plus six , darling .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Then I 'll stick to that and leave George to Olivia .

lg.l: I expect she 'll manage him all right . I have great faith in
Olivia . But you 'll marry me , anyhow , wo n't you , Brian ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Even if we have to wait till I 'm twenty-one ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Even if we have to wait till you 're fifty-one .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: holding out her hands to himDarling !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: uneasilyI say , do n't do that .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , I promised I would n't kiss you .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh ! . . . Well , you might just send me a kiss . You can look the other way as if you did n't know I was here .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Like this ?

div.stage: He looks the other way , kisses the tips of his fingers , and flicks it carelessly in her direction .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: That was a lovely one . Now here 's one coming for you .

div.stage: He catches it gracefully and conveys it to his mouth .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: with a low bowMadam , I thank you .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: curtseyingYour servant , Mr . Strange .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: from outsideDinah !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: jumping upHullo !

div.stage: OLIVIA comes in through the windows , followed by GEORGE and LADY MARDEN , the latter a vigorous young woman of sixty odd , who always looks as if she were beagling .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Aunt Julia wants to see the pigs , dear . I wish you 'd take her down . I 'm rather tired , and your uncle has some business to attend to .

lg.l: I 've always said that you do n't take enough exercise ,
Olivia . Look at me — sixty-five and proud of it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , Aunt Julia , you 're wonderful .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: How old would Olivia be if she took exercise ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do n't stand about asking silly questions , Dinah . Your aunt has n't much time .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: May I come , too , Lady Marden ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Well , a little exercise would n't do you any harm , Mr . Strange . You 're an artist , ai n't you ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , I try to paint .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: He sold a picture last March for —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , never mind that now .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Unhealthy life . Well , come along .

div.stage: She strides out , followed by DINAH and BRIAN .
GEORGE sits down at his desk with his head in his hand , and stabs the blotting-paper with a pen . OLIVIA takes the curtains with her to the sofa and begins to work on them .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: looking up and seeing themReally , Olivia , we 've got something more important , more vital to us than curtains , to discuss , now that we are alone at last .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I was n't going to discuss them , dear .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm always glad to see Aunt Julia in my house , but I wish she had n't chosen this day of all days to come to lunch .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: It was n't Aunt Julia 's fault . It was really Mr. Pim who chose the wrong day .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: fiercelyGood Heavens , is it true ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: About Jacob Telworthy ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You told me he was dead . You always said that he was dead . You — you —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , I always thought that he was dead . He was as dead as anybody could be . All the papers said he was dead .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: scornfullyThe papers !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: as if this would settle it for GEORGEThe Times said he was dead . There was a paragraph about him . Apparently even his death was fraudulent .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , I 'm not blaming you , Olivia , but what are we going to do , that 's the question , what are we going to do ? My God , it 's horrible ! You 've never been married to me at all ! You do n't seem to understand .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: It is a little difficult to realise . You see , it does n't seem to have made any difference to our happiness .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , that 's what 's so terrible . I mean — well , of course , we were quite innocent in the matter . But , at the same time , nothing can get over the fact that we — we had no right to — to be happy .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Would you rather we had been miserable ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 're Telworthy 's wife , that 's what you do n't seem to understand . You 're Telworthy 's wife . You — er — forgive me , Olivia , but it 's the horrible truth — you committed bigamy when you married me .In horrorBigamy !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: It is an ugly word , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , but do n't you understand —He jumps up and comes over to herLook here , Olivia , old girl , the whole thing is nonsense , eh ? It is n't your husband , it 's some other Telworthy that this fellow met . That 's right , is n't it ? Some other shady swindler who turned up on the boat , eh ? This sort of thing does n't happen to people like us — committing bigamy and all that . Some other fellow .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: shaking her headI knew all the shady swindlers in Sydney , George . . . . They came to dinner . . . . There were no others called Telworthy .

div.stage: GEORGE goes back despondently to his seat .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , what are we going to do ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You sent Mr. Pim away so quickly . He might have told us things . Telworthy 's plans . Where he is now . You hurried him away so quickly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 've sent a note round to ask him to come back . My one idea at the moment was to get him out of the house — to hush things up .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You can n't hush up two husbands .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: in despairYou can n't . Everybody will know . Everybody !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: The children , Aunt Julia , they may as well know now as later . Mr. Pim must , of course .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do not propose to discuss my private affairs with Mr. Pim ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But he 's mixed himself up in them rather , has n't he , and if you 're going to ask him questions ——

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I only propose to ask him one question . I shall ask him if he is absolutely certain of the man 's name . I can do that quite easily without letting him know the reason for my inquiry .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You could n't make a mistake about a name like Telworthy . But he might tell us something about Telworthy 's plans . Perhaps he 's going back to Australia at once . Perhaps he thinks I 'm dead , too . Perhaps — oh , there are so many things I want to know .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , dear . It would be interesting to — that is , one naturally wants to know these things , but of course it does n't make any real difference .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedNo difference ?

lg.l: Well , that is to say , you 're as much his wife if he 's in
Australia as you are if he 's in England .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I am not his wife at all .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But , Olivia , surely you understand the position ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: shaking her headJacob Telworthy may be alive , but I am not his wife . I ceased to be his wife when I became yours .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You never were my wife . That is the terrible part of it . Our union — you make me say it , Olivia — has been unhallowed by the Church . Unhallowed even by the Law . Legally , we have been living in — living in — well , the point is , how does the Law stand ? I imagine that Telworthy could get a — a divorce . . . . Oh , it seems impossible that things like this can be happening to us .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: JoyfullyA divorce ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I — I imagine so .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But then we could really get married , and we should n't be living in — living in — whatever we were living in before .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I can n't understand you , Olivia . You talk about it so calmly , as if there was nothing blameworthy in being divorced , as if there was nothing unusual in my marrying a divorced woman , as if there was nothing wrong in our having lived together for years without having been married .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What seems wrong to me is that I lived for five years with a bad man whom I hated . What seems right to me is that I lived for five years with a good man whom I love .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , my dear , I know . But right and wrong do n't settle themselves as easily as that . We 've been living together when you were Telworthy 's wife . That 's wrong .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do you mean wicked ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , no doubt the Court would consider that we acted in perfect innocence —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What Court ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: These things have to be done legally , of course . I believe the proper method is a nullity suit , declaring our marriage null and — er — void . It would , so to speak , wipe out these years of — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Wickedness ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of irregular union , and — er — then —

lg.l: Then I could go back to Jacob . . . . Do you really mean that ,
George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: uneasilyWell , dear , you see — that 's how things are — one can n't get away from — er ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What you feel is that Telworthy has the greater claim ? You are prepared to — make way for him ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Both the Church and the Law would say that I had no claim at all , I 'm afraid . I — I suppose I have n't .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I see .She looks at him curiouslyThank you for making it so clear , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , whether or not you go back to — er — Telworthy is another matter altogether . That would naturally be for you to decide .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: cheerfullyFor me and Jacko to decide .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Er — Jacko ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I used to call my first husband — I mean my only husband — Jacko . I did n't like the name of Jacob , and Jacko seemed to suit him somehow . . . . He had very long arms . Dear Jacko .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: annoyedYou do n't seem to realise that this is not a joke , Olivia .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: a trifle hystericallyIt may not be a joke , but it is funny , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I must say I do n't see anything funny in a tragedy that has wrecked two lives .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Two ? Oh , but Jacko 's life is n't wrecked . It has just been miraculously restored to him . And a wife , too . There 's nothing tragic for Jacko in it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: stifflyI was referring to our two lives — yours and mine .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yours , George ? Your life is n't wrecked . The Court will absolve you of all blame ; your friends will sympathise with you , and tell you that I was a designing woman who deliberately took you in ; your Aunt Julia ——

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: overwroughtStop it ! What do you mean ? Have you no heart ? Do you think I want to lose you , Olivia ? Do you think I want my home broken up like this ? Have n't you been happy with me these last five years ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Very happy .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well then , how can you talk like that ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: patheticallyBut you want to send me away .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There you go again . I do n't want to . I have hardly had time to realise just what it will mean to me when you go . The fact is I simply dare n't realise it . I dare n't think about it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: earnestlyTry thinking about it , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And you talk as if I wanted to send you away !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Try thinking about it , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You do n't seem to understand that I 'm not sending you away . You simply are n't mine to keep .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Whose am I ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Your husband 's . Telworthy 's .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: gentlyIf I belong to anybody but myself , I think I belong to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Not in the eyes of the Law . Not in the eyes of the Church . Not even in the eyes of — er ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: The County ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: annoyedI was about to say “ Heaven . ”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: unimpressedOh !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That this should happen to us !He gets up and walks about the room , wondering when he will wake up from this impossible dream , OLIVIA works in silence . Then she stands up and shakes out her curtains .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: looking at themI do hope Jacko will like these .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What ! You ——Going up to herOlivia , Olivia , have you no heart ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ought you to talk like that to another man 's wife ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Confound it , is this just a joke to you ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You must forgive me , George ; I am a little over-excited — at the thought of returning to Jacob , I suppose .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do you want to return to him ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: One wants to do what is right . In the eyes of — er — Heaven .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Seeing what sort of man he is , I have no doubt that you could get a separation , supposing that he did n't — er — divorce you . I do n't know what is best . I must consult my solicitor . The whole position has been sprung on us , and —miserablyI do n't know , I do n't know . I can n't take it all in .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Would n't you like to consult your Aunt Julia too ? She could tell you what the County — I mean what Heaven really thought about it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes . Aunt Julia has plenty of common sense . You 're quite right , Olivia . This is n't a thing we can keep from the family .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do I still call her Aunt Julia ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: looking up from his pacingsWhat ? What ?ANNE comes in .Well , what is it ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Mr. Pim says he will come down at once , sir .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , thank you , thank you .

div.stage: ANNE goes out .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: George , Mr. Pim has got to know .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't see the necessity .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Not even for me ? When a woman suddenly hears that her long-lost husband is restored to her , do n't you think she wants to ask questions ? Where is he living , and how is he looking , and ——

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: coldlyOf course , if you are interested in these things —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: How can I help being ? Do n't be so silly , George . We must know what Jacko —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: annoyedI wish you would n't call him by that ridiculous name .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: My husband —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: wincingYes , well — your husband ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , we must know his plans — where we can communicate with him , and so on .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I have no wish to communicate with him .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 'll have to , dear .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't see the necessity .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , you 'll want to — to apologise to him for living with his wife for so long . And as I belong to him , he ought to be told where he can — call for me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: after a struggleYou put it in a very peculiar way , but I see your-point .With a shudderOh , the horrible publicity of it all !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: going up to him and comforting himPoor George . Dear , do n't think I do n't sympathise with you . I understand so exactly what you are feeling . The publicity ! It 's terrible .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: miserablyI want to do what 's right , Olivia . You believe that ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of course I do . It 's only that we do n't quite agree as to what is right and what is wrong .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It is n't a question of agreeing . Right is right , and wrong is wrong , all the world over .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: with a sad little smileBut more particularly in Buckinghamshire , I think .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If I only considered myself , I should say : “ Let us pack this man Telworthy back to Australia . He would make no claim . He would accept money to go away and say nothing about it . ” If I consulted simply my own happiness , Olivia , that is what I should say . But when I consult — er ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedMine ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My conscience ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then I can n't do it . It 's wrong .He is at the window as he says this .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: making her first and last appealGeorge , are n't I worth a little ——

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: turning roundH'sh ! Dinah !Loudly for DINAH 'S benefitWell , then I 'll write to him and — Ah , Dinah , where 's Aunt Julia ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: coming inWe 've seen the pigs , and now she 's discussing the Art of Landseer with Brian . I just came to ask ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Dinah , dear , bring Aunt Julia here . And Brian too . We have things we want to talk about with you all .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: outragedOlivia !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Righto . What fun !

div.stage: Exit DINAH .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Olivia , you do n't seriously suggest that we should discuss these things with a child like Dinah and a young man like Strange , a mere acquaintance .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Dinah will have to know . I 'm very fond of her , George . You can n't send me away without telling Dinah . And Brian is my friend . You have your solicitor and your aunt and your conscience to consult — may n't I even have Brian ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: forgettingI should have thought that your husband ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , but we do n't know where Jacko is .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I was not referring to — er — Telworthy .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well then ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , naturally I — you must n't — Oh , this is horrible !

div.stage: He comes back to his desk as the others come in .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: getting upGeorge and I have had some rather bad news , Aunt Julia . We wanted your advice . Where will you sit ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Thank you , Olivia . I can sit down by myself .She does so , near GEORGE . DINAH sits on the sofa with OLIVIA , and BRIAN half leans against the back of it . There is a hush of expectation . . . .What is it ? Money , I suppose . Nobody 's safe nowadays .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: signalling for helpOlivia —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: We 've just heard that my first husband is still alive .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Telworthy !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Good Lord !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: George !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: excitedlyAnd only this morning I was saying that nothing ever happened in this house !Remorsefully to OLIVIADarling , I do n't mean that . Darling one !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: What does this mean , George ? I leave you for ten minutes — barely ten minutes — to go and look at the pigs , and when I come back you tell me that Olivia is a bigamist .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: indignantlyI say —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: restraining himH'sh !

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: to OLIVIAIf this is a row , I 'm on your side .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Well , George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm afraid it 's true , Aunt Julia . We heard the news just before lunch — just before you came . We 've only this moment had an opportunity of talking about it , of wondering what to do .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: What was his name — Tel — something —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Jacob Telworthy .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: So he 's alive still ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Apparently . There seems to be no doubt about it .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: to OLIVIADid n't you see him die ? I should always want to see my husband die before I married again . Not that I approve of second marriages , anyhow . I told you so at the time , George .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: And me , Aunt Julia .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Did I ? Well , I generally say what I think .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I ought to tell you , Aunt Julia , that no blame attaches to Olivia over this . Of that I am perfectly satisfied . It 's nobody 's fault , except ——

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Except Telworthy 's . He seems to have been rather careless . Well , what are you going to do about it ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's just it . It 's a terrible situation . There 's bound to be so much publicity . Not only all this , but — but Telworthy 's past and — and everything .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I should have said that it was Telworthy 's present which was the trouble . Had he a past as well ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: He was a fraudulent company promoter . He went to prison a good deal .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: George , you never told me this !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I — er ——

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do n't see why he should want to talk about it .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: indignantlyWhat 's it got to do with Olivia , anyhow ? It 's not her fault .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: sarcasticallyOh no , I daresay it 's mine .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: to GEORGEYOU wanted to ask Aunt Julia what was the right thing to do .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: bursting outGood Heavens , what is there to do except the one and only thing ?They all look at him and he becomes embarrassedI 'm sorry . You do n't want me to —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do , Brian .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Well , go on , Mr . Strange . What would you do in George 's position ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Do ? Say to the woman I loved , “ You 're mine , and let this other damned fellow come and take you from me if he can ! ” And he could n't — how could he ?— not if the woman chose me .

div.stage: LADY MARDEN gazes at BRIAN in amazement , GEORGE in anger , OLIVIA presses his hand gratefully . He has said what she has been waiting — oh , so eagerly — for GEORGE to say .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: adoringlyOh , Brian !In a whisperIt is me , is n't it , and not Olivia ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: You baby , of course !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I 'm afraid , Mr . Strange , your morals are as peculiar as your views on Art . If you had led a more healthy life —

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: This is not a question of morals or of art , it 's a question of love .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Hear , hear !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: to GEORGEIs n't it that girl 's bedtime yet ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: to DINAHWe 'll let her sit up a little longer if she 's good .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I will be good , Olivia , only I thought anybody , however important a debate was , was allowed to say “ Hear , hear ! ”

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: coldlyI really think we could discuss this better if Mr . Strange took Dinah out for a walk . Strange , if you — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Tell them what you have settled first , George .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Settled ? What is there to be settled ? It settles itself .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: sadlyThat 's just it .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: The marriage must be annulled — is that the word , George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I presume so .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: One 's solicitor will know all about that of course .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: And when the marriage has been annulled , what then ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Presumably Olivia will return to her husband .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: bitterlyAnd that 's morality ! As expounded by Bishop Landseer !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: angeredI do n't know what you mean by Bishop Landseer . Morality is acting in accordance with the Laws of the Land and the Laws of the Church . I am quite prepared to believe that your creed embraces neither marriage nor monogamy , but my creed is different .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: fiercelyMy creed includes both marriage and monogamy , and monogamy means sticking to the woman you love , as long as she wants you .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: calmlyYou suggest that George and Olivia should go on living together , although they have never been legally married , and wait for this Telworthy man to divorce her , and then — bless the man , what do you think the County would say ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: scornfullyDoes it matter ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , if you really want to know , the men would say , “ Gad , she 's a fine woman ; I do n't wonder he sticks to her , ” and the women would say , “ I can n't think what he sees in her to stick to her like that , ” and they 'd both say , “ After all , he may be a damn fool , but you can n't deny he 's a sportsman . ” That 's what the County would say .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: indignantlyWas it for this sort of thing , Olivia , that you insisted on having Dinah and Mr . Strange in here ? To insult me in my own house ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I can n't think what young people are coming to nowadays .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I think , dear , you and Brian had better go .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: getting upWe will go . But I 'm just going to say one thing , Uncle George . Brian and I are going to marry each other , and when we are married we 'll stick to each other , however many of our dead husbands and wives turn up !

div.stage: She goes out indignantly , followed by BRIAN .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Upon my word , this is a pleasant discussion .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I think the discussion is over , George . It is only a question of where I shall go , while you are bringing your — what sort of suit did you call it ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: to GEORGENullity suit . I suppose that is the best thing ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's horrible . The awful publicity . That it should be happening to us , that 's what I can n't get over .

lg.l: I do n't remember anything of the sort in the Marden
Family before , ever .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: absentlyLady Fanny .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: recollectingYes , of course ; but that was two hundred years ago . The standards were different then . Besides , it was n't quite the same , anyhow .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: absentlyNo , it was n't quite the same .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: No . We shall all feel it . Terribly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: his apologyIf there were any other way ! Olivia , what can I do ? It is the only way , is n't it ? All that that fellow said — of course , it sounds very well — but as things are . . . . Is there anything in marriage , or is n't there ? You believe that there is , do n't you ? You are n't one of these Socialists . Well , then , can we go on living together when you 're another man 's wife ? It is n't only what people will say , but it is wrong , is n't it ? . . . And supposing he does n't divorce you , are we to go on living together , unmarried , for ever ? Olivia , you seem to think that I 'm just thinking of the publicity — what people will say . I 'm not . I 'm not . That comes in any way . But I want to do what 's right , what 's best . I do n't mean what 's best for us , what makes us happiest , I mean what 's really best , what 's rightest . What anybody else would do in my place . I do n't know . It 's so unfair . You 're not my wife at all , but I want to do what 's right . . . . Oh , Olivia , Olivia , you do understand , do n't you ?

div.stage: They have both forgotten LADY MARDEN . OLIVIA has never taken her eyes off him as he makes his last attempt to convince himself .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: almost tenderlySo very very well , George . Oh , I understand just what you are feeling . And oh , I do so wish that you could —with a little sigh— but then it would n't be George , not the George I married —with a rueful little laugh— or did n't quite marry .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I must say , I think you are both talking a little wildly .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: repeating it , oh , so tenderlyOr did n't — quite — marry .She looks at him with all her heart in her eyes . She is giving him his last chance to say “ Damn Telworthy ; you 're mine ! ” He struggles desperately with himself . . . . Will he ?— will he ? . . . But we shall never know , for at that moment ANNE comes in .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Mr. Pim is here , sir .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: emerging from the struggle with an effortPim ? Pim ? Oh , ah , yes , of course . Mr. Pim .Looking upWhere have you put him ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I want to see Mr. Pim , too , George .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Who on earth is Mr. Pim ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Show him in here , Anne .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: She goes out .Yes , madam .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: It was Mr. Pim who told us about my husband . He came across with him in the boat , and recognised him as the Telworthy he knew in Australia .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Oh ! Shall I be in the way ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , no . It does n't matter , does it , Olivia ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Please stay .

div.stage: ANNE enters followed by MR. PIM .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Mr. Pim .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: pulling himself togetherAh , Mr. Pim ! Very good of you to have come . The fact is — er —It is too much for him ; he looks despairingly at OLIVIA .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: We 're so sorry to trouble you , Mr. Pim . By the way , do you know Lady Marden ?MR. PIM and LADY MARDEN bow to each other .Do come and sit down , wo n't you ?She makes room for him on the sofa next to herThe fact is , Mr. Pim , you gave us rather a surprise this morning , and before we had time to realise what it all meant , you had gone .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . A surprise , Mrs. Marden ? Dear me , not an unpleasant one , I hope ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , rather a — surprising one .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Olivia , allow me a moment . Mr. Pim , you mentioned a man called Telworthy this morning . My wife used to — that is to say , I used to — that is , there are reasons —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I think we had better be perfectly frank , George .

lg.l: I am sixty-five years of age , Mr. Pim , and I can say that
I 've never had a moment 's uneasiness by telling the truth .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIMafter a desperate effort to keep up with the conversationOh ! . . . I — er — I 'm afraid I am rather at sea . Have I — er — left anything unsaid in presenting my credentials to you this morning ? This Telworthy whom you mention — I seem to remember the name —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Mr. Pim , you told us this morning of a man whom you had met on the boat , a man who had come down in the world , whom you had known in Sydney . A man called Telworthy .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIMrelievedAh yes , yes , of course . I did say Telworthy , did n't I ? Most curious coincidence , Lady Marden . Poor man , poor man ! Let me see , it must have been ten years ago —

lg.l: Just a moment , Mr. Pim . You 're quite sure that his name was
Telworthy ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Telworthy — Telworthy — did n't I say Telworthy ? Yes , that was it — Telworthy . Poor fellow !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I 'm going to be perfectly frank with you , Mr. Pim . I feel quite sure that I can trust you . This man Telworthy whom you met is my husband .

lg.l: PIM . Your husband ?
lg.stage: He looks in mild surprise at GEORGE .
lg.l: But — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: My first husband . His death was announced six years ago . I had left him some years before that , but there seems no doubt from your story that he 's still alive . His record — the country he comes from — above all , the very unusual name — Telworthy .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Telworthy — yes — certainly a most peculiar name . I remember saying so . Your first husband ? Dear me ! Dear me !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You understand , Mr. Pim , that all this is in absolute confidence .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Of course , of course .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , since he is my husband , we naturally want to know something about him . Where is he now , for instance ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIMsurprisedWhere is he now ? But surely I told you ? I told you what happened at Marseilles ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: At Marseilles ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Yes , yes , poor fellow , it was most unfortunate .Quite happy againYou must understand , Lady Marden , that although I had met the poor fellow before in Australia , I was never in any way intimate —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: thumping the deskWhere is he now , that 's what we want to know ?

div.stage: MR. PIM turns to him with a start .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Please , Mr. Pim !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Where is he now ? But — but did n't I tell you of the curious fatality at Marseilles — poor fellow — the fish-bone ?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Fish-bone ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Yes , yes , a herring , I understand .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: understanding firstDo you mean he 's dead ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Dead — of course — did n't I —?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: laughing hystericallyOh , Mr. Pim , you — oh , what a husband to have — oh , I —But that is all she can say for the moment .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Pull yourself together , Olivia . This is so unhealthy for you .to PIMSo he really is dead this time ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Oh , undoubtedly , undoubtedly . A fishbone lodged in his throat .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: trying to realise itDead !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: struggling with her laughterI think you must excuse me , Mr. Pim — I can never thank you enough — a herring — there 's something about a herring — morality depends on such little things — George , you —Shaking her head at him in a weak state of laughter , she hurries out of the room .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Dear me ! Dear me !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Now , let us have this quite clear , Mr. Pim . You say that the man , Telworthy , Jacob Telworthy , is dead ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Telworthy , yes — did n't I say Telworthy ? This man I was telling you about —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 's dead ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Yes , yes , he died at Marseilles .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: A dispensation of Providence , George . One can look at it in no other light .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Dead !Suddenly annoyedReally , Mr. Pim , I think you might have told us before .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . But I — I was telling you — I —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If you had only told us the whole story at once , instead of in two — two instalments like this , you would have saved us all a good deal of anxiety .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Really , I —

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I am sure Mr. Pim meant well , George , but it seems a pity he could n't have said so before . If the man was dead , why try to hush it up ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIMlost againReally , Lady Marden , I —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: getting upWell , well , at any rate , I am much obliged to you , Mr. Pim , for having come down to us this afternoon . Dead ! De mortuis , and so forth , but the situation would have been impossible had he lived . Good-bye !Holding out his handGood-bye !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Pim .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: PIM . Good-bye , good-bye !GEORGE takes him to the door .Of course , if I had —to himselfTelworthy — I think that was the name .He goes out , still wondering .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: with a sigh of thankfulnessWell ! This is wonderful news , Aunt Julia .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Most providential ! . . . You understand , of course , that you are not married to Olivia ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: who did n'tNot married ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: If her first husband only died at Marseilles a few days ago —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good Heavens !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Not that it matters . You can get married quietly again . Nobody need know .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: considering itYes . . . yes . Then all these years we have been — er — Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Who 's going to know ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , that 's true . . . . And in perfect innocence , too .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: I should suggest a Registry Office in London .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: A Registry Office , yes .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Better go up to town this afternoon . Ca n't do it too quickly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes . We can stay at an hotel —

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: surprisedGeorge !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: You will stay at your club .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh — ah — yes , of course , Aunt Julia .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: Better take your solicitor with you to be on the safe side . . . . To the Registry Office , I mean .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: getting upWell , I must be getting along , George . Say good-bye to Olivia for me . And those children . Of course , you wo n't allow this absurd love-business between them to come to anything ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Most certainly not . Good-bye , Aunt Julia !

sp.speaker: LADY MARDEN
sp.p: indicating the windowsI 'll go this way .As she goesAnd get Olivia out more , George . I do n't like these hysterics . You want to be firm with her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: firmlyYes , yes ! Good-bye !

div.stage: He waves to her and then goes back to his seat .
OLIVIA comes in , and stands in the middle of the room looking at him . He comes to her eagerly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: holding out his handsOlivia ! Olivia !But it is not so easy as that .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: drawing herself up proudlyMrs. Telworthy !

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: ( OLIVIA is standing where we left her at the end of the last act . )

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: taken abackOlivia , I — I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: leaving melodrama with a little laugh and coming down to himPoor George ! Did I frighten you rather ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 're so strange to-day . I do n't understand you . You 're not like the Olivia I know .

div.stage: They sit down on the sofa together .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Perhaps you do n't know me very well after all .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: affectionatelyOh , that 's nonsense , old girl . You 're just my Olivia .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: And yet it seemed as though I was n't going to be your Olivia half an hour ago .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: with a shudderDo n't talk about it . It does n't bear thinking about . Well , thank Heaven that 's over . Now we can get married again quietly and nobody will be any the wiser .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Married again ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , dear . As you — er —he laughs uneasilysaid just now , you are Mrs. Telworthy . Just for the moment . But we can soon put that right . My idea was to go up this evening and — er — make arrangements , and if you come up to-morrow morning , if we can manage it by then , we could get quietly married at a Registry Office , and — er — nobody any the wiser .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , I see . You want me to marry you at a Registry Office to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If we can arrange it by then . I do n't know how long these things take , but I should imagine there would be no difficulty .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh no , that part ought to be quite easy . But —She hesitates .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But what ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , if you want to marry me to-morrow , George , ought n't you to propose to me first ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: amazedPropose ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . It is usual , is n't it , to propose to a person before you marry her , and — and we want to do the usual thing , do n't we ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: upsetBut you — but we . . .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You see , dear , you 're George Marden , and I 'm Olivia Telworthy , and you — you 're attracted by me , and think I would make you a good wife , and you want to marry me . Well , naturally you propose to me first , and — tell me how much you are attracted by me , and what a good wife you think I shall make , and how badly you want to marry me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: falling into the humour of it , as he thinksThe baby ! Did she want to be proposed to all over again ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , she did rather .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: rather fancying himself as an actorShe shall then .He adopts what he considers to be an appropriate attitudeMrs. Telworthy , I have long admired you in silence , and the time has now come to put my admiration into words . Er —But apparently he finds a difficulty .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: hopefullyInto words .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: with the idea of helpingOh , Mr. Marden !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Er — may I call you Olivia ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: taking her handOlivia — I —He hesitates .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do n't want to interrupt , but ought n't you to be on your knees ? It is — usual , I believe . If one of the servants came in , you could say you were looking for my scissors .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Really , Olivia , you must allow me to manage my own proposal in my own way .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: meeklyI 'm sorry . Do go on .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , er — confound it , Olivia , I love you . Will you marry me ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Thank you , George , I will think it over .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: laughingSilly girl ! Well then , to-morrow morning . No wedding-cake , I 'm afraid , Olivia .He laughs againBut we 'll go and have a good lunch somewhere .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I will think it over , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: good-humouredlyWell , give us a kiss while you 're thinking .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I 'm afraid you must n't kiss me until we are actually engaged .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: laughing uneasilyOh , we need n't take it as seriously as all that .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But a woman must take a proposal seriously .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: alarmed at lastWhat do you mean ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I mean that the whole question , as I heard somebody say once , demands much more anxious thought than either of us has given it . These hasty marriages —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hasty !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , you 've only just proposed to me , and you want to marry me to-morrow .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Now you 're talking perfect nonsense , Olivia . You know quite well that our case is utterly different from — from any other .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: All the same , one has to ask oneself questions . With a young girl like — well , with a young girl , love may well seem to be all that matters . But with a woman of my age , it is different . I have to ask myself if you can afford to support a wife .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: coldlyFortunately that is a question that you can very easily answer for yourself .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , but I have been hearing rather bad reports lately . What with taxes always going up , and rents always going down , some of our landowners are getting into rather straitened circumstances . At least , so I 'm told .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know what you 're talking about .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedOh , is n't it true ? I heard of a case only this morning — a landowner who always seemed to be very comfortably off , but who could n't afford an allowance for his only niece when she wanted to get married . It made me think that one ought n't to judge by appearances .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You know perfectly well that I can afford to support a wife as my wife should be supported .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I 'm so glad , dear . Then your income — you are n't getting anxious at all ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: stifflyYou know perfectly well what my income is . I see no reason for anxiety in the future .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ah , well , then we need n't think about that any more . Well , then , there is another thing to be considered .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I can n't make out what you 're up to . Do n't you want to get married ; to — er — legalise this extraordinary situation in which we are placed ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I want to be sure that I am going to be happy , George . I can n't just jump at the very first offer I have had since my husband died , without considering the whole question very carefully .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: So I 'm under consideration , eh ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Every suitor is .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: sarcastically , as he thinksWell , go on .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , then , there 's your niece . You have a niece who lives with you . Of course Dinah is a delightful girl , but one does n't like marrying into a household in which there is another grown-up woman . But perhaps she will be getting married herself soon ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I see no prospect of it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I think it would make it much easier if she did .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is this a threat , Olivia ? Are you telling me that if I do not allow young Strange to marry Dinah , you will not marry me ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: A threat ? Oh no , George .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then what does it mean ?

lg.l: I 'm just wondering if you love me as much as Brian loves
Dinah . You do love me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: from his heartYou know I do , old girl .He comes to her .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You 're not just attracted by my pretty face ? . . . Is it a pretty face ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's an adorable one .He tries to kiss it , but she turns away .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: How can I be sure that it is not only my face which makes you think that you care for me ? Love which rests upon a mere outward attraction cannot lead to any lasting happiness — as one of our thinkers has observed .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What 's come over you , Olivia ? I do n't understand what you 're driving at . Why should you doubt my love ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ah !— Why ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You can n't pretend that we have n't been happy together . I 've — I 've been a good pal to you , eh ? We — we suit each other , old girl .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do we ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course we do .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I wonder . When two people of our age think of getting married , one wants to be very sure that there is real community of ideas between them . Whether it is a comparatively trivial matter , like the right colour for a curtain , or some very much more serious question of conduct which arises , one wants to feel that there is some chance of agreement between husband and wife .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We — we love each other , old girl .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: We do now , yes . But what shall we be like in five years ’ time ? Supposing that after we have been married five years , we found ourselves estranged from each other upon such questions as Dinah 's future , or the decorations of the drawing-room , or even the advice to give to a friend who had innocently contracted a bigamous marriage ? How bitterly we should regret then our hasty plunge into a matrimony which was no true partnership , whether of tastes , or of ideas , or even of consciences !With a sighAh me !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: nastilyUnfortunately for your argument , Olivia , I can answer you out of your own mouth . You seem to have forgotten what you said this morning in the case of — er — young Strange .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: reproachfullyIs it quite fair , George , to drag up what was said this morning ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 've brought it on yourself .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I ? . . . Well , and what did I say this morning ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You said that it was quite enough that Strange was a gentleman and in love with Dinah for me to let them marry each other .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh ! . . . Is that enough , George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: triumphantlyYou said so .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: meeklyWell , if you think so , too , I — I do n't mind risking it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: kindlyAha , my dear ! You see !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Then you do think it 's enough ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I — er — Yes , yes , I — I think so .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: going to himMy darling one ! Then we can have a double wedding . How jolly !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: astoundedA double one !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . You and me , Brian and Dinah .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: firmlyNow look here , Olivia , understand once and for all , I am not to be blackmailed into giving my consent to Dinah 's engagement . Neither blackmailed nor tricked . Our marriage has nothing whatever to do with Dinah 's .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: No , dear . I quite understand . They may take place about the same time , but they have nothing to do with each other .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I see no prospect of Dinah 's marriage taking place for many years .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: No , dear , that was what I said .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: not understanding for the momentYou said . . . . ? I see . Now , Olivia , let us have this perfectly clear . You apparently insist on treating my — er — proposal as serious .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedWas n't it serious ? Were you trifling with me ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You know quite well what I mean . You treat it as an ordinary proposal from a man to a woman who have never been more than acquaintances before . Very well then . Will you tell me what you propose to do , if you decide to — ah — refuse me ? You do not suggest that we should go on living together — unmarried ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: shockedOf course not , George ! What would the County — I mean Heaven — I mean the Law — I mean , of course not ! Besides , it 's so unnecessary . If I decide to accept you , of course I shall marry you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Quite so . And if you — ah — decide to refuse me ? What will you do ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Meaning by that ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Just that , George . I shall stay here — just as before . I like this house . It wants a little re-decorating perhaps , but I do like it , George . . . . Yes , I shall be quite happy here .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I see . You will continue to live down here — in spite of what you said just now about the immorality of it .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedBut there 's nothing immoral in a widow living alone in a big country house , with perhaps the niece of a friend of hers staying with her , just to keep her company .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: sarcasticAnd what shall I be doing , when you 've so very kindly taken possession of my house for me ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do n't know , George . Travelling , I expect . You could come down sometimes with a chaperone . I suppose there would be nothing wrong in that .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: indignantThank you ! And what if I refuse to be turned out of my house ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Then , seeing that we can n't both be in it , it looks as though you 'd have to turn me out .CasuallyI suppose there are legal ways of doing these things . You 'd have to consult your solicitor again .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: amazedLegal ways ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , you could n't throw me out , could you ? You 'd have to get an injunction against me — or prosecute me for trespass — or something . It would make an awfully unusual case , would n't it ? The papers would be full of it .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You must be mad !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: dreamilyWidow of well-known ex-convict takes possession of J. P .' s house . Popular country gentleman denied entrance to his own home . Doomed to travel .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: angrilyI 've had enough of this . Do you mean all this nonsense ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I do mean , George , that I am in no hurry to go up to London and get married . I love the country just now , andwith a sighafter this morning , I 'm — rather tired of husbands .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: in a rageI 've never heard so much — damned nonsense in my life . I will leave you to come to your senses .He goes out indignantly .

div.stage: OLIVIA , who has forgiven him already , throws a loving kiss after him , and then turns triumphantly to her dear curtains . She takes them , smiling , to the sofa , and has just got to work again , when MR. PIM appears at the open windows .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: in a whisperEr , may I come in , Mrs. Marden ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: turning round in surpriseMr. Pim !

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: anxiouslyMr. Marden is — er — not here ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: getting upDo you want to see him ? I will tell him .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: No , no , no ! Not for the world !He comes in and looks anxiously at the doorThere is no immediate danger of his returning , Mrs. Marden ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: surprisedNo , I do n't think so . What is it ? You —

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I took the liberty of returning by the window in the hope of — er — coming upon you alone , Mrs. Marden .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: still rather nervousI — er — Mr. Marden will be very angry with me . Quite rightly . I blame myself entirely . I do not know how I can have been so stupid .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What is it , Mr. Pim ? Has my husband come to life again ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Mrs. Marden , I throw myself on your mercy entirely . The fact is — his name was Polwittle .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: at a lossWhose ? My husband 's ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , yes . The name came back to me suddenly , just as I reached the gate . Polwittle , poor fellow .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But , Mr. Pim , my husband 's name was Telworthy .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: No , no , Polwittle .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But , really I ought to . . . .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: firmlyPolwittle . It came back to me suddenly just as I reached the gate . For the moment , I had thoughts of conveying the news by letter . I was naturally disinclined to return in person , and — Polwittle .ProudlyIf you remember , I always said it was a curious name .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But who is Polwittle ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: in surprise at her stupidityThe man I have been telling you about , who met with the sad fatality at Marseilles . Henry Polwittle — or was it Ernest ? No , Henry , I think . Poor fellow .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: indignantlyBut you said his name was Telworthy ! How could you ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , yes , I blame myself entirely .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: But how could you think of a name like Telworthy , if it was n't Telworthy ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: eagerlyAh , that is the really interesting thing about the whole matter .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Mr. Pim , all your visits here to-day have been interesting .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , but you see , on my first appearance here this morning , I was received by — er — Miss Diana .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Dinah .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Miss Dinah , yes . She was in — er — rather a communicative mood , and she happened to mention , by way of passing the time , that before your marriage to Mr. Marden you had been a Mrs .— er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Telworthy .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , yes , Telworthy , of course . She mentioned also Australia . By some process of the brain — which strikes me as decidedly curious — when I was trying to recollect the name of the poor fellow on the boat , whom you remember I had also met in Australia , the fact that this other name was also stored in my memory , a name equally peculiar — this fact I say . . .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: seeing that the sentence is rapidly going to piecesYes , I understand .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I blame myself , I blame myself entirely .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , you must n't do that , Mr. Pim . It was really Dinah 's fault for inflicting all our family history on you .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Oh , but a charming young woman . I assure you I was very much interested in all that she told me .Getting upWell , Mrs .— er — Marden , I can only hope that you will forgive me for the needless distress I have caused you to-day .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , you must n't worry about that — please .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: And you will tell your husband — you will break the news to him ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: smiling to herselfI will — break the news to him .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: You understand how it is that I thought it better to come to you in the first place ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I am very glad you did .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: holding out his handThen I will say good-bye , and — er —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Just a moment , Mr. Pim . Let us have it quite clear this time . You never knew my husband , Jacob Telworthy , you never met him in Australia , you never saw him on the boat , and nothing whatever happened to him at Marseilles . Is that right ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , yes , that is so .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: So that , since he was supposed to have died in Australia six years ago , he is presumably still dead ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Yes , yes , undoubtedly .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: holding out her hand with a charming smileThen good-bye , Mr. Pim , and thank you so much for — for all your trouble .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: Not at all , Mrs. Marden . I can only assure you I —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: from the windowHullo , here 's Mr. Pim !She comes in , followed by BRIAN .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: anxiously looking at the door in case MR. MARDEN should come inYes , yes , I — er —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Pim , you must n't run away without even saying how do you do ! Such old friends as we are . Why , it is ages since I saw you ! Are you staying to tea ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I 'm afraid I —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Mr. Pim has to hurry away , Dinah . You must n't keep him .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , but you 'll come back again ?

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: I fear that I am only a passer-by , Miss — er — Dinah .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You can walk with him to the gate , dear .

sp.speaker: PIM
sp.p: gratefully to OLIVIAThank you .He edges towards the windowIf you would be so kind , Miss Dinah —

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I 'll catch you up .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Come along then , Mr. Pim .As they go outI want to hear all about your first wife . You have n't really told me anything yet .

div.stage: OLIVIA resumes her work , and BRIAN sits on the back of the sofa looking at her .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: awkwardlyI just wanted to say , if you do n't think it cheek , that I 'm — I 'm on your side , if I may be , and if I can help you at all I should be very proud of being allowed to .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: looking up at himBrian , you dear . That 's sweet of you . . . But it 's quite all right now , you know .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so glad .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , that 's what Mr. Pim came back to say . He 'd made a mistake about the name .SmilingGeorge is the only husband I have .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: surprisedWhat ? You mean that the whole thing — that Pim —With convictionSilly ass !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: kindlyOh , well , he did n't mean to be .After a pauseBrian , do you know anything about the Law ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: I 'm afraid not . I hate the Law . Why ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: casuallyOh , I just — I was wondering — thinking about all the shocks we 've been through to-day . Second marriages , and all that .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Oh ! It 's a rotten business .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I suppose there 's nothing wrong in getting married to the same person twice ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: A hundred times if you like , I should think .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: After all , in France , they always go through it twice , do n't they ? Once before the Mayor or somebody , and once in church .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of course they do ! How silly of me . . . I think it 's rather a nice idea . They ought to do it in England more .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Well , once will be enough for Dinah and me , if you can work it .AnxiouslyD'you think there 's any chance , Olivia ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: smilingEvery chance , dear .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: jumping upI say , do you really ? Have you squared him ? I mean , has he —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Go and catch them up now . We 'll talk about it later on .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Bless you . Righto .

div.stage: As he goes out by the windows , GEORGE comes in at the door . GEORGE stands looking after him , and then turns to OLIVIA , who is absorbed in her curtains . He walks up and down the room , fidgeting with things , waiting for her to speak . As she says nothing , he begins to talk himself , but in an obviously unconcerned way . There is a pause after each answer of hers , before he gets out his next remark .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: casuallyGood-looking fellow , Strange .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: equally casuallyBrian — yes , is n't he ? And such a nice boy . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Got fifty pounds for a picture the other day , did n't he ? Hey ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . Of course he has only just begun . . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Critics think well of him , what ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: They all say he has genius . Oh , I do n't think there 's any doubt about it . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , I do n't profess to know anything about painting .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You 've never had time to take it up , dear .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I know what I like , of course . Ca n't say I see much in this new-fangled stuff . If a man can paint , why can n't he paint like — like Rubens or — or Reynolds ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I suppose we all have our own styles . Brian will find his directly . Of course , he 's only just beginning . . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But they think a lot of him , what ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh yes !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: H 'm ! . . . Good-looking fellow .There is rather a longer silence this time , GEORGE continues to hope that he is appearing casual and unconcerned . He stands looking at OLIVIA 'S work for a moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Nearly finished ‘ em ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Very nearly . Are my scissors there ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: looking roundScissors ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ah , here they are . . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Where are you going to put ‘ em ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: as if really wonderingI do n't quite know . . . . I had thought of this room , but — I 'm not quite sure .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Brighten the room up a bit .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: walking over to the present curtainsH 'm . They are a bit faded .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: shaking out hers , and looking at them criticallySometimes I think I love them , and sometimes I 'm not quite sure .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Best way is to hang ‘ em up and see how you like ‘ em then . Always take ‘ em down again .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: That 's rather a good idea , George !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Best way .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . . . . I think we might do that . . . . The only thing is —she hesitates

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , the carpet and the chairs , and the cushions and things —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What about ‘ em ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , if we had new curtains —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 'd want a new carpet , eh ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: doubtfullyY — yes . Well , new chair-covers anyhow .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: H 'm . . . . Well , why not ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , but —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: with an awkward laughWe 're not so hard up as all that , you know .

lg.l: No , I suppose not .
I suppose it would mean that
I should have to go up to London for them . That 's rather a nuisance .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: extremely casualOh , I do n't know . We might go up together one day .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , of course if we were up — for anything else — we could just look about us , and see if we could find what we want .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That 's what I meant .

div.stage: There is another silence . GEORGE is wondering whether to come to closer quarters with the great question .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , by the way , George —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: innocentlyI told Brian , and I expect he 'll tell Dinah , that Mr. Pim had made a mistake about the name .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: astonishedYou told Brian that Mr. Pim —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes — I told him that the whole thing was a mistake . It seemed the simplest way .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Olivia ! Then you mean that Brian and Dinah think that — that we have been married all the time ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . . . They both think so now .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: coming close to herOlivia , does that mean that you are thinking of marrying me ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: At your old Registry Office ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: eagerlyYes !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: To-morrow ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do you want me to very much ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: My darling , you know I do !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: a little apprehensiveWe should have to do it very quietly .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , darling . Nobody need know at all . We do n't want anybody to know . And now that you 've put Brian and Dinah off the scent , by telling them that Mr. Pim made a mistake —He breaks off , and says admiringlyThat was very clever of you , Olivia . I should never have thought of that .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: innocentlyNo , darling . . . . You do n't think it was wrong , George ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: his verdictAn innocent deception . . . perfectly harmless .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes , dear , that was what I thought about — about what I was doing .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then you will come to-morrow ?She nods .And if we happen to see the carpet , or anything that you want —

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , what fun !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: beamingAnd a wedding lunch at the Carlton , what ?She nods eagerly .And — and a bit of a honeymoon in Paris ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , George !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: hungrilyGive us a kiss , old girl .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: lovinglyGeorge !

div.stage: She holds up her cheek to him . He kisses it , and then suddenly takes her in his arms .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do n't ever leave me , old girl .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: affectionatelyDo n't ever send me away , old boy .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: ferventlyI wo n't . . . .AwkwardlyI — I do n't think I would have , you know . I — I —

div.stage: DINAH and BRIAN appear at the windows , having seen MR. PIM safely off .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: surprisedOo , I say !

div.stage: GEORGE hastily moves away .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hallo !

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: going up impetuously to himGive me one , too , George ; Brian wo n't mind .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Really , Dinah , you are the limit .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: formally , but enjoying itDo you mind , Mr . Strange ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: a little uncomfortablyOh , I say , sir —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We 'll risk it , Dinah .He kisses her .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: triumphantly to BRIANDid you notice that one ? That was n't just an ordinary affectionate kiss . It was a special bless — you — my — children one .to GEORGEWas n't it ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: You do talk nonsense , darling .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , I 'm so happy , now that Mr. Pim has relented about your first husband —

div.stage: GEORGE catches OLIVIA 'S eye and smiles ; she smiles back ; but they are different smiles .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: the actorYes , yes , stupid fellow Pim , what ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Absolute idiot .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: — And now that George has relented about my first husband .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You get on much too quickly , young woman .to BRIANSo you want to marry my Dinah , eh ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: with a smileWell , I do rather , sir .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: hastilyNot at once , of course , George . We want to be engaged for a long time first , and write letters to each other , and tell each other how much we love each other , and sit next to each other when we go out to dinner .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: to OLIVIAWell , that sounds fairly harmless , I think .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: smilingI think so . . . .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: to BRIANThen you 'd better have a talk with me — er — Brian .

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Thank you very much , sir .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , come along then .Looking at his watchI am going up to town after tea , so we 'd better —

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I say ! Are you going to London ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: with the smile of the conspiratorA little business . Never you mind , young lady .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: calmlyAll right . Only , bring me back something nice .
