sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: to BRIANShall we walk down and look at the pigs ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: Righto !

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Do n't go far , dear . I may want you in a moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All right , darling , we 'll be on the terrace .

div.stage: They go out together .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Brian and George always try to discuss me in front of the pigs . So tactless of them . Are you going to London , too , darling ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: To-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: What are you going to do in London ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , shopping , and — one or two little things .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: With George ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Yes . . . .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I say , was n't it lovely about Pim ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Lovely ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Yes ; he told me all about it . Making such a hash of things , I mean .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: innocentlyDid he make a hash of things ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: Well , I mean keeping on coming like that . And if you look at it all round — well , for all he had to say , he need n't really have come at all .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: smiling to herselfI should n't quite say that , Dinah .She stands up and shakes out the curtains .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I say , are n't they jolly ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: demurelyI 'm so glad everybody likes them . Tell George I 'm ready , will you ?

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: I say , is he going to hang them up for you ?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Well , I thought he could reach best .

lg.l: Righto ! What fun !
George ! George !
Brian is just telling George about the five shillings he 's got in the
Post Office . . . . George !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: from the terraceComing !

div.stage: He hurries in , the model husband , BRIAN follows .

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Oh , George , just hang these up for me , will you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , darling . I 'll get the steps from the library .

div.stage: He hurries out .
BRIAN takes out his sketching block . It is obvious that his five shillings has turned the scale . He bows to DINAH . He kisses OLIVIA 'S hand with an air . He motions to DINAH to be seated .

sp.speaker: DINAH
sp.p: impressedWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: BRIAN
sp.p: beginning to drawPortrait of Lady Strange .

div.stage: GEORGE hurries in with the steps , and gets to work . There is a great deal of curtain , and for the moment he becomes slightly involved in it . However , by draping it over his head and shoulders , he manages to get successfully up the steps . There we may leave him .

But we have not quite finished with MR. PIM . It is a matter of honour with him now that he should get his little story quite accurate before passing out of the MARDENS ’ life for ever . So he comes back for the last time ; for the last time we see his head at the window . He whispers to OLIVIA .

lg.l: PIM . Mrs. Marden ! I 've just remembered . His name was Ernest
Polwittle — not Henry .

div.stage: He goes off happily . A curious family the MARDENS . Perhaps somebody else would have committed bigamy if he had not remembered in time that it was Ernest . . . . Ernest . . . . Yes . . . . Now he can go back with an easy conscience to the Trevors .

docTitle.titlePart: THE CAMBERLEY TRIANGLE A COMEDY IN ONE ACT

body.stage: This play was first produced by Mr. Godfrey Tearle at the Coliseum on September 8 , 1919 , with the following cast :
Dennis Camberley — GODFREY TEARLE . Kate Camberley — MARY MALONE . Cyril Norwood — EWAN BROOK .
THE CAMBERLEY TRIANGLE
It is an evening of 1919 in KATE 'S drawing-room . She is expecting him , and the Curtain goes up as he is announced .

sp.speaker: MAID
sp.p: Mr. Cyril Norwood .

body.stage: He comes in .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: for the MAID 'S benefit , but you may be sure she knowsAh , good evening , Mrs. Camberley !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Good evening !

body.stage: They shake hands . NORWOOD is sleek and prosperous , in a morning coat with a white slip to his waistcoat . He is good-looking in rather an obvious way with rather an obvious moustache . Most women like him — at least , so he will tell you .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: as soon as they are aloneMy darling !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Cyril !

body.stage: He takes her hands and kisses them . He would kiss her face , but she is not quite ready for this .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You let me yesterday . Why may n't I kiss you to-day ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Not just yet , dear . I want to talk to you . Come and sit down .

body.stage: They sit on the sofa together .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You are n't sorry for what you said yesterday ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: looking at him thoughtfully , and then shaking her headNo .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Then what 's happened ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I 've just had a letter from Dennis .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: anxiouslyDennis — your husband ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Where does he write from ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: India .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Oh , well !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: He says I may expect him home almost as soon as I get the letter .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Good Heavens !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Yes . . . .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: always hopefulPerhaps he did n't catch the boat that he expected to . Would n't he have cabled from somewhere on the way ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You can n't depend on cables nowadays . I do n't know — What are we to do , Cyril ?

lg.l: You know what I always wanted you to do .
Come away with me .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: doubtfullyAnd let Dennis come home and find — an empty house ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: eagerlyYou are nothing to him , and he is nothing to you . A war-wedding !— after you 'd been engaged to each other for a week ! And forty-eight hours afterwards he is sent out to India — and you have n't seen him since .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Yes . I keep telling myself that .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: The world may say that you 're his wife and he 's your husband , but — what do you know of him ? He wo n't even be the boy you married . He 'll be a stranger whom you 'll hardly recognise . And you are n't the girl he married . You 're a woman now , and you 're just beginning to learn what love is . Come with me .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: It 's true , it 's true . But he has been fighting for us . And to come home again after those four years of exile , and find —

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Exile — that 's making much too much of it . He 's come through the war safely , and he 's probably had what he 'd call a topping good time . Like enough he 's been in love half-a-dozen times himself since — on leave in India and that sort of thing . India ! Well , you should read Kipling .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I wonder . Of course , as you say , I do n't know him . But I feel that we should be happier afterwards if we were quite straight about it and told him just what had happened . If he had been doing what you say , he would understand — and perhaps be glad of it .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: uneasilyReally , darling , it 's hardly a thing you can talk over calmly with a husband , even if he — We do n't want any unpleasantness , and — er —Taking her hands againBesides , I want you , Kate . It may be weeks before he comes back . We can n't go on like this . . . Kate !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Do you love me so very much ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: My darling !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Well , let us wait till the end of the week — in case he comes . I do n't want to seem to be afraid of him .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: eagerlyAnd then ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Then I 'll come with you .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: taking her in his armsMy darling ! . . . There ! And now what are you going to do ? Ask me to stay to dinner or what ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Certainly not , sir . I 'm going out to dinner to-night .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: jealouslyWho with ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: eagerlyAt our little restaurant ?She nodsGood girl ! Then go and put on a hat , while I ring ‘ em up and see if they 've got a table .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What fun ! I wo n't be a moment .She goes to the doorCyril , you will always love me ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Of course I will , darling .She nods at him and goes out . He is very well pleased with himself when he is left alone . He goes to the telephone with a smileGerrard 11 , 001 . Yes . . . I want a table for two . To-night . . . Mr. Cyril Norwood . . . Oh , in about half an hour . . . Yes , for two . Is that all right ? . . . Thank you .

body.stage: He puts the receiver back and turns round to see DENNIS CAMBERLEY , who has just come in . DENNIS is certainly a man now ; very easily and pleasantly master of himself and of anybody else who gets in his way .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: surprisedHallo !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: nodding pleasantlyHallo !

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: wondering who he isYou — er ——?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I just came in , Mr. Norwood .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You know my name ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Oh yes , I 've heard a good deal about you , Mr. Cyril Norwood .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: stifflyI do n't think I 've had the pleasure of — er ——

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: winninglyOh , but I 'm sure you must have heard a good deal about me .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Good God , you do n't mean ——

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I do , indeed .With a bowDennis Camberley , the missing husband .PleadinglyYou have heard about me , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I — er — Mr. Camberley , yes , of course . So you 're back ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Yes , I 'm back . Sometimes they do n't come back , Mr. Norwood , and sometimes — they do . . . . Even after four years . . . . But you did talk about me sometimes ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: How did you know my name ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: A little bird told me about you .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: turning away in angerPooh !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: One of those little Eastern birds , which sit on the backs of crocodiles , searching for — well , let us say , breakfast . He said to me one morning : “ Talking of parasites , ” he said , “ do you know Mr. Cyril Norwood ? ” he said , “ because I could tell you an interesting story about him , ” he said , “ if you care to — ”

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: wheeling round furiouslyLook here , sir , we 'd better have it out quite plainly . I do n't want any veiled insults and sneers from you . I admit that an unfortunate situation has arisen , but we must look facts in the face . You may be Mrs. Camberley 's husband , but she has not seen you for four years , and — well , she and I love each other . There you have it . What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: anxiouslyYou do n't feel that I have neglected her , Mr. Norwood ? You see , I could n't come home for week-ends very well , and —

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: pleasantlyWell , what do you suggest ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: taken abackReally , sir , I — er —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You see , I feel so out of it all . I 've been leading such a nasty , uncivilised life for the last four years , I really hardly know what is — what is being done . Now you have been mixing in Society . . . making munitions . . .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: stifflyI have been engaged on important work for the Government of a confidential nature —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You , as I was saying , have been mixing in Society , engaged on important work for the Government of a confidential nature ——

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: It was my great regret that I had no opportunity of enlisting ——

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: With no opportunity , as I was about to say , of enlisting , but with many opportunities , fortunately , of making love to my wife .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Now look here , Mr. Camberley , I 've already told you ——

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: soothing himBut , my dear Mr. Norwood , I 'm only doing what you said . I 'm looking facts in the face .SurprisedYou are n't ashamed of having made love to my wife , are you ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: impatientlyWhat are you going to do ? That 's all that matters between you and me . What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Well , that was what I was going to ask you . You 're so much more in the swim than I am .EarnestlyWhat is being done in Society just now ? You must have heard a good deal of gossip about it . All your friends , who were also engaged on important work of a confidential nature , with no opportunity of enlisting — do n't they tell you their own experiences ? What have the husbands been doing lately when they came back from the front ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: advancing on him angrilyNow , once and for all , sir ——

body.stage: KATE comes in , with a hat in each hand , calling to NORWOOD as she comes .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Oh , Cyril — which of these two hats —she sees her husband— Dennis !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: looking at her steadfastlyHow are you , Kate ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: stammeringYou 've — you 've come back ?She puts the hats down .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I 've come back . As I was telling Mr. Norwood .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: looking from one to the otherYou —?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: smilingOh , we 're quite old friends .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: going to herI 've told him , Kate .

body.stage: He takes her hands , and tries to look defiantly at DENNIS , though he is not feeling like that at all .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: looking anxiously at DENNISWhat are you going to do ?

body.stage: She can hardly make him out . He is different from the husband who left her four years ago .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Well , that 's what Cyril keeps asking me .to NORWOODYou do n't mind my calling you Cyril ?— such an old friend of my wife 's —

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: unable to make him outDennis !She is frightened .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: soothinglyIt 's all right , dear .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Do let 's sit down and talk it over in a friendly way .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: going to himDennis , can you ever forgive me ? We never ought to have got married — we knew each other so little — you had to go away so soon — I — I was going to write and tell you — oh , I wish —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: That 's all right , Kate .He will not let her come too close to him . He steps back and looks at her from head to feetYou 've altered .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: That 's just it , Dennis . I 'm not the girl who —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You 've grown four years younger and four years prettier .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: dropping her eyesHave I ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Yes . . . . You do your hair a new way .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: surprisedDo you like it ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I love it .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: coughingYes , well , perhaps we 'd better —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: with a startI beg your pardon , Cyril . I was forgetting you for the moment . Well , now do sit down ,NORWOOD and KATE sit down together on the sofa , but DENNIS remains standingThat 's right .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: to KATEYou want to marry him , eh ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: We have already told you the circumstances , Mr. Camberley . I need hardly say how regrettable it is that — er — but at the same time these — er — things will happen , and since it — er — has happened —

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I feel I hardly know you , Dennis . Did I love you when I married you ? I do n't know . It was so sudden . We had no time to find out anything about each other . And now you come back — a stranger —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: jerking his head at NORWOODAnd he 's not a stranger , eh ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: dropping her eyesN-no .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You feel you know all about him ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I — we —She is unhappy .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: We have discovered that we love each other .Taking her handsMy darling one , this is distressing for you . Let me —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: sharplyIt would n't be distressing for her , if you did n't keep messing her about . Why the devil can n't you sit on a chair by yourself ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: indignantlyReally !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: freeing herself from him , and moving to the extreme end of the sofaWhat are you going to do , Dennis ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: looking at them thoughtfully , his chin on his handI do n't know . . . . It 's difficult . I do n't want to do anything melodramatic . I meanto KATEit would n't really help matters if I did shoot him , would it ?

body.stage: KATE looks at him without saying anything , trying to understand this new man who has come into her life . NORWOOD swallows , and tries very hard to say something

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I — I —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: turning to himYou do n't think so , do you ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I — I —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: No , I 'm quite sure you 're right . It would n't really help . It is difficult , is n't it ? You seeto KATEyou love him —he waits a moment for her to say it if she will , but she only looks at him— and he says he loves you , but at the same time I am your husband . . . .He walks up and down thoughtfully , and then says suddenly to NORWOODI 'll tell you what — I 'll fight you for her .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: trying to be firmI think we 'd better leave this eighteenth-century nonsense out of it .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: pleasantlyThey fight in the twentieth century , too , Mr. Norwood . Perhaps you had n't heard what we 've been doing these last four years ? Oh , quite a lot of it . . . . Well ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You do n't wish me to believe that you 're serious ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Perfectly . Swords , pistols , fists , catch-as-catch-can — what would you like ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I do not propose to indulge in an undignified scuffle for the — er — lady of my heart .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: cheerfullyNothing doing in scuffles , eh ? All right , then , I 'll toss you for her .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Now you 're merely being vulgar .to KATEMy dear —

body.stage: She motions him back with her hand , but does not take her eyes off DENNIS .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Really , Mr. Norwood , you 're a little hard to please . If you do n't like my suggestions , perhaps you will make one of your own .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: This is obviously a matter in which it is for the — er — lady to choose .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You think Mrs. Camberley should choose between us ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: What do you say , Kate ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You are very generous , Dennis .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: after a pauseVery well , you shall choose .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: complacentlyAh !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Wait a moment , Mr. Norwood .to KATEWhen did you first meet him ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: A year ago .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: And he 's been making love to you for a year ?KATE bends her headHe 's been making love to you for a year ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I think , sir , that the sooner the lady makes her choice , and brings this distressing scene to a close — After all , is it fair to her to —?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Are you fair to me ? You 've been making love to her for a year . I made love to her for a fort-night — four years ago . And now you want her to choose between us . Is that fair ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You hardly expect us to wait a year before she is allowed to make up her mind ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I waited four years for her out there . . . . However , I wo n't ask you to wait a year . I 'll ask you to wait for five minutes .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What is it you want us to do , Dennis ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I want you to listen to both of us , for five minutes each ; that 's all . After all , we 're your suitors , are n't we ? You 're going to choose between us . Very well , then , you must hear what we have to say . Mr. Norwood shall have five minutes alone with you in which to present his case ; five minutes in which to tell you how beautiful you are . . . . and how rich he is . . . and how happy you 'll be together . And I shall have my five minutes .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: sneeringFive minutes in which to tell her lies about me , eh ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Damn it , you 've had a whole year in which to tell her lies about yourself ; you ought n't to grudge me five minutes .to KATEWell ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I agree , Dennis .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Good .He spins a coin , puts it on the back of his hand , and says to NORWOODCall !

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: What on earth —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Choice of innings .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I never heard of anything so — Tails .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: uncovering itHeads . You shall have first knock .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: bewilderedWhat do you — I do n't —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You have five minutes in which to lay your case before Mrs. Camberley .He looks at his watchFive minutes — and then I shall come back . . . . Is there a fire in the dining-room , Kate ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: smiling in spite of herselfA gas-fire ; it is n't lit .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Then I shall light it .to NORWOODThat will make the room nice and warm for you by the time you 've finished .He goes to the door and says againFive minutes .

body.stage: There is an awkward silence after he is gone . KATE waits for NORWOOD to say something , but NORWOOD does n't know in the least what is expected of him .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: looking anxiously at the doorWhat 's the fellow 's game , eh ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Game ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Yes . What 's he up to ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Is he up to anything ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I do n't like it . Why the devil did he choose to-day to come back ? If he 'd waited another week , we 'd have been safely away together . What 's his game , I wonder ?

body.stage: He walks up and down , worrying it out .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I do n't think he 's playing a game . He 's just giving me my chance .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: What chance ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: A chance to decide between you .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: You 've decided that , Kate . You 've had a year to think about it in , and you 've decided . We love each other ; you 're coming away with me ; that 's all settled . Only . . . what the deuce is he up to ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: sitting down and talking to herselfYou 're quite right about my not knowing him . . . . How one rushed into marriage in those early days of the war — knowing nothing about each other . And then they come back , and even the little one thought one did know is different . . . . I suppose he feels the same about me .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: to himselfDamn him !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: after a pauseWell , Cyril ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: looking sharply round at herWell ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: We have n't got very long .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: looking at his watchHe really means to come back — in five minutes ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You heard him say so .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: going up to her and speaking eagerlyWhat 's the matter with slipping out now ? You 've got a hat here . We can slip out quietly . He wo n't hear us . He 'll come back and find us gone — well , what can he do ? Probably he 'll hang about for a bit and then go to his club . We 'll have a bit of dinner ; ring up your maid ; get her to meet you with some things , and go off by the night mail . Scotland — anywhere you like . Let the whole business simmer down a bit . We do n't want any melodramatic eighteenth-century nonsense .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Go out now , and not wait for him to have his five minutes ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: impatientlyWhat does he want with five minutes ? What 's the good of it to him ? Just to take a pathetic farewell of you , and pretend that you 've ruined his life , when all the time he 's chuckling in his sleeve at having got rid of you so easily . I know these young fellows . Some Major 's wife in India is what he 's got his eye on . . . . Or else he 'll try fooling around with the hands-up business . You do n't want to be mixed up with any scandal of that sort . No , the best thing we can do — I 'm speaking for your sake , Kate — is to slip off quietly , while we 've got the chance . We can write and explain all that we want to explain .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: looking wonderingly at him — another man whom she does n't knowIs that playing quite fair to Dennis ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Good Lord , this is n't a game ! Camberley may think so with his tossing-up and all the rest of it , but you and I are n't children . Everything 's fair in a case like this . Put your hat on — quickly —he gets it for her— here you are —

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: standing upI 'm not sure , Cyril .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: What d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: He expects me to wait for him .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: If it comes to that , he expected you to wait for him four years ago .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Yes . . . .QuietlyThank you for reminding me .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Kate , do n't be stupid . What 's happened to you ? Of course , I know it 's been beastly upsetting for you , all this — but then , why do you want to go on with it ? Why do you want more upsetting scenes ? You 've got a chance now of getting out of it all , and —He looks at his watchGood Lord !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Is the five minutes over ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Quick , quick !He puts his fingers to his lipsQuietly .He walks on tiptoe to the door .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Cyril !

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: H'sh !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: sitting down againIt 's no good , Cyril , I must wait for him .

body.stage: The door opens , and NORWOOD starts back quickly as DENNIS comes in .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: looking at his watchInnings declared closed .to NORWOODThe dining-room is nicely warmed now , and I 've left you an evening paper .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: going to KATELook here , Mr. Camberley , Kate and I —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Mrs. Camberley , no doubt , will tell me .

body.stage: He holds the door open and waits politely for NORWOOD to go .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: I do n't know what your game is —

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You 've never been in Mesopotamia , Mr. Norwood ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: It 's a very trying place for the temper . . . . I 'm waiting for you .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: irresoluteWell , I ——He comes sulkily to the doorWell , I shall come back for Kate in five minutes .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Mrs. Camberley and I will be ready for you . You know your way ?

body.stage: NORWOOD goes out .
DENNIS shuts the door . He comes into the room and stands looking at KATE .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: uncomfortablyWell ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: No , do n't move . I just want to look at you . . . . I 've seen you like that for four years . Do n't move . . . . I 've been in some dreary places , but you 've been with me most of the time . Just let 's have a last look .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: A last look ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You 're saying good-bye to me ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I do n't know whether it 's to you , Kate . To the girl who has been with me these last four years . Was that you ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: dropping her eyesI do n't know , Dennis .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I wish to God I was n't your husband .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What would you do if you were n't my husband ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Make love to you .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Ca n't you do that now ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Being your husband rather handicaps me , you know . I never really stood a chance against the other fellow .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: I was to choose between you , you said . You think that I have already made up my mind ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: smilingI think so .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: And chosen him ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: shaking his headOh , no !

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: surprisedYou think I have chosen you ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: noddingM 'm .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: indignantlyReally , Dennis ! Considering that I had practically arranged to run away with him twenty minutes ago ! You must think me very fickle .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Not fickle . Imaginative .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What do you mean ? And why are you so certain that I am going to choose you ? And why in that case did you talk about taking a last look at me ? And what —?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Of course , we 've only got five minutes , but I think that if you asked your questions one at a time ——

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: smilingWell , you need n't answer them all together .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: All right then , one at a time . Why am I certain that you will choose me ? Because for the first time in your life you have just been alone with Mr. Cyril Norwood . That 's what I meant by saying you were imaginative . The Norwood you 've been thinking yourself in love with does n't exist . I 'm certain that you 've seen him for the first time in these last few minutes . Why , the Archangel Gabriel would have made a hash of a five minutes like that ; it would have been impossible for him to have said the right thing to you . Norwood ? Good Lord , he did n't stand a chance . You were judging him all the time , were n't you ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: thoughtfullyYou 're very clever , Dennis .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: cheerfullyFour years ’ study of the Turkish character .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: But how do you know I 'm not judging you all the time ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Of course you are . But there 's all the difference in the world between judging a stranger like me , and judging the man you thought you were in love with .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You are a stranger to me .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I know . That 's why I said good-bye to the girl who had been with me these last four years , the girl I had married . Well , I 've said good-bye to her . You 're not my wife any longer , Kate ; but if you do n't mind pretending that I 'm not your husband , and just give me a chance of making love to you — well , that 's all I want .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: You 're very generous , Dennis .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: No , I 'm not . I 'm very much in love ; and for a man very much in love I 'm being rather less of a silly ass than usual . Why should you love me ? You fell in love with my uniform at the beginning of the war . I was ordered out , and you fell in love with the departing hero . After that ? Well , I had four years — alone — in which to think about you , and you had four years — with other men — in which to forget me . Is it any wonder that —?

body.stage: NORWOOD comes in .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: roughlyWell ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: You arrive just in time , Mr. Norwood . I was talking too much .to KATEMrs. Camberley , we are both at your disposal . Will you choose between us , which one is to have the happiness of — serving you ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: holding out his hand to her , and speaking in the voice of the proprietorKate !

body.stage: KATE goes slowly up to him with her hand held out .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: shaking NORWOOD 'S handGood-bye , Mr. Norwood .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: astoundedKate !to DENNISYou devil !

lg.l: And only a moment ago I was comparing you to the Archangel
Gabriel .

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: sneeringly to KATESo you 're going to be a loving wife to him after all ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: tapping him kindly on the shoulderYou 'll remember what I said about Mesopotamia ?

sp.speaker: NORWOOD
sp.p: pulling himself together hastilyGood-bye , Mrs. Camberley . I can only hope that you will be happy .

body.stage: He goes out with dignity .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: closing the doorWell , there we agree .

body.stage: He comes back to her .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: What a stupid little fool I have been .She holds out her arms to himDennis !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: retreating in mock alarmOh no , you do n't !He shakes a finger at herWe 're not going to rush it this time .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: reproachfullyDennis !

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: I think you should call me Mr. Camberley .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: with a smileMr. Camberley .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: That 's better . Now our courtship begins .Bowing lowMadam , will you do me the great honour of dining with me this evening ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: curtseyingI shall be charmed .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Then let us hasten . The carriage waits .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: holding up the two hatsWhich of these two chapeaux do you prefer , Mr. Camberley ?

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Might I express a preference for the black one with the pink roses ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: It is very elegant , is it not ?She puts it on .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: Vastly becoming , upon my life . . . . I might mention that I am staying at the club . Is your ladyship doing anything to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Nothing of any great importance .

body.stage: He offers his arm and she takes it .

sp.speaker: DENNIS
sp.p: as they go to the doorThen perhaps I may be permitted to call round to-morrow morning about eleven , and make inquiries as to your ladyship 's health .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: It would be very obliging of you , sir .

body.stage: They go out together .

docTitle.titlePart: THE ROMANTIC AGE A COMEDY IN THREE ACTS

body.stage: ACT I The hall of MR. KNOWLE 'S house . Evening .
ACT II A glade in the wood . Morning .

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: The hall again . Afternoon .
This play was first produced by Mr. Arthur Wontner at the Comedy Theatre on October 18 , 1920 , with the following cast :

Henry Knowle — A. BROMLEY-DAVENPORT . Mary Knowle — LOTTIE VENNE . Melisande — BARBARA HOFFE . Jane — DOROTHY TETLEY . Bobby — JOHN WILLIAMS . Gervase Mallory — ARTHUR WONTNER . Ern — ROY LENNOL . Gentleman Susan — H. O . NICHOLSON . Alice — IRENE RATHBONE .

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: We are looking at the inner hall of MR. HENRY KNOWLE 'S country house , at about 9. 15 of a June evening . There are doors R. and L .— on the right leading to the drawing-room , on the left to the entrance hall , the dining-room and the library . At the back are windows — French windows on the right , then an interval of wall , then casement windows .

MRS. HENRY KNOWLE , her daughter , MELISANDE , and her niece , JANE BAGOT , are waiting for their coffee , MRS. KNOWLE , short and stoutish , is reclining on the sofa ; JANE , pleasant-looking and rather obviously pretty , is sitting in a chair near her , glancing at a book ; MELISANDE , the beautiful , the romantic , is standing by the open French windows , gazing into the night .

ALICE , the parlourmaid , comes in with the coffee . She stands in front of MRS. KNOWLE , a little embarrassed because MRS. KNOWLE 'S eyes are closed . She waits there until JANE looks up from her book .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Aunt Mary , dear , are you having coffee ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEopening her eyes with a startCoffee . Oh , yes , coffee . Jane , put the milk in for me . And no sugar . Dr. Anderson is very firm about that . “ No sugar , Mrs. Knowle , ” he said . “ Oh , Dr. Anderson ! ” I said .

div.stage: ALICE has taken the tray to JANE , who pours out her own and her aunt 's coffee , and takes her cup off the tray .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: ALICE takes the tray to MRS. KNOWLE .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you .

div.stage: ALICE goes over to MELISANDE , who says nothing , but waves her away .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEas soon as ALICE is goneJane !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , Aunt Mary ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Was my mouth open ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , no , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah , I 'm glad of that . It 's so bad for the servants .She finishes her coffee .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: getting upShall I put it down for you ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you , dear .

div.stage: JANE puts the two cups down and goes back to her book . MRS. KNOWLE fidgets a little on her sofa .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Sandy !There is no answerSandy !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Melisande !

div.stage: MELISANDE turns round and comes slowly towards her mother .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Did you call me , Mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Three times , darling . Did n't you hear me ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I am sorry , Mother , I was thinking of other things .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . You think too much , dear . You remember what the great poet tells us . “ Do noble things , not dream them all day long . ” Tennyson , was n't it ? I know I wrote it in your album for you when you were a little girl . It 's so true .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Kingsley , Mother , not Tennyson .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: noddingKingsley , that 's right .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , it 's the same thing . I know when my mother used to call me I used to come running up , saying , “ What is it , Mummy , darling ? ” And even if it was anything upstairs , like a handkerchief or a pair of socks to be mended , I used to trot off happily , saying to myself , “ Do noble things , not dream them all day long . ”

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I am sorry , Mother . What is the noble thing you want doing ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well now , you see , I 've forgotten . If only you 'd come at once , dear —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I was looking out into the night . It 's a wonderful night . Midsummer Night .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Midsummer Night . And now I suppose the days will start drawing in , and we shall have winter upon us before we know where we are . All these changes of the seasons are very inconsiderate to an invalid . Ah , now I remember what I wanted , dear . Can you find me another cushion ? Dr. Anderson considers it most important that the small of the back should be well supported after a meal .Indicating the placeJust here , dear .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: jumping up with the cushion from her chairLet me , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you , Jane . Just here , please .JANE arranges it .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Is that right ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you , dear . I only do it for Dr. Anderson 's sake .

div.stage: JANE goes back to her book and MELISANDE goes back to her Midsummer Night . There is silence for a little .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Oh , Sandy . . . Sandy !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Melisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: coming patiently down to themYes , Mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Oh , Sandy , I 've just remembered —MELISANDE shudders .What is it , darling child ? Are you cold ? That comes of standing by the open window in a treacherous climate like this . Close the window and come and sit down properly .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: It 's a wonderful night , Mother . Midsummer Night . I 'm not cold .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . But you shuddered . I distinctly saw you shudder . Did n't you see her , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I 'm afraid I was n't looking , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I did n't shudder because I was cold . I shuddered because you will keep calling me by that horrible name . I shudder every time I hear it .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEsurprisedWhat name , Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: There it is again . Oh , why did you christen me by such a wonderful , beautiful , magical name as Melisande , if you were going to call me Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , dear , as I think I 've told you , that was a mistake of your father 's . I suppose he got it out of some book . I should certainly never have agreed to it , if I had heard him distinctly . I thought he said Millicent — after your Aunt Milly . And not being very well at the time , and leaving it all to him , I never really knew about it until it was too late to do anything . I did say to your father , “ Ca n't we christen her again ? ” But there was nothing in the prayer book about it except “ riper years , ” and nobody seemed to know when riper years began . Besides , we were all calling you Sandy then . I think Sandy is a very pretty name , do n't you , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , but do n't you think Melisande is beautiful , Aunt Mary ? I mean really beautiful .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , it never seems to me quite respectable , not for a nicely-brought-up young girl in a Christian house . It makes me think of the sort of person who meets a strange young man to whom she has never been introduced , and talks to him in a forest with her hair coming down . They find her afterwards floating in a pool . Not at all the thing one wants for one 's daughter .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , but how thrilling it sounds !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , I think you are safer with “ Jane , ” dear . Your mother knew what she was about . And if I can save my only child from floating in a pool by calling her Sandy , I certainly think it is my duty to do so .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: to her self ecstaticallyMelisande !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEto MELISANDEOh , and talking about floating in a pool reminds me about the bread-sauce at dinner to-night . You heard what your father said ? You must give cook a good talking to in the morning . She has been getting very careless lately . I do n't know what 's come over her .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I 've come over her . When you were over her , everything was all right . You know all about housekeeping ; you take an interest in it . I do n't . I hate it . How can you expect the house to be run properly when they all know I hate it ? Why did you ever give it up and make me do it when you know how I hate it ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , you must learn not to hate it . I 'm sure Jane here does n't hate it , and her mother is always telling me what a great help she is .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: warninglyIt 's no good your saying you like it , Jane , after what you told me yesterday .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I do n't like it , but it does n't make me miserable doing it . But then I 'm different . I 'm not romantic like Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: One does n't need to be very romantic not to want to talk about bread-sauce . Bread-sauce on a night like this !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , I 'm only thinking of you , Sandy , not of myself . If I thought about myself I should disregard all the warnings that Dr. Anderson keeps giving me , and I should insist on doing the housekeeping just as I always used to . But I have to think of you . I want to see you married to some nice , steady young man before I die — my handkerchief , Jane —JANE gets up and gives her her handkerchief from the other end of the sofa— before I dieshe touches her eyes with her handkerchief, and no nice young man will want to marry you , if you have n't learnt how to look after his house for him .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: contemptuouslyIf that 's marriage , I shall never get married .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: shockedMelisande , darling !

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Dr. Anderson was saying , only yesterday , trying to make me more cheerful , “ Why , Mrs. Knowle , ” he said , “ you 'll live another hundred years yet . ” “ Dr. Anderson , ” I said , “ I do n't want to live another hundred years . I only want to live until my dear daughter , Melisande ” — I did n't say Sandy to him because it seemed rather familiar — “ I only want to live until my daughter Melisande is happily married to some nice , steady young man . Do this for me , Dr. Anderson , ” I said , “ and I shall be your lifelong debtor . ” He promised to do his best . It was then that he mentioned about the cushion in the small of the back after meals . And so do n't forget to tell cook about the bread-sauce , will you , dear ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I will tell her , Mother .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . That 's right . I like a man to be interested in his food . I hope both your husbands , Sandy and Jane , will take a proper interest in what they eat . You will find that , after you have been married some years , and told each other everything you did and saw before you met , there is n't really anything to talk about at meals except food . And you must talk ; I hope you will both remember that . Nothing breaks up the home so quickly as silent meals . Of course , breakfast does n't matter , because he has his paper then ; and after you have said , “ Is there anything in the paper , dear ? ” and he has said , “ No , ” then he does n't expect anything more . I wonder sometimes why they go on printing the newspapers . I 've been married twenty years , and there has never been anything in the paper yet .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , Mother , I hate to hear you talking about marriage like that . Was n't there ever any kind of romance between you and Father ? Not even when he was wooing you ? Was n't there ever one magic Midsummer morning when you saw suddenly “ a livelier emerald twinkle in the grass , a purer sapphire melt into the sea ” ? Was n't there ever one passionate ecstatic moment when “ once he drew with one long kiss my whole soul through my lips , as sunlight drinketh dew ” ? Or did you talk about bread-sauce all the time ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: eagerlyTell us about it , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , dear , there is n't very much to tell . I am quite sure that we never drank dew together , or anything like that , as Sandy suggests , and it was n't by the sea at all , it was at Surbiton . He used to come down from London with his racquet and play tennis with us . And then he would stay on to supper sometimes , and then after supper we would go into the garden together — it was quite dark then , but everything smelt so beautifully , I shall always remember it — and we talked , oh , I do n't know what about , but I knew somehow that I should marry him one day . I do n't think he knew — he was n't sure — and then he came to a subscription dance one evening — I think Mother , your grandmother , guessed that that was to be my great evening , because she was very particular about my dress , and I remember she sent me upstairs again before we started , because I had n't got the right pair of shoes on — rather a tight pair — however , I put them on . And there was a hansom outside the hall , and it was our last dance together , and he said , “ Shall we sit it out , Miss Bagot ? ” Well , of course , I was only too glad to , and we sat it out in the hansom , driving all round Surbiton , and what your grandmother would have said I do n't know , but , of course , I never told her . And when we got home after the dance , I went up to her room — as soon as I 'd got my shoes off — and said , “ Mother , I have some wonderful news for you , ” and she said , “ Not Mr. Knowle — Henry ? ” and I said , “ ‘ M , ” rather bright-eyed you know , and wanting to cry . And she said , “ Oh , my darling child ! ” and — Jane , where 's my handkerchief ?It has dropped off the sofa and JANE picks it upThank you , dear .She dabs her eyesWell , that 's really all , you know , except that —she dabs her eyes again— I 'm afraid I 'm feeling rather overcome . I 'm sure Dr. Anderson would say it was very bad for me to feel overcome . Your poor dear grandmother . Jane , dear , why did you ask me to tell you all this ? I must go away and compose myself before your uncle and Mr. Coote come in . I do n't know what I should do if Mr. Coote saw me like this .She begins to get upAnd after calling me a Spartan Mother only yesterday , because I said that if any nice , steady young man came along and took my own dear little girl away from me , I should bear the terrible wrench in silence rather than cause either of them a moment 's remorse .She is up nowThere !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Shall I come with you ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . No , dear , not just now . Let me be by myself for a little .She turns back suddenly at the doorOh ! Perhaps later on , when the men come from the dining-room , dear Jane , you might join me , with your Uncle Henry — if the opportunity occurs . . . . But only if it occurs , of course .

div.stage: She goes .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: coming back to the sofaPoor Aunt Mary ! It always seems so queer that one 's mother and aunts and people should have had their romances too .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Do you call that romance , Jane ? Tennis and subscription dances and wearing tight shoes ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyWell , no , darling , not romance of course , but you know what I mean .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Just think of the commonplace little story which mother has just told us , and compare it with any of the love-stories of history . Is n't it pitiful , Jane , that people should be satisfied now with so little ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , darling , very , very sad , but I do n't think Aunt Mary —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I am not blaming Mother . It is the same almost everywhere nowadays . There is no romance left .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: No , darling . Of course , I am not romantic like you , but I do agree with you . It is very sad . Somehow there is no —she searches for the right word— no romance left .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Just think of the average marriage . It makes one shudder .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: doing her bestPositively shudder !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: He meets Her at —she shudders— a subscription dance , or a tennis party —she shudders againor — at golf . He calls upon her mother — perhaps in a top hat — perhapstragicallyeven in a bowler hat .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: A bowler hat ! One shudders .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Her mother makes tactful inquiries about his income — discovers that he is a nice , steady young man — and decides that he shall marry her daughter . He is asked to come again , he is invited to parties ; it is understood that he is falling in love with the daughter . The rest of the family are encouraged to leave them alone together — if the opportunity occurs , Jane .ContemptuouslyBut , of course , only if it occurs .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyYes , dear .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: One day he proposes to her .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: to herself ecstaticallyOh !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: He stutters out a few unbeautiful words which she takes to be a proposal . She goes and tells Mother . He goes and tells Father . They are engaged . They talk about each other as “ my fiancé . ” Perhaps they are engaged for months and months —

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Years and years sometimes , Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: For years and years — and wherever they go , people make silly little jokes about them , and cough very loudly if they go into a room where the two of them are . And then they get married at last , and everybody comes and watches them get married , and makes more silly jokes , and they go away for what they call a honeymoon , and they tell everybody — they shout it out in the newspapers — where they are going for their honeymoon ; and then they come back and start talking about bread-sauce . Oh , Jane , it 's horrible .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Horrible , darling .With a French airBut what would you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: in a low thrilling voiceWhat would I ? Ah , what would I , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Because you see , Sandy — I mean Melisande — you see , darling , this is the twentieth century , and —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Sometimes I see him clothed in mail , riding beneath my lattice window . All in the blue unclouded weather Thick-jewelled shone the saddle leather , The helmet and the helmet feather Burned like one burning flame together , As he rode down to Camelot . And from his blazoned baldric slung A mighty silver bugle hung , And as he rode his armour rung As he rode down to Camelot .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I know , dear . But of course they do n't nowadays .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And as he rides beneath my room , singing to himself , I wave one lily hand to him from my lattice , and toss him down a gage , a gage for him to wear in his helm , a rose — perhaps just a rose .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awedNo , Melisande , would you really ? Wave a lily hand to him ?She waves oneI mean , would n't it be rather — you know . Rather forward .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Forward !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: upsetWell , I mean — Well , of course , I suppose it was different in those days .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How else could he know that I loved him ? How else could he wear my gage in his helm when he rode to battle ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Well , of course , there is that .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And then when he has slain his enemies in battle , he comes back to me . I knot my sheets together so as to form a rope — for I have been immured in my room — and I let myself down to him . He places me on the saddle in front of him , and we ride forth together into the world — together for always !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: a little uncomfortablyYou do get married , I suppose , darling , or do you — er —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: We stop at a little hermitage on the way , and a good priest marries us .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: relieved .Ah , yes .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And sometimes he is not in armour . He is a prince from Fairyland . My father is king of a neighbouring country , a country which is sorely troubled by a dragon .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: By a what , dear ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: A dragon .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , yes , of course .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: The king , my father , offers my hand and half his kingdom to anybody who will slay the monster . A prince who happens to be passing through the country essays the adventure . Alas , the dragon devours him .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , Melisande , that is n't the one ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: My eyes have barely rested upon him . He has aroused no emotion in my heart .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so glad .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Another prince steps forward . Impetuously he rushes upon the fiery monster . Alas , he likewise is consumed .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: sympathetically .Poor fellow

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And then one evening a beautiful and modest youth in blue and gold appears at my father 's court , and begs that he too be allowed to try his fortune with the dragon . Passing through the great hall on my way to my bed-chamber , I see him suddenly . Our eyes meet . . . . Oh , Jane !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Darling ! . . . You ought to have lived in those days , Melisande . They would have suited you so well .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Will they never come back again ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Well , I do n't quite see how they can . People do n't dress in blue and gold nowadays . I mean men .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: No .She sighsWell , I suppose I shall never marry .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Of course , I 'm not romantic like you , darling , and I do n't have time to read all the wonderful books you read , and though I quite agree with everything you say , and of course it must have been thrilling to have lived in those wonderful old days , still here we are , andwith a wave of the hand— and what I mean is — here we are .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You are content to put romance out of your life , and to make the ordinary commonplace marriage ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: What I mean is , that it would n't be commonplace if it was the right man . Some nice , clean-looking Englishman — I do n't say beautiful — pleasant , and good at games , dependable , not very clever perhaps , but making enough money ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: carelesslyIt sounds rather like Bobby .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: confusedIt is n't like Bobby , or any one else particularly . It 's just anybody . It was n't any particular person . I was just describing the sort of man without thinking of any one in ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: All right , dear , all right .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Besides , we all know Bobby 's devoted to you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: firmlyNow , look here , Jane , I warn you solemnly that if you think you are going to leave me and Bobby alone together this evening ——Voices are heard outside .Well , I warn you .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: in a whisperOf course not , darling .With perfect tactAnd , as I was saying , Melisande , it was quite the most —— Ah , here you are at last ! We wondered what had happened to you !

div.stage: Enter BOBBY and MR. KNOWLE . JANE has already described BOBBY for us . MR. KNOWLE is a pleasant , middle-aged man with a sense of humour , which he cultivates for his own amusement entirely .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Were you very miserable without us ?He goes towards them .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: laughingVery .

div.stage: MELISANDE gets up as BOBBY comes , and moves away .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Where 's your Mother , Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: In the dining-room , I think , Father .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah ! Resting , no doubt . By the way , you wo n't forget what I said about the bread-sauce , will you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You do n't want it remembered , Father , do you ? What you said ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Not the actual words . All I want , my dear , is that you should endeavour to explain to the cook the difference between bread-sauce and a bread-poultice . Make it clear to her that there is no need to provide a bread-poultice with an obviously healthy chicken , such as we had to-night , but that a properly made bread-sauce is a necessity , if the full flavour of the bird is to be obtained .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: “ Full flavour of the bird is to be obtained . ” Yes , Father .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . That 's right , my dear . Bring it home to her . A little quiet talk will do wonders . Well , and so it 's Midsummer Night . Why are n't you two out in the garden looking for fairies ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , it 's a topping night , you know . We ought to be out . D'you feel like a stroll , Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: No , thank you , Bobby , I do n't think I 'll go out .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh , I say , it 's awfully warm .

lg.l: KNOWLE . Well , Jane , I shall take you out . If we meet any of
Sandy 's fairy friends , you can introduce me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking across warningly at herJane ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyI 'm afraid , Uncle Henry , that Melisande and I — I promised Sandy — we ——

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEputting her arm firmly through hisNonsense . I 'm not going to have my niece taken away from me , when she is only staying with us for such a short time . Besides I insist upon being introduced to Titania . I want to complain about the rings on the tennis-lawn . They must dance somewhere else .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: looking anxiously at MELISANDEYou see , Uncle Henry , I 'm not feeling very ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: resignedAll right , Jane .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: brightlyAll right , Uncle Henry .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEvery brightlyIt 's all right , Bobby .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Come along !They go to the open windows together .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEas they goAny message for Oberon , if we meet him ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: gravelyNo , thank you , Father .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . It 's his turn to write , I suppose .

div.stage: JANE laughs as they go out together .

Left alone , MELISANDE takes up a book and goes to the sofa with it , while BOBBY walks about the room unhappily , whistling to himself . He keeps looking across at her , and at last their eyes meet .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: putting down her bookWell , Bobby ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: awkwardlyWell , Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: angrilyDo n't call me that ; you know how I hate it .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Sorry . Melisande . But it 's such a dashed mouthful . And your father was calling you Sandy just now , and you did n't say anything .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: One cannot always control one 's parents . There comes a time when it is almost useless to say things to them .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: eagerlyI never mind your saying things to me , Sandy — I mean , Melisande . I never shall mind , really I sha n't . Of course , I know I 'm not worthy of you , and all that , but — I say , Melisande , is n't there any hope ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Bobby , I asked you not to talk to me like that again .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: coming to herI know you did , but I must . I can n't believe that you —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I told you that , if you promised not to talk like that again , then I would n't tell anybody anything about it , so that it should n't be awkward for you . And I have n't told anybody , not even Jane , to whom I tell all my secrets . Most men , when they propose to a girl , and she refuses them , have to go right out of the country and shoot lions ; it 's the only thing left for them to do . But I did try and make it easy for you , Bobby .SadlyAnd now you 're beginning all over again .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: awkwardlyI though perhaps you might have changed your mind . Lots of girls do .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: contemptuouslyLots of girls ! Is that how you think of me ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , your mother said —He breaks off hurriedly .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: coldlyHave you been discussing me with my mother ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , Sandy , do n't be angry . Sorry ; I mean Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Do n't apologise . Go on .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , I did n't discuss you with your mother . She just happened to say that girls never knew their own minds , and that they always said “ No ” the first time , and that I need n't be downhearted , because —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: That you need n't ? You mean you told her ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , it sort of came out .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: After I had promised that I would n't say anything , you went and told her ! And then I suppose you went and told the cook , and she said that her brother 's young woman was just the same , and then you told the butcher , and he said , “ You stick to it , sir . All women are alike . My missis said ‘ No ’ to me the first time . ” And then you went and told the gardeners — I suppose you had all the gardeners together in the potting-shed , and gave them a lecture about it — and when you had told them , you said , “ Excuse me a moment , I must now go and tell the postman , ” and then —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , steady ; you know that is n't fair .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , what a world !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , you know that is n't fair .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: picking up her bookFather and Jane are outside , Bobby , if you have anything you wish to tell them . But I suppose they know already .She pretends to read .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , you know —He does n't quite know what to say . There is an awkward silence . Then he says humblyI 'm awfully sorry , Melisande . Please forgive me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking at him gravelyThat 's nice of you , Bobby . Please forgive me . I was n't fair .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I swear I never said anything to anybody else , only your mother . And it sort of came out with her . She began talking about you —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: But I never told anybody else .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: It would n't be necessary if you told Mother .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I 'm awfully sorry , but I really do n't see why you should mind so much . I mean , I know I 'm not anybody very much , but I can n't help falling in love with you , and — well , it is a sort of a compliment to you , is n't it ?— even if it 's only me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Of course it is , Bobby , and I do thank you for the compliment . But mixing Mother up in it makes it all so — so unromantic .After a pauseSometimes I think I shall never marry .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh , rot ! . . . I say , you do like me , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh yes . You are a nice , clean-looking Englishman — I do n't say beautiful —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I should hope not !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Pleasant , good at games , dependable — not very clever , perhaps , but making enough money —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , I mean , that 's not so bad .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , but I want so much more !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: What sort of things ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , Bobby , you 're so — so ordinary !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , dash it all , you did n't want me to be a freak , did you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: So — commonplace . So — unromantic .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , steady on ! I do n't say I 'm always reading poetry and all that , if that 's what you mean by romantic , but — commonplace ! I 'm blessed if I see how you make out that .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Bobby , I do n't want to hurt your feelings —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Go on , never mind my feelings .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Well then , look at yourself in the glass !

div.stage: BOBBY goes anxiously to the glass , and then pulls at his clothes .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: looking back at herWell ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I do n't see what 's wrong .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , Bobby , everything 's wrong . The man to whom I give myself must be not only my lover , but my true knight , my hero , my prince . He must perform deeds of derring-do to win my love . Oh , how can you perform deeds of derring-do in a stupid little suit like that !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: looking at itWhat 's the matter with it ? It 's what every other fellow wears .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: contemptuouslyWhat every other fellow wears ! And you think what every other fellow thinks , and talk what every other fellow talks , and eat what every other — I suppose you did n't like the bread-sauce this evening ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: guardedlyWell , not as bread-sauce .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: nodding her headI thought so , I thought so .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: struck by an ideaI say , you did n't make it , did you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Do I look as if I made it ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I thought perhaps — You know , I really do n't know what you do want , Sandy . Sorry ; I mean —

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Go on calling me Sandy , I 'd rather you did .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , when you marry this prince of yours , is he going to do the cooking ? I do n't understand you , Sandy , really I do n't .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: shaking her head gently at himNo , I 'm sure you do n't , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: still trying , howeverI suppose it 's because he 's doing the cooking that he wo n't be able to dress for dinner . He sounds a funny sort of chap ; I should like to see him .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You would n't understand him if you did see him .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: jealouslyHave you seen him ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Only in my dreams .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: relievedOh , well .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: dreamily to herselfPerhaps I shall never see him in this world — and then I shall never marry . But if he ever comes for me , he will come not like other men ; and because he is so different from everybody else , then I shall know him when he comes for me . He wo n't talk about bread-sauce — billiards — and the money market . He wo n't wear a little black suit , with a little black tie — all sideways .BOBBY hastily pulls his tie straight .I do n't know how he will be dressed , but I know this , that when I see him , that when my eyes have looked into his , when his eyes have looked into mine —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , steady !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: waking from her dreamYes ?She gives a little laughPoor Bobby !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: appealinglyI say , Sandy !He goes up to her .

div.stage: MRS. KNOWLE has seized this moment to come back for her handkerchief . She sees them together , and begins to walk out on tiptoe .
They hear her and turn round suddenly .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEin a whisperDo n't take any notice of me . I only just came for my handkerchief .She continues to walk on tiptoe towards the opposite door .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: getting upWe were just wondering where you were , Mother . Here 's your handkerchief .She picks it up from the sofa .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEstill in the voice in which you speak to an invalidThank you , dear . Do n't let me interrupt you — I was just going —

lg.l: But I am just going into the garden . Stay and talk to
Bobby , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEwith a happy smile , hoping for the bestYes , my darling .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: going to the windowsThat 's right .She stops at the windows and holds out her hands to the night— The moon shines bright : In such a night as this When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise , in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls , And sighed his soul towards the Grecian tents , Where Cressid lay that night . In such a night Stood Dido with a willow in her hand , Upon the wild sea banks , and waft her love To come again to Carthage .

div.stage: She stays there a moment , and then says in a thrilling voice ) In such a night ! Ah !
She goes to it .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEin a different voiceAh ! . . . Well , Mr. Coote ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: turning back to her with a startOh — er — yes ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . No , I think I must call you Bobby . I may call you Bobby , may n't I ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh , please do , Mrs. Knowle .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEarchlyNot Mrs. Knowle ! Ca n't you think of a better name ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: wondering if he ought to call her MARYEr — I 'm — I 'm afraid I do n't quite —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Mother .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh , but I say —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEgiving him her handAnd now come and sit on the sofa with me , and tell me all about it .

div.stage: They go to the sofa together .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: But I say , Mrs. Knowle —

lg.l: KNOWLE
lg.stage: shaking a finger playfully at him
lg.l: Not Mrs. Knowle ,
Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: But I say , you must n't think — I mean Sandy and I — we are n't —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . You do n't mean to tell me , Mr. Coote , that she has refused you again .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Yes . I say , I 'd much rather not talk about it .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , it just shows you that what I said the other day was true . Girls do n't know their own minds .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: ruefullyI think Sandy knows hers — about me , anyhow .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Mr. Coote , you are forgetting what the poet said — Shakespeare , or was it the other man ?— “ Faint heart never won fair lady . ” If Mr. Knowle had had a faint heart , he would never have won me . Seven times I refused him , and seven times he came again — like Jacob . The eighth time he drew out a revolver , and threatened to shoot himself . I was shaking like an aspen leaf . Suddenly I realised that I loved him . “ Henry , ” I said , “ I am yours . ” He took me in his arms — putting down the revolver first , of course . I have never regretted my surrender , Mr. Coote .With a sighAh , me ! We women are strange creatures .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I do n't believe Sandy would mind if I did shoot myself .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Oh , do n't say that , Mr. Coote . She is very warm-hearted . I 'm sure it would upset her a good deal . Oh no , you are taking too gloomy a view of the situation , I am sure of it .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , I sha n't shoot myself , but I sha n't propose to her again . I know when I 'm not wanted .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . But we do want you , Mr. Coote . Both my husband and I —

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , I 'd much rather not talk about it , if you do n't mind . I practically promised her that I would n't say anything to you this time .

lg.l: KNOWLE . What , not say anything to her only mother ? But how should
I know if I were to call you “ Bobby , ” or not ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , of course — I mean I have n't really said anything , have I ? Nothing she 'd really mind . She 's so funny about things .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . She is indeed , Mr. Coote . I do n't know where she gets it from . Neither Henry nor I are in the least funny . It was all the result of being christened in that irreligious way — I quite thought he said Millicent — and reading all those books , instead of visiting the sick as I used to do . I was quite a little Red Riding Hood until Henry sprang at me so fiercely .MR. KNOWLE and JANE come in by the window , and she turns round towards them .Ah , there you both are . I was wondering where you had got to . Mr. Coote has been telling me all about his prospects in the city . So comforting . Jane , you did n't get your feet wet , I hope .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: It 's quite dry , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . It 's a most beautiful night , my dear . We 've been talking to the fairies — have n't we , Jane ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , as long as you did n't get cold . Did you see Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . We did n't see any one but Titania — and Peters . He had an appointment , apparently — but not with Titania .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: He is walking out with Alice , I think .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , Melisande will have to talk to Alice in the morning . I always warned you , Henry , about the danger of having an unmarried chauffeur on the premises . I always felt it was a mistake .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Apparently , my dear , Peters feels as strongly about it as you . He is doing his best to remedy the error .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEgetting upWell , I must be going to bed . I have been through a good deal to-night ; more than any of you know about .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEcheerfullyWhat 's the matter , my love ? Indigestion ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Beyond saying that it is not indigestion , Henry , my lips are sealed . I shall suffer my cross — my mental cross — in silence .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Shall I come with you , Aunt Mary ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . In five minutes , dear .To HeavenMy only daughter has left me , and gone into the night . Fortunately my niece has offered to help me out of my — to help me .Holding out her handGood-night , Mr. Coote .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Good-night , Mrs. Knowle .

lg.l: KNOWLE . Good-night ! And remember
what
Shakespeare said .
lg.stage: She presses his hand and holds it
lg.l: Good-night !
Good-night ! . . . Good-night !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Shakespeare said so many things . Among others , he said , “ Good-night , good-night , parting is such sweet sorrow , that I could say good-night till it be morrow . ”MRS. KNOWLE looks at him severely , and then , without saying anything , goes over to him and holds up her cheek .Good-night , my dear . Sleep well .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . In five minutes , Jane .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , Aunt Mary .

div.stage: MRS. KNOWLE goes to the door , BOBBY hurrying in front to open it for her .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEat the doorI shall not sleep well . I shall lie awake all night . Dr. Anderson will be very much distressed . “ Dr. Anderson , ” I shall say , “ it is not your fault . I lay awake all night , thinking of my loved ones . ” In five minutes , Jane .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . An exacting programme . Well , I shall be in the library , if anybody wants to think of me — or say good-night to me — or anything like that .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Then I 'd better say good-night to you now , Uncle Henry .She goes up to him .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEkissing herGood-night , dear .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . If there 's anybody else who wants to kiss me — what about you , Bobby ? Or will you come into the library and have a smoke first ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh , I shall be going to bed directly , I think . Rather tired to-day , somehow .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: He goes out .KNOWLE . Then good-night to you also . Dear me , what a business this is . Sandy has left us for ever , I understand . If she should come back , Jane , and wishes to kiss the top of my head , she will find it in the library — just above the back of the armchair nearest the door .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Did Sandy go out into the garden ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: gloomilyYes — about five minutes ago .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: timidlyI 'm so sorry , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Thanks , it 's awfully decent of you .After a pauseDo n't let 's talk about it .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Of course I wo n't if it hurts you , Bobby . But I felt I had to say something , I felt so sorry . You did n't mind , did you ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: It 's awfully decent of you to mind .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: gentlyI mind very much when my friends are unhappy .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Thanks awfully .He stands up , buttons his coat , and looks at himselfI say , do you see anything wrong with it ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Wrong with what ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: My clothes .He revolves slowly .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Of course not . They fit beautifully .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Sandy 's so funny about things . I do n't know what she means half the time .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Of course , I 'm very fond of Melisande , but I do see what you mean . She 's sosearching for the right word— so romantic .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: eagerlyYes , that 's just it . It takes a bit of living up to . I say , have a cigarette , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: No , thank you . Of course , I 'm very fond of Melisande , but I do feel sometimes that I do n't altogether envy the man who marries her .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , do you really feel that ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes . She 's toogetting the right word at last— too romantic .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You 're about right , you know . I mean she talks about doing deeds of derring-do . Well , I mean that 's all very well , but when one marries and settles down — you know what I mean ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Exactly . That 's just how I feel about it . As I said to Melisande only this evening , this is the twentieth century . Well , I happen to like the twentieth century . That 's all .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I see what you mean .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: It may be very unromantic of me , but I like men to be keen on games , and to wear the clothes that everybody else wears — as long as they fit well , of course — and to talk about the ordinary things that everybody talks about . Of course , Melisande would say that that was very stupid and unromantic of me ——

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I do n't think it is at all .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: How awfully nice of you to say that , Bobby . You do understand so wonderfully .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
