sp.p: with a laughI say , that 's rather funny . I was just thinking the same about you .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I say , were you really ? I 'm so glad . I like to feel that we are really friends , and that we understand each other . I do n't know whether I 'm different from other girls , but I do n't make friends very easily .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Do you mean men or women friends ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Both . In fact , but for Melisande and you , I can hardly think of any — not what you call real friends .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Melisande is a great friend , is n't she ? You tell each other all your secrets , and that sort of thing , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , we 're great friends , but there are some things that I could never tell even her .ImpressivelyI could never show her my inmost heart .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I do n't believe about your not having any men friends . I bet there are hundreds of them , as keen on you as anything .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I wonder . It would be rather nice to think there were . That sounds horrid , does n't it , but a girl can n't help wanting to be liked .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Of course she can n't ; nobody can . I do n't think it 's a bit horrid .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: How nice of you .She gets upWell , I must be going , I suppose .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: What 's the hurry ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Aunt Mary . She said five minutes .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: And how long will you be with her ? You 'll come down again , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: No , I do n't think so . I 'm rather tired this evening .Holding out her handGood-night , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: taking itOh , but look here , I 'll come and light your candle for you .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: How nice of you !

div.stage: She manages to get her hand back , and they walk to the door together .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I suppose I may as well go to bed myself .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: at the doorWell , if you are , we 'd better put the lights out .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Righto .He puts them out .I say , what a night !The moonlight streams through the windows on them .You 'll hardly want a candle .

div.stage: They go out together .

The hall is empty . Suddenly the front door bell is heard to ring . After a little interval , ALICE comes in , turns on the light , and looks round the hall . She is walking across the hall to the drawing-room when MR. KNOWLE comes in from behind her , and she turns round .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Were you looking for me , Alice ?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir . There 's a gentleman at the front door , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Rather late for a call , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He 's in a motor car , sir , and it 's broken down , and he wondered if you 'd lend him a little petrol . He told me to say how very sorry he was to trouble you ——

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . But he 's not troubling me at all — particularly if Peters is about . I daresay you could find Peters , Alice , and if it 's not troubling Peters too much , perhaps he would see to it . And ask the gentleman to come in . We can n't keep him standing on the door-mat .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir . I did ask him before , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , ask him this time in the voice of one who is about to bring in the whiskey .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . And then — bring in the whiskey .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir .She goes out , and returns a moment laterHe says , thank you very much , sir , but he really wo n't come in , and he 's very sorry indeed to trouble you about the petrol .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah ! I 'm afraid we were too allusive for him .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: hopefullyYes , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , we wo n't be quite so subtle this time . Present Mr. Knowle 's compliments , and say that I shall be very much honoured if he will drink a glass of whiskey with me before proceeding on his journey .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . And then — bring in the whiskey .

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir .She goes out . In a little while she comes back followed by the stranger , who is dressed from head to foot in a long cloak .Mr. Gervase Mallory .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . How do you do , Mr. Mallory ? I 'm very glad to see you .They shake hands .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It 's very kind of you . I really must apologise for bothering you like this . I 'm afraid I 'm being an awful nuisance .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Not at all . Are you going far ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Collingham . I live at Little Malling , about twenty miles away . Do you know it ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Yes . I 've been through it . I did n't know it was as far away as that .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with a laughWell , perhaps only by the way I came . The fact is I 've lost myself rather .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I 'm afraid you have . Collingham . You ought n't to have come within five miles of us .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I suppose I ought n't .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , all the more reason for having a drink now that you are here .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It 's awfully kind of you .

div.stage: ALICE comes in .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah , here we are .ALICE puts down the whiskey .You 've told Peters ?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes , sir . He 's looking after it now .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . That 's right ,ALICE goes out .You 'll have some whiskey , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thanks very much .

div.stage: He comes to the table .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . And do take your coat off , wo n't you , and make yourself comfortable ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Er — thanks . I do n't think ——He smiles to himself and keeps his cloak on .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEbusy with the drinksSay when .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . And soda ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Please . . . . Thanks !

div.stage: He takes the glass .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEgiving himself oneI 'm so glad you came , because I have a horror of drinking alone . Even when my wife gives me cough-mixture , I insist on somebody else in the house having cough-mixture too . A glass of cough-mixture with an old friend just before going to bed ——He looks upBut do take your coat off , wo n't you , and sit down and be comfortable ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Er — thanks very much , but I do n't think ——With a shrug and a smileOh , well !He puts down his glass and begins to take it off . He is in fancy dress — the wonderful young Prince in blue and gold of MELISANDE 'S dream .

div.stage: MR. KNOWLE turns round to him again just as he has put his cloak down . He looks at GERVASE in amazement .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEpointing to his whiskey glassBut I have n't even begun it yet . . . . Perhaps it 's the port .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: laughingI 'm awfully sorry . You must wonder what on earth I 'm doing .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . No , no ; I wondered what on earth I 'd been doing .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You see , I 'm going to a fancy dress dance at Collingham .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . You relieve my mind considerably .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: That 's why I did n't want to come in — or take my cloak off .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEinspecting himIt becomes you extraordinarily well , if I may say so .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , thanks very much . But one feels rather absurd in it when other people are in ordinary clothes .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . On the contrary , you make other people feel absurd . I do n't know that that particular style would have suited me , butlooking at himselfI am sure that I could have found something more expressive of my emotions than this .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You 're quite right . “ Dress does make a difference , Davy . ”

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . It does indeed .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I feel it 's almost wicked of me to be drinking a whiskey and soda .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Very wicked .Taking out his caseHave a cigarette , too ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: May I have one of my own ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Do .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: feeling for itIf I can find it . They were very careless about pockets in the old days . I had a special one put in somewhere , only it 's rather difficult to get at . . . . Ah , here it is .He takes a cigarette from his case , and after trying to put the case back in his pocket again , places it on the table .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Match ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thanks .Picking up his whiskeyWell , here 's luck , and — my most grateful thanks .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEraising his glassMay you slay all your dragons .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you .They drink .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , now about Collingham . I do n't know if you saw a map outside in the hall .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I saw it , but I am afraid I did n't look at it . I was too much interested in your prints .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEeagerlyYou do n't say that you are interested in prints ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Very much — as an entire amateur .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Most of the young men who come here think that the art began and ended with Kirchner . If you are really interested , I have something in the library — but of course I must n't take up your time now . If you could bear to come over another day — after all , we are neighbours ——

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It 's awfully nice of you ; I should love it .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Hedgling is the name of the village . I mention it because you seem to have lost your way so completely ——

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , by Jove , now I know where I am . It 's so different in the moonlight . I 'm lunching this way to-morrow . Might I come on afterwards ? And then I can return your petrol , thank you for your hospitality , and expose my complete ignorance of old prints , all in one afternoon .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , but you must come anyhow . Come to tea .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: That will be ripping .Getting upWell , I suppose I ought to be getting on .He picks up his cloak .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . We might just have a look at that map on the way .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh yes , do let 's .

div.stage: They go to the door together , and stand for a moment looking at the casement windows .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . It really is a wonderful night .He switches off the lights , and the moon streams through the windowsJust look .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with a deep sighWonderful !

div.stage: They go out together .

The hall is empty for a moment . Then GERVASE reappears . He has forgotten his cigarette-case . He finds it , and on his way out again stops for a moment in the moonlight , looking through the casement windows .

MELISANDE comes in by the French windows . He hears her , and at the same moment she sees him . She gives a little wondering cry . It is He ! The knight of her dreams . They stand gazing at each other . . . . Silently he makes obeisance to her ; silently she acknowledges it . . . . Then he is gone .

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: It is seven o'clock on a beautiful midsummer morning . The scene is a glade in a wood a little way above the village of Hedgling .

sp.speaker: GERVASE MALLORY
sp.p: , still in his fancy dress , but with his cloak on , comes in . He looks round him and says , “ By Jove , how jolly ! ” He takes off his cloak , throws it down , stretches himself , turns round , and , seeing the view behind him , goes to look at it . While he is looking he hears an unmelodious whistling . He turns round with a start ; the whistling goes on ; he says “ Good Lord ! ” and tries to get to his cloak . It is too late . ERN , a very small boy , comes through the trees into the glade . GERVASE gives a sigh of resignation and stands there . ERN stops in the middle of his tune and gazes at him .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo — er ! Oo !He circles slowly round GERVASE .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I quite agree with you .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo ! Look !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , it is a bit dressy , is n't it ? Come round to the back — take a good look at it while you can . That 's right . . . . Been all round ? Good !

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You keep saying “ Oo . ” It makes conversation very difficult . Do you mind if I sit down ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: sitting down on a logI gather that I have your consent . I thank you .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo ! Look !He points at GERVASE 'S legs .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: What is it now ? My legs ? Oh , but surely you 've noticed those before ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: sitting down in front of GERVASEOo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Really , I do n't understand you . I came up here for a walk in a perfectly ordinary blue suit , and you do nothing but say “ Oo . ” What does your father wear when he 's ploughing ? I suppose you do n't walk all round him and say “ Oo ! ” What does your Uncle George wear when he 's reaping ? I suppose you do n't — By the way , I wish you 'd tell me your name .ERN gazes at him dumbly .Oh , come ! They must have told you your name when you got up this moving .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: smiling sheepishlyErn .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: bowingHow do you do ? I am very glad to meet you , Mr. Hearne . My name is Mallory .ERN grinsThank you .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: tapping himselfI 'm Ern .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , I 'm Mallory .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Ern .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Mallory . We can n't keep on saying this to each other , you know , because then we never get any farther . Once an introduction is over , Mr. Hearne , we are —

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Ern .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , I know . I was very glad to hear it . But now — Oh , I see what you mean . Ern — short for Ernest ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: noddingThey calls me Ern .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: That 's very friendly of them . Being more of a stranger I shall call you Ernest . Well , Ernest —getting upJust excuse me a moment , will you ? Very penetrating bark this tree has . It must be a Pomeranian .He folds his cloak upon it and sits down againThat 's better . Now we can talk comfortably together . I do n't know if there 's anything you particularly want to discuss — nothing ?— well , then , I will suggest the subject of breakfast .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: grinning‘ Ad my breakfast .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You 've had yours ? You selfish brute ! . . . Of course , you 're wondering why I have n't had mine .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Bacon fat .He makes reminiscent noises .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Do n't keep on going through all the courses . Well , what happened was this . My car broke down . I suppose you never had a motor car of your own .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Do n't like moty cars .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , really , after last night I 'm inclined to agree with you . Well , no , I ought n't to say that , because , if I had n't broken down , I should never have seen Her . Ernest , I do n't know if you 're married or anything of that sort , but I think even your rough stern heart would have been moved by that vision of loveliness which I saw last night .He is silent for a little , thinking of her .Well , then , I lost my way . There I was — ten miles from anywhere — in the middle of what was supposed to be a short cut — late at night — Midsummer Night — what would you have done , Ernest ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Gone ‘ ome .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Do n't be silly . How could I go home when I did n't know where home was , and it was a hundred miles away , and I 'd just seen the Princess ? No , I did what your father or your Uncle George or any wise man would have done , I sat in the car and thought of Her .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You are surprised ? Ah , but if you 'd seen her . . . . Have you ever been alone in the moonlight on Midsummer Night — I do n't mean just for a minute or two , but all through the night until the dawn came ? You are n't really alone , you know . All round you there are little whisperings going on , little breathings , little rustlings . Somebody is out hunting ; somebody stirs in his sleep as he dreams again the hunt of yesterday ; somebody up in the tree-tops pipes suddenly to the dawn , and then , finding that the dawn has not come , puts his silly little head back under his wing and goes to sleep again . . . . And the fairies are out . Do you believe in fairies , Ernest ? You would have believed in them last night . I heard them whispering .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: coming out of his thoughts with a laughWell , of course , I can n't expect you to believe me . But do n't go about thinking that there 's nothing in the world but bacon fat and bull'shYpppHeNeyes . Well , then , I suppose I went to sleep , for I woke up suddenly and it was morning , the most wonderful sparkling magical morning — but , of course , you were just settling down to business then .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !He makes more reminiscent noises .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , that 's just what I said . I said to myself , breakfast .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: ‘ Ad my breakfast .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , but I ‘ ad n't . I said to myself , “ Surely my old friend , Ernest , whom I used to shoot bison with in the Himalayas , has got an estate somewhere in these parts . I will go and share his simple meal with him . ” So I got out of the car , and I did what you did n't do , young man , I had a bathe in the river , and then a dry on a pocket-handkerchief — one of my sister 's , unfortunately — and then I came out to look for breakfast . And suddenly , whom should I meet but my old friend , Ernest , the same hearty fellow , the same inveterate talker as when we shot dragon-flies together in the swamps of Malay .Shaking his handErnest , old boy , pleased to meet you . What about it ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: ‘ Ad my —

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: S'sh .He gets upNow then — to business . Do you mind looking the other way while I try to find my purse .Feeling for it .Every morning when you get up , you should say , “ Thank God , I 'm getting a big boy now and I 've got pockets in my trousers . ” And you should feel very sorry for the poor people who lived in fairy books and had no trousers to put pockets in . Ah , here we are . Now then , Ernest , attend very carefully . Where do you live ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: ‘ Ome .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You mean , you have n't got a flat of your own yet ? Well , how far away is your home ?ERN grins and says nothingA mile ?ERN continues to grinHalf a mile ?ERN grinsSix inches ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: pointingDown there .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Good . Now then , I want you to take this —giving him half-a-crown—

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: Oo !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , I thought that would move you — and I want you to ask your mother if you can bring me some breakfast up here . Now , listen very carefully , because we are coming to the important part . Hard-boiled eggs , bread , butter , and a bottle of milk — and anything else she likes . Tell her that it 's most important , because your old friend Mallory whom you shot white mice with in Egypt is starving by the roadside . And if you come back here with a basket quickly , I 'll give you as many bull'shYpppHeNeyes as you can eat in a week .Very earnestlyNow , Ernest , with all the passion and emotion of which I am capable before breakfast , I ask you : have you got that ?

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: noddingGoing ‘ ome .He looks at the half-crown again .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Going ‘ ome . Yes . But — returning with breakfast . Starving man — lost in forest — return with basket — save life .To himselfI believe I could explain it better to a Chinaman .to ERNNow then , off you go .

sp.speaker: ERN
sp.p: as he goes off‘ Ad my breakfast .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , and I wonder if I shall get mine .

div.stage: GERVASE walks slowly after him and stands looking at him as he goes down the hill . Then , turning round , he sees another stranger in the distance .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Hullo , here 's another of them .He walks towards the logHorribly crowded the country 's getting nowadays .He puts on his coat .

div.stage: A moment later a travelling Peddler , name of SUSAN , comes in singing . He sees GERVASE sitting on the log .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: with a bowGood morning , sir .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: looking roundGood morning .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I had thought to be alone . I trust my singing did not discommode you .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Not at all . I like it . Do go on .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Alas , the song ends there .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , well , could n't we have it again ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Perhaps later , sir , if you insist .Taking off his hatWould it inconvenience you if I rested here for a few minutes ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Not a bit . It 's a jolly place to rest at , is n't it ? Have you come far this morning ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Three or four miles — a mere nothing on a morning like this . Besides , what does the great William say ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I do n't think I know him . What does he say ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: A merry heart goes all the way .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , Shakespeare , yes .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: And why , you ask , am I merry ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , I did n't , but I was just going to . Why are you merry ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Can you not guess ? What does the great Ralph say ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: trying hardThe great Ralph . . . . No , you 've got me there . I 'm sure I do n't know him . Well , what does he say ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Give me health and a day , and I will make the pomp of Empires ridiculous .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Emerson , of course . Silly of me .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: So you see , sir — I am well , the day is well , all is well .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Sir , I congratulate you . In the words of the great Percy —to himselfthat 's got him .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: at a lossThe — er — great Percy ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Hail to thee , blithe spirit !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: eagerlyI take you , I take you ! Shelley ! Ah , there 's a poet , Mr .— er — I do n't think I quite caught your name .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh ! My name 's Gervase Mallory — to be referred to by posterity , I hope , as the great Gervase .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Not a poet , too ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , no , not professionally .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: But one with the poets in spirit — like myself . I am very glad to meet you , Mr. Mallory . It is most good-natured of you to converse with me . My name is Susan ,GERVASE bows .Generally called Master Susan in these parts , or sometimes Gentleman Susan . I am a travelling Peddler by profession .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: A delightful profession , I am sure .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: The most delightful of all professions .He begins to undo his pack ,Speaking professionally for the moment , if I may so far venture , you are not in any need of boot-laces , buttons , or collar-studs ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: smilingWell , no , not at this actual moment . On almost any other day perhaps — but no , not this morning .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I only just mentioned it in passing — en passant , as the French say .He brings out a paper bag from his pack .Would the fact of my eating my breakfast in this pleasant resting place detract at all from your appreciation of the beautiful day which Heaven has sent us ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Eating your what ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: My simple breakfast .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: shaking his headI 'm very sorry , but I really do n't think I could bear it . Only five minutes ago Ernest — I do n't know if you know Ernest ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: The great Ernest ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: indicating with his handNo , the very small one — Well , he was telling me all about the breakfast he 'd just had , and now you 're showing me the breakfast you 're just going to have — no , I can n't bear it .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: My dear sir , you do n't mean to tell me that you would do me the honour of joining me at my simple repast ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: jumping up excitedlyThe honour of joining you !— the honour ! My dear Mr. Susan ! Now I know why they call you Gentleman Susan .Shaking his head sadlyBut no . It would n't be fair to you . I should eat too much . Besides , Ernest may come back . No , I will wait . It would n't be fair .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: unpacking his breakfastBacon or cheese ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Cheese — I mean bacon — I mean — I say , you are n't serious ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: handing him bread and cheeseI trust you will find it up to your expectations .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: taking itI say , you really —SolemnlyMaster Susan , with all the passion and emotion of which I am capable before breakfast , I say “ Thank you . ”He takes a biteThank you .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: eating alsoPlease do not mention it . I am more than repaid by your company .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It is charming of you to say so , and I am very proud to be your guest , but I beg you to allow me to pay for this delightful cheese .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: No , no . I could n't hear of it .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I warn you that if you will not allow me to pay for this delightful cheese , I shall insist on buying all your boot-laces . Nay , more , I shall buy all your studs , and all your buttons . Your profession would then be gone .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Well , well , shall we say tuppence ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Tuppence for a banquet like this ? My dear friend , nothing less than half-a-crown will satisfy me .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Sixpence . Not a penny more .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with a sighVery well , then .He begins to feel in his pocket , and in so doing reveals part of his dress . SUSAN opens his eyes at it , and then goes on eating . GERVASE finds his purse and produces sixpence , which he gives to SUSAN .Sir , I thank you .He resumes his breakfast .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You are too generous . . . . Forgive me for asking , but you are not by chance a fellow-traveller upon the road ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Do you mean professionally ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Yes . There is a young fellow , a contortionist and sword-swallower , known locally in these parts as Humphrey the Human Hiatus , who travels from village to village . Just for a moment I wondered —

div.stage: He glances at GERVASE 's legs , which are uncovered . GERVASE hastily wraps his coat round them .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I am not Humphrey . No . Gervase the Cheese Swallower . . . . Er — my costume —

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Please say nothing more . It was ill-mannered of me to have inquired . Let a man wear what he likes . It is a free world .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , the fact is , I have been having a bathe .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: with a bowI congratulate you on your bathing costume .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You live near here then ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Little Malling . I came over in a car .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Little Malling ? That 's about twenty miles away .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , much more than that surely .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: No . There 's Hedgling down there .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: surprisedHedgling ? Heavens , how I must have lost my way . . . . Then I have been within a mile of her all night . And I never knew !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: You are married , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No . Not yet .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Get married .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Take my advice and get married .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You recommend it ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I do . . . . There is no companion like a wife , if you marry the right woman .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I have been married thirty years . Thirty years of happiness .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But in your profession you must go away from your wife a good deal .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: smilingBut then I come back to her a good deal .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: thoughtfullyYes , that must be rather jolly .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Why do you think I welcomed your company so much when I came upon you here this morning ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: modestlyOh , well ——

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: It was something to tell my wife when I got back to her . When you are married , every adventure becomes two adventures . You have your adventure , and then you go back to your wife and have your adventure again . Perhaps it is a better adventure that second time . You can say the things which you did n't quite say the first time , and do the things which you did n't quite do . When my week 's travels are ever , and I go back to my wife , I shall have a whole week 's happenings to tell her . They wo n't lose in the telling , Mr. Mallory . Our little breakfast here this morning — she will love to hear about that . I can see her happy excited face as I tell her all that I said to you , and — if I can remember it — all that you said to me .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: eagerlyI say , how jolly !ThoughtfullyYou wo n't forget what I said about the Great Percy ? I thought that was rather good .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: I hope it was n't too good , Mr. Mallory . If it was , I shall find myself telling it to her as one of my own remarks . That 's why I say “ Get married . ” Then you can make things fair for yourself . You can tell her all the good things of mine which you said .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But there must be more in marriage than that .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: There are a million things in marriage , but companionship is at the bottom of it all . . . . Do you know what companionship means ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: How do you mean ? Literally ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: The derivation of it in the dictionary . It means the art of having meals with a person . Cynics talk of the impossibility of sitting opposite the same woman every day at breakfast . Impossible to them , perhaps , poor shallow-hearted creatures , but not impossible to two people who have found what love is .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It does n't sound very romantic .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: solemnlyIt is the most romantic thing in the whole world . . . . Some more cheese ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: taking itThank you . . . .ThoughtfullyDo you believe in love at first sight , Master Susan ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Why not ? If it 's the woman you love at first sight , not only the face .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I see .After a pauseIt 's rather hard to tell , you know . I suppose the proper thing to do is to ask her to have breakfast with you , and see how you get on .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Well , you might do worse .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: laughingAnd propose to her after breakfast ?

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: If you will . It is better than proposing to her at a ball as some young people do , carried away suddenly by a snatched kiss in the moonlight .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: shaking his headNothing like that happened last night .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: What does the Great Alfred say of the kiss ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I never read the Daily Mail .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Tennyson , Mr. Mallory , Tennyson .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: “ The kiss , ” says the Great Alfred , “ the woven arms , seem but to be weak symbols of the settled bliss , the comfort , I have found in thee . ” The same idea , Mr. Mallory . Companionship , or the art of having breakfast with a person .Getting upWell , I must be moving on . We have been companions for a short time ; I thank you for it . I wish you well .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: getting upI say , I 've been awfully glad to meet you . And I shall never forget the breakfast you gave me .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: It is friendly of you to say so .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: hesitatinglyYou wo n't mind my having another one when Ernest comes back — I mean , if Ernest comes back ? You wo n't think I 'm slighting yours in any way ? But after an outdoor bathe , you know , one does ——

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: Please ! I am happy to think you have such an appetite .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: holding out his handWell , good-bye , Mr. Susan ,SUSAN looks at his hand doubtfully , and GERVASE says with a laughOh , come on !

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: shaking itGood-bye , Mr. Mallory .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: And I sha n't forget what you said .

sp.speaker: SUSAN
sp.p: smilingI expect you will , Mr. Mallory . Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes off .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: calling after himBecause it was n't the moonlight , it was n't really . It was just Her .To himselfIt was just Her . . . . I suppose the great Whatsisname would say , “ It was just She , ” but then , that is n't what I mean .

div.stage: GERVASE watches him going down the hill . Then he turns to the other side , says , “ Hallo ! ” suddenly in great astonishment , and withdraws a few steps .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It can n't be !He goes cautiously forward and looks againIt is !

div.stage: He comes back , and walks gently off through the trees .

MELISANDE comes in . She has no hat ; her hair is in two plaits to her waist ; she is wearing a dress which might belong to any century . She stands in the middle of the glade , looks round it , holds out her hands to it for a moment , and then clasps them with a sigh of happiness . . . .
GERVASE , his cloak thrown away , comes in behind her . For a moment he is half-hidden by the trees .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: very softlyPrincess !

div.stage: She hears but thinks she is still dreaming . She smiles a little .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: a little more loudlyPrincess !

div.stage: She listens and nods to herself , GERVASE steps out into the open .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Princess !

div.stage: She turns round .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking at him wonderinglyYou !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: At your service , Princess .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: It was you who came last night .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I was at your father 's court last night . I saw you . You looked at me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I thought it was only a dream when I looked at you . I thought it was a dream when you called me just now . Is it still a dream ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: If it is a dream , let us go on dreaming .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Where do you come from ? Fairyland ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: This is Fairyland . We are in the enchanted forest .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: with a sigh of happinessAh !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You have been looking for it ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: For so long .She is silent for a little , and then says with a smileMay one sit down in an enchanted forest ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Your throne awaits you .He spreads his cloak over the log .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Thank you . . . . Wo n't you sit , too ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: shaking his headI have n't finished looking at you yet . . . . You are very lovely , Princess .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Am I ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Have n't they told you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Perhaps I wondered sometimes .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Very lovely . . . . Have you a name which goes with it ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: My name is Melisande .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: his whole heart in itMelisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: content at lastAh !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: solemnlyNow the Princess Melisande was very beautiful .He lies down on the grass near her , looks up at her and is silent for a little .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: smiling shylyMay we talk about you , now ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It is for the Princess to say what we shall talk about . If your Royal Highness commands , then I will even talk about myself .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You see , I do n't know your name yet .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I am called Gervase .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Gervase . It is a pretty name .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I have been keeping it for this morning .

lg.l: It will be Prince Gervase , will it not , if this is
Fairyland ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Alas , no . For I am only a humble woodcutter 's son . One of seven .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Of seven ? I thought that humble woodcutters always had three sons , and that it was the youngest who went into the world to seek his fortune .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Three — that 's right . I said “ one of several . ” Now that I count them up , three .Counting on his fingersEr — Bowshanks , er — Mulberry-face and myself . Three . I am the youngest .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And the fairies came to your christening ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Now for the first time I think that they did .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: noddingThey always come to the christening of the third and youngest son , and they make him the tallest and the bravest and the most handsome .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: modestlyOh , well .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You are the tallest and the bravest and the most handsome , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with a modest smileWell , of course , Mulberry-face is hardly a starter , and then Bowshanks —he indicates the curve of his legs— I mean , there 's not much competition .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I have no sisters .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: The Princess never has sisters . She has suitors .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: with a sighYes , she has suitors .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: taking out his daggerTell me their names that I may remove them for you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: There is one dressed in black and white who seeks to win my hand .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: feeling the pointHe bites the dust to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: To-morrow ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Unless it rains in the night . Perhaps it would be safer if we arranged for him to bite it this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How brave you are !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Say no more . It will be a pleasure .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Ah , but I cannot ask you to make this sacrifice for me .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: The sacrifice will be his .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: But are you so certain that you will kill him ? Suppose he were to kill you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: getting upMadam , when the third son of a humble woodcutter engages in mortal combat with one upon whom the beautiful Princess has frowned , there can be but one end to the struggle . To doubt this would be to let Romance go .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You are right . I should never have doubted .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: At the same time , it would perhaps be as well to ask the help of my Uncle Otto .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: But is it fair to seek the assistance of an uncle in order to kill one small black and white suitor ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Ah , but he is a wizard . One is always allowed to ask the help of a wizard . My idea was that he should cast a spell upon the presumptuous youth who seeks to woo you , so that to those who gazed upon him he should have the outward semblance of a rabbit . He would then realise the hopelessness of his suit and . . . go away .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: with dignityI should certainly never marry a small black and white rabbit .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No , you could n't , could you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: gravelyNo .Then their eyes meet . There is a twinkle in his ; hers respond ; and suddenly they are laughing together .What nonsense you talk !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , it 's such an absurdly fine morning , is n't it ? There 's a sort of sparkle in the air . I 'm really trying to be quite sensible .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: making room for him at her feetGo on talking nonsense .He sits down on the ground and leans against the log at her side .Tell me about yourself . You have told me nothing yet , but thatshe smiles at himyour father is a woodcutter .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes . He — er — cuts wood .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And you resolved to go out into the world and seek your fortune ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes . You see if you are a third son of a humble woodcutter , nobody thinks very much of you at home , and they never take you out with them ; and when you are cutting wood , they always put you where the sawdust gets into your mouth . Because , you see , they have never read history , and so they do n't know that the third and youngest son is always the nicest of the family .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And the tallest and the bravest and the most handsome .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: And all the other things you mention .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: So you ran away ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: So I ran away — to seek my fortune .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: But your uncle the wizard , or your godmother or somebody , gave you a magic ring to take with you on your travels ?NoddingThey always do , you know .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: showing the ring on his fingerYes , my fairy godmother gave me a magic ring . Here it is .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking at itWhat does it do ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You turn it round once and think very hard of anybody you want , and suddenly the person you are thinking of appears before you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How wonderful ! Have you tried it yet ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Once . . . . That 's why you are here .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh !SoftlyHave you been thinking of me ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: All night .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I dreamed of you all night .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: happilyDid you , Melisande ? How dear of you to dream of me !AnxiouslyWas I — was I all right ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , yes !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: pleasedAh !He spreads himself a little and removes a speck of dust from his sleeve

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: thinking of it stillYou were so brave .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , I expect I 'm pretty brave in other people 's dreams — I 'm so cowardly in my own . Did I kill anybody ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You were engaged in a terrible fight with a dragon when I woke up .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Leaving me and the dragon still asleep — I mean , still fighting ? Oh , Melisande , how could you leave us until you knew who had won ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I tried so hard to get back to you .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I expect I was winning , you know . I wish you could have got back for the finish . . . . Melisande , let me come into your dreams again to-night .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You never asked me last night . You just came .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you for letting me come .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: And then when I woke up early this morning , the world was so young , so beautiful , so fresh that I had to be with it . It called to me so clearly — to come out and find its secret . So I came up here , to this enchanted place , and all the way it whispered to me — wonderful things .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: What did it whisper , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: The secret of happiness .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Ah , what is it , Melisande ?She smiles and shakes her headI met a magician in the woods this morning .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Did he speak to you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: He told me the secret of happiness .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: What did he tell you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: He said it was marriage .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Ah , but he did n't mean by marriage what so many people mean .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: He seemed a very potent magician .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Marriage to many people means just food . Housekeeping . He did n't mean that .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: A very wise and reverend magician .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Love is romance . Is there anything romantic in breakfast — or lunch ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , not so much in lunch , of course , but — -

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How well you understand ! Why do the others not understand ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: smiling at herPerhaps because they have not seen Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh no , no , that is n't it . All the others — -

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Do you mean your suitors ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes . They are so unromantic , so material . The clothes they wear ; the things they talk about . But you are so different . Why is it ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I do n't know . Perhaps because I am the third son of a woodcutter . Perhaps because they do n't know that you are the Princess . Perhaps because they have never been in the enchanted forest .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: What would the forest tell them ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: All the birds in the forest are singing “ Melisande ” ; the little brook runs through the forest murmuring “ Melisande ” ; the tall trees bend their heads and whisper to each other “ Melisande . ” All the flowers have put on their gay dresses for her . Oh , Melisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: awedIs it true ?They are silent for a little , happy to be together . . . . He looks back at her and gives a sudden little laugh .What is it ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Just you and I — together — on the top of the world like this .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes , that 's what I feel , too .After a pauseGo on pretending .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Pretending ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: That the world is very young .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: We are very young , Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: timidlyIt is only a dream , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Who knows what a dream is ? Perhaps we fell asleep in Fairyland a thousand years ago , and all that we thought real was a dream , until now at last we are awake again .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How wonderful that would be .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Perhaps we are dreaming now . But is it your dream or my dream , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: after thinking it outI think I would rather it were your dream , Gervase . For then I should be in it , and that would mean that you had been thinking of me .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Then it shall be my dream , Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Let it be a long one , my dear .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: For ever and for ever .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: dreamilyOh , I know that it is only a dream , and that presently we shall wake up ; or else that you will go away and I will go away , too , and we shall never meet again ; for in the real world , what could I be to you , or you to me ? So go on pretending .

div.stage: He stands up and faces her .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Melisande , if this were Fairyland , or if we were knights and ladies in some old romance , would you trust yourself to me ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: So very proudly .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You would let me come to your father 's court and claim you over all your other suitors , and fight for you , and take you away with me ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: If this were Fairyland , yes .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You would trust me ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I would trust my lord .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: smiling at herThen I will come for the Princess this afternoon .With sudden feelingAh , how can I keep away now that I have seen the Princess ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: shyly — happilyWhen you saw me last night , did you know that you would see me again ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I have been waiting for you here .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: How did you know that I would come ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: On such a morning — in such a place — how could the loved one not be here ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking awayThe loved one ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I saw you last night .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: softlyWas that enough ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Enough , yes . Enough ? Oh no , no , no !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: noddingI will wait for you this afternoon .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: And you will come away with me ? Out into the world with me ? Over the hills and far away with me ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: softlyOver the hills and far away .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: going to herPrincess !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Not Princess .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Melisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: holding out her hand to himAh !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: May I kiss your hands , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: They are my lord 's to kiss .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: kissing themDear hands .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Now I shall love them , too .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: May I kiss your lips , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: proudlyWho shall , if not my lord ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Melisande !He touches her lips with his .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: breaking away from himOh !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: triumphantlyI love you , Melisande ! I love you !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: wonderinglyWhy did n't I wake up when you kissed me ? We are still here . The dream goes on .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It is no dream , Melisande . Or if it is a dream , then in my dream I love you , and if we are awake , then awake I love you . I love you if this is Fairyland , and if there is no Fairyland , then my love will make a faery land of the world for you . For I love you , Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: timidlyAre we pretending still ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No , no , no !

div.stage: She looks at him gravely for a moment and then nods her head .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: pointingI live down there . You will come for me ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I will come .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I am my lord 's servant . I will wait for him .She moves away from him . Then she curtsies and saysThis afternoon , my lord .

div.stage: She goes down the hill .
He stands looking after her . While he is standing there , ERN comes through the trees with breakfast .

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: It is about four o'clock in the afternoon of the same day . JANE is sitting on the sofa in the hall , glancing at a paper , but evidently rather bored with it , and hoping that somebody — BOBBY , did you say ?— will appear presently . However , it is MR. KNOWLE who comes in .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah , Jane !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: looking upHallo , Uncle Henry . Did you have a good day ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , Peters and I had a very enjoyable drive .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: But you found nothing at the sale ? What a pity !

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEtaking a catalogue from his pocketNothing which I wanted myself , but there were several very interesting lots . Peters was strongly tempted by Lot 29 — “ Two hip-baths and a stuffed crocodile . ” Very useful things to have by you if you think of getting married , Jane , and setting up house for yourself . I do n't know if you have any thoughts in that direction ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: a little embarrassedWell , I suppose I shall some day .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah ! . . . Where 's Bobby ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: carelesslyBobby ? Oh , he 's about somewhere .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I think Bobby would like to hear about Lot 29 .Returning to his catalogueOr perhaps Lot 42 . “ Lot 42 — Twelve aspidistras , towel-horse , and ‘ The Maiden 's Prayer . ’ ” All for seven and sixpence . I ought to have had Bobby with me . He could have made a firm offer of eight shillings . . . . By the way , I have a daughter , have n't I ? How was Sandy this morning ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I did n't see her . Aunt Mary is rather anxious about her .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Has she left us for ever ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: There 's nothing to be frightened about really .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I 'm not frightened .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: She had breakfast before any of us were up , and went out with some sandwiches afterwards , and she has n't come back yet .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . A very healthy way of spending the day .MRS. KNOWLE comes inWell , Mary , I hear that we have no daughter now .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah , there you are , Henry . Thank Heaven that you are back safely .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . My dear , I always meant to come back safely . Did n't you expect me ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . I had given up hope . Jane here will tell you what a terrible morning I have had ; prostrate on the sofa , mourning for my loved ones . My only child torn from me , my husband — dead .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEsurprisedOh , I was dead ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . I pictured the car smashed to atoms , and you lying in the road , dead , with Peters by your side .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah ! How was Peters ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEwith a shrugI did n't look . What is a chauffeur to one who has lost her husband and her only child in the same morning ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Still , I think you might have looked .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Sandy 's all right , Aunt Mary . You know she often goes out alone all day like this .

lg.l: KNOWLE . Ah , is she alone ? Jane , did you count the gardeners as
I asked you ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Count the gardeners ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . To make sure that none of them is missing too .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: It 's quite all right , Aunt Mary . Sandy will be back by tea-time .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEresignedIt all comes of christening her Melisande . You know , Henry , I quite thought you said Millicent .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , talking about tea , my dear — at which happy meal our long-lost daughter will be restored to us — we have a visitor coming , a nice young fellow who takes an interest in prints .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . I 've heard nothing of this , Henry .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . No , my dear , that 's why I 'm telling you now .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . A young man ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Nice-looking ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Rich ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I forgot to ask him , Mary . However , we can remedy that omission as soon as he arrives .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . It 's a very unfortunate day for him to have chosen . Here 's Sandy lost , and I 'm not fit to be seen , and — Jane , your hair wants tidying ——

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . He is not coming to see you or Sandy or Jane , my dear ; he is coming to see me . Fortunately , I am looking very beautiful this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Jane , you had better be in the garden , dear , and see if you can stop Sandy before she comes in , and just give her a warning . I do n't know what she 'll look like after roaming the fields all day , and falling into pools ——

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . A sweet disorder in the dress kindles in clothes a wantonness .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . I will go and tidy myself . Jane , I think your mother would like you to — but , after all , one must think of one 's own child first . You will tell Sandy , wo n't you ? We had better have tea in here . . . . Henry , your trousers —she looks to see that JANE is not listening , and then says in a loud whisperyour trousers ——

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I 'm afraid I did n't make myself clear , Mary . It 's a young fellow who is coming to see my prints ; not the Prince of Wales who is coming to see my trousers .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEturning to JANEYou 'll remember , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: smilingYes , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . That 's a good girl .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah ! . . . Your aunt was n't very lucid , Jane . Which one of you is it who is going to marry the gentleman ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Do n't be so absurd , Uncle Henry .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEtaking out his catalogue againPerhaps he would be interested in Lot 29 .BOBBY comes in through the windows .Ah , here 's Bobby . Bobby , they tell me that you think of setting up house .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: looking quickly at JANEWho told you that ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Now , starting with two hip-baths and a stuffed crocodile for nine shillings and sixpence , and working up to twelve aspidistras , a towel-horse and “ The Maiden 's Prayer ” for eight shillings , you practically have the spare room furnished for seventeen and six . But perhaps I had better leave the catalogue with you .He presses it into the bewildered BOBBY 'S handsI must go and tidy myself up . Somebody is coming to propose to me this afternoon .

div.stage: He hurries out .
BOBBY looks after him blankly , and then turns to JANE .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , what 's happened ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Happened ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Yes , why did he say that about my setting up house ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I think he was just being funny . He is sometimes , you know .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You do n't think he guessed ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Guessed what ? About you and Melisande ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , shut up , Jane . I thought we agreed not to say anything more about that .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: But what else could he have guessed ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You know well enough .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: shaking her headNo , I do n't .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I told you this morning .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: What did you tell me ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You know .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: No , I do n't .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Yes , you do .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: No , I do n't .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: coming closerAll right , shall I tell you again ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: edging awayI do n't want to hear it .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: How do you know you do n't want to hear it , if you do n't know what it is ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I can guess what it is .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: There you are !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: It 's what you say to everybody , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: loftilyIf you want to know , Miss Bagot , I have only said it to one other person in my life , and that was in mistake for you .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: coldlyMelisande and I are not very much alike , Mr. Coote .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: No . You 're much prettier .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: turning her head awayYou do n't really think so . Anyhow , it is n't true .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: It is true , Jane . I swear it .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Well , you did n't think so yesterday .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Why do you keep talking about yesterday ? I 'm talking about to-day .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: A girl has her pride , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: So has a man . I 'm awfully proud of being in love with you .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: That is n't what I mean .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyWell — well — well , what it comes to is that you get refused by Sandy , and then you immediately come to me and expect me to jump at you .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Suppose I had waited a year and then come to you , would that have been better ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Of course it would .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , really I can n't follow you , darling .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: indignantlyYou must n't call me darling .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Must n't call you what ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyDarling .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Did I call you darling ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: shortlyYes .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: to himself“ Darling . ” No , I suppose I must n't . But it suits you so awfully well — darling .She stamps her footI 'm sorry , darl —— I mean Jane , but really I can n't follow you . Because you 're so frightfully fascinating , that after twenty-four hours of it , I simply have to tell you how much I love you , then your pride is hurt . But if you had been so frightfully unattractive that it took me a whole year to see anything in you at all , then apparently you 'd have been awfully proud .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: You have known me a whole year , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Not really , you know . Directly I saw you and Sandy together I knew I was in love with one of you , but — well , love is a dashed rummy thing , and I thought it was Sandy . And so I did n't really see you till last night , when you were so awfully decent to me .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: wistfullyIt sounds very well , but the trouble is that it will sound just as well to the next girl .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: What next girl ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: The one you propose to to-morrow .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You know , Jane , when you talk like that I feel that you do n't deserve to be proposed to at all .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: loftilyI 'm sure I do n't want to be .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: coming closerAre you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Am I what ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Quite sure .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I should have thought it was pretty obvious seeing that I 've just refused you .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Have you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Have I what ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Refused me .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I thought I had .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: And would you be glad if I went away and never saw you again ?She hesitatesHonest , Jane . Would you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: awkwardlyWell , of course , I like you , Bobby . I always have .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: But you feel that you would like me better if I were somebody else 's husband ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: indignantlyOh , I never said that .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Dash it , you 've been saying it all this afternoon .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: weaklyBobby , do n't ; I can n't argue with you . But really , dear , I can n't say now that I will marry you . Oh , you must understand . Oh , think what Sandy ——

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: We wo n't tell Sandy .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: surprisedBut she 's bound to know .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: We wo n't tell anybody .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: eagerlyBobby !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: noddingJust you and me . Nobody else for a long time . A little private secret .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Bobby !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: coming to herIs it a bargain , Jane ? Because if it 's a bargain ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: going away from himNo , no , Bobby . Not now . I must go upstairs and tidy myself — no , I must n't , I must wait for Melisande — no , Bobby , do n't . Not yet . I mean it , really . Do go , dear , anybody might come in .

div.stage: BOBBY , who has been following her round the hall , as she retreats nervously , stops and nods to her .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: All right , darling , I 'll go .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: You must n't say “ darling . ” You might say it accidentally in front of them all .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: grinningAll right , Miss Bagot . . . I am going now , Miss Bagot .At the windowsGood-bye , Miss Bagot .JANE blows him a kiss . He bowsYour favour to hand , Miss Bagot .He turns and sees MELISANDE coming through the gardenHallo , here 's Sandy !He hurries off in the opposite direction .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , Jane , Jane !She sinks into a chair .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: What , dear ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Everything .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , but that 's so vague , darling . Do you mean that ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: dreamilyI have seen him ; I have talked to him ; he has kissed me .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: amazedKissed you ? Do you mean that he has — kissed you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I have looked into his eyes , and he has looked into mine .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , but who ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: The true knight , the prince , for whom I have been waiting so long .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: But who is he ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: They call him Gervase .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Gervase who ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: scornfullyDid Elaine say , “ Lancelot who ” when they told her his name was Lancelot ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes , dear , but this is the twentieth century . He must have a name .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: dreamilyThrough the forest he came to me , dressed in blue and gold .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: sharplySandy !Struck with an ideaHave you been out all day without your hat , darling ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: vaguelyHave I ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: I mean — blue and gold . They do n't do it nowadays .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: nodding to herHe did , Jane .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: But how ?— Why ? Who can he be ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: He said he was a humble woodcutter 's son . That means he was a prince in disguise . He called me his princess .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Darling , how could he be a prince ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I have read stories sometimes of men who went to sleep and woke up thousands of years afterwards and found themselves in a different world . Perhaps , Jane , he lived in those old days , and ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Did he talk like an ordinary person ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh no , no !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Well , it 's really extraordinary . . . . Was he a gentleman ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: smiling at herI did n't ask him , Jane .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: crosslyYou know what I mean .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: He is coming this afternoon to take me away .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: amazedTo take you away ? But what about Aunt Mary ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: vaguelyAunt Mary ? What has she got to do with it ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: impatientlyOh , but ——With a shrug of resignationI do n't understand . Do you mean he 's coming here ?MELISANDE nods gravelyMelisande , you 'll let me see him ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes . I 've thought it all out . I wanted you here , Jane . He will come in ; I will present you ; and then you must leave us alone . But I should like you to see him . Just to see how different , how utterly different he is from every other man . . . . But you will promise to go when you have seen him , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: noddingI 'll say , “ I 'm afraid I must leave you now , and —— ” Sandy , how can he be a prince ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: When you see him , Jane , you will say , “ How can he not be a prince ? ”

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: But one has to leave princes backward . I mean — he wo n't expect — you know ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I do n't think so . Besides , after all , you are my cousin .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Yes . I think I shall get that in ; just to be on the safe side . “ Well , cousin , I must leave you now , as I have to attend my aunt . ” And then a sort of — not exactly a curtsey , but —she practises , murmuring the words to herselfI suppose you did n't happen to mention me to him this morning ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: half smilingOh no !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: hurtI do n't see why you should n't have . What did you talk about ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I do n't know .She grips JANE 'S arm suddenlyJane , I did n't dream it all this morning , did I ? It did happen ? I saw him — he kissed me — he is coming for me — he ——

div.stage: Enter ALICE

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Mr. Gervase Mallory .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: happilyAh !

div.stage: GERVASE comes in , an apparently ordinary young man in a loud golfing suit .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking at him with growing amazement and horrorOh !

div.stage: JANE looks from one to the other in bewilderment .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I ought to explain . Mr. Knowle was kind enough to lend me some petrol last night ; my car broke down ; he was good enough to say I might come this afternoon and see his prints . I am hoping to be allowed to thank him again for his kindness last night . And — er — I 've brought back the petrol .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: still with her eyes on himMy father will no doubt be here directly . This is my cousin , Miss Bagot .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: bowingHow do you do ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: nervouslyHow do you do ?After a pauseWell , I 'm afraid I must leave you now , as ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: with her eyes still on GERVASE , putting out a hand and clutching at JANENo !

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: startledWhat ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Do n't go , Jane . Do sit down , wo n't you , Mr .— er ——

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Mallory .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Mr. Mallory .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Where will you sit , Mr. Mallory ?She is still talking in an utterly expressionless voice .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you . Where are you ——he indicates the sofa .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: moving to it , but still holding JANEThank you .

div.stage: MELISANDE and JANE sit down together on the sofa . GERVASE sits on a chair near . There is an awkward silence .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: half getting upWell , I 'm afraid I must ——

div.stage: MELISANDE pulls her down . She subsides .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Charming weather we are having , are we not , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: enthusiasticallyOh , rather . Absolutely top-hole .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: to JANEAbsolutely top-hole weather , is it not , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , I love it .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You play golf , I expect , Mr. Mallory ?

lg.l: Oh , rather . I 've been playing this morning .
Pretty rotten , too , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Jane plays golf .to JANEYou 're pretty rotten , too , are n't you , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Bobby and I were both very bad to-day .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I think you will like Bobby , Mr. Mallory . He is staying with us just now . I expect you will have a good deal in common . He is on the Stock Exchange .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: smilingSo am I .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: valiantly repressing a shudderJane , Mr. Mallory is on the Stock Exchange . Is n't that curious ? I felt sure that he must be directly I saw him .

div.stage: There is another awkward silence .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: getting upWell , I 'm afraid I must ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: pulling her downDo n't go , Jane . I suppose there are a great many of you on the Stock Exchange , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh , quite a lot .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Quite a lot , Jane . . . . You do n't know Bobby — Mr. Coote ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: N — no , I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I suppose there are so many of you , and you dress so much alike , and look so much alike , that it 's difficult to be quite sure whom you do know .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes , of course , that makes it more difficult .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes . You see that , do n't you , Jane ? . . . You play billiards and bridge , of course , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh yes .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: They are absolutely top-hole games , are n't they ? Are you — pretty rotten at them ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: getting upAh , here 's my father .

div.stage: Enter MR. KNOWLE

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Ah , Mr. Mallory , delighted to see you . And Sandy and Jane to entertain you . That 's right .

div.stage: They shake hands

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: How do you do ?

div.stage: ALICE comes in with tea

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . I 've been wasting my day at a sale . I hope you spent yours more profitably ,GERVASE laughs pleasantlyAnd what have you been doing , Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Wasting mine , too , Father .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Dear , dear . Well , they say that the wasted hours are the best .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: moving to the doorI think I will go and ——MRS. KNOWLE comes in with outstretched hands

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . My dear , this is Mr. Mallory .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . My dear Mr. Mallory !Turning roundSandy , dear !MELISANDE comes slowly backHow do you do ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: shaking handsHow do you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Sandy , dear !to GERVASEMy daughter , Melisande , Mr. Mallory . My only child .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh — er — we ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Mr. Mallory and I have met , Mother .

lg.l: KNOWLE
And our dear Jane .
My dear sister 's only daughter . But dear Jane has a brother . Dear
Harold ! In the Civil Service . Sandy , dear , will you pour out tea ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: resignedYes , Mother .She goes to the tea-table .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEgoing to the sofaI am such an invalid now , Mr. Mallory ——

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: helping herOh , I 'm so sorry . Can I ——?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you . Dr. Anderson insists on my resting as much as possible . So my dear Melisande looks after the house for me . Such a comfort . You are not married yourself , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No . Oh no .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEsmiling to herselfAh !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Jane , Mother 's tea .JANE takes it .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: coming forwardOh , I beg your pardon . Let me ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: It 's all right .

div.stage: GERVASE takes up a cake-stand .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Where 's Bobby ? Bobby is the real expert at this .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I expect Mr. Mallory is an expert , too , Father . You enjoy tea-parties , I expect , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I enjoy most things , Miss Knowle .To MRS. KNOWLEWhat will you have ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Thank you . I have to be careful . Dr. Anderson insists on my being careful , Mr. Mallory .ConfidentiallyNothing organic , you understand . Both my husband and I — Melisande has an absolutely sound constitution .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: indicating cupJane . . . Sugar and milk , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Please .To MR. KNOWLEWo n't you have this , sir ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . No thank you . I have a special cup .

div.stage: He takes a large cup from MELISANDE ) . A family tradition , Mr. Mallory . But whether it is that I am supposed to require more nourishment than the others , or that I can n't be trusted with anything breakable , History does not relate .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: laughingWell , I think you 're lucky . I like a big cup .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Have mine .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No , thanks .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: coming inHallo ! Tea ?

lg.l: KNOWLE . Ah , Bobby , you 're just in time .
This is Mr .
Coote . Bobby , this is Mr. Mallory .
lg.stage: They nod to each other and say , “ How do you do ? ”

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: indicating a seat next to herCome and sit here , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: who was making for JANEOh — er — righto .He sits down .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEto GERVASEAnd how did the dance go last night ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Oh , were you at a dance ? How lovely !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Dance ?

sp.speaker: MR

sp.p: understandingAh !

sp.speaker: MRS

sp.speaker: MR

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Dear , dear . . . . Peters is in love just now . . . . I hope he did n't give you cider in mistake for petrol .

lg.l: KNOWLE . Ah !
Wo n't Mr. Mallory have some more tea ,
Sandy ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE

sp.p: Thank you .to MRS. KNOWLEWo n't you ——

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Please do n't trouble . I never have more than one cup . Dr. Anderson is very firm about that . Only one cup , Mrs. Knowle .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: to MELISANDESandwich ? Oh , you 're busy . Sandwich , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: taking oneThank you .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: to GERVASESandwich ?

sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: to MR. KNOWLESandwich ?

sp.speaker: MR

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: to himselfSandwich , Mr. Coote ? Thank you .He takes one .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEto GERVASEBeing such an invalid , Mr. Mallory , it is a great comfort to me to have Melisande to look after the house .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I am sure it is .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Of course , I can n't expect to keep her for ever .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: coldlyMore tea , Jane ?

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Thank you , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . It 's extraordinary how she has taken to it . I must say that I do like a girl to be a good housekeeper . Do n't you agree , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , of course , all that sort of thing is rather important .

sp.speaker: MRS

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I 'm sure Mr. Mallory agrees with you , Mother .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: laughingWell , one must eat .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: passing plateHave another sandwich ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: taking oneThanks .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Do you live in the neighbourhood , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: About twenty miles away . Little Malling .

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: helpfullyOh , yes .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , I hope we shall see you here again .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: That 's very kind of you indeed . I shall love to come .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: More tea , Father ?

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . No , thank you , my love .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: More tea , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No , thank you .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLEgetting upI do n't want to hurry you , Mr. Mallory , but if you have really finished ——

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: getting upRight .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . You wo n't go without seeing the garden , Mr. Mallory ? Sandy , when your father has finished with Mr. Mallory , you must show him the garden . We are very proud of our roses , Mr. Mallory . Melisande takes a great interest in the roses .

lg.l: I should like very much to see the garden .
Shall I see you again , Mrs. Knowle . . . . Do n't get up , please .

sp.p: KNOWLEgetting upIn case we do n't —she holds out her hand

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: shaking itGood-bye . And thank you so much .

sp.speaker: MRS

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: smilingThank you .With a bow to JANE and BOBBYGood-bye , in case ——

sp.speaker: BOBBY

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: Good-bye , Mr. Mallory .

sp.speaker: MR
sp.p: KNOWLE . Well , come along .As they go outIt is curious how much time one has to spend in saying “ How do you do ” and “ Good-bye . ” I once calculated that a man of seventy . . . .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLE . Jane , dear , would you mind coming with me to the drawing-room , and helping me to — er ——

sp.speaker: JANE
sp.p: resignedOf course , Aunt Mary .

sp.speaker: MRS

JANE turns at the door , sees that MELISANDE is not looking , and blows a hasty kiss to BOBBY .

sp.p: Something more to eat ?

sp.p: Bobby !

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: turningYes ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: There 's something I want to say to you . Do n't go .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
