sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes . . . . You were quite right .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: How do you mean ? When ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: When you said that girls did n't know their own minds .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Oh !With an awkward laughYes . Well — er — I do n't expect any of us do , really , you know . I mean — er — that is to say ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I 'm sorry I said what I did say to you last night , Bobby . I ought n't to have said all those things .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , that 's all right

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I did n't mean them . And — and Bobby — I will marry you if you like .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: staggeredSandy !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , Sandy . I say ! I say ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: offering her cheekYou may kiss me if you like , Bobby .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say ! . . . Er — er —he kisses her gingerlythanks ! . . . Er — I say ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: What is it , Bobby ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , you know —he tries againI do n't want you to — to feel that — I mean , just because I asked you twice — I mean I do n't want you to feel that — well , I mean you must n't do it just for my sake , Sandy . I mean Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: You may call me Sandy .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , you see what I mean , Sandy .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: It is n't that , Bobby . It is n't that .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: You know , I was thinking about it last night — afterwards , you know — and I began to see , I began to see that perhaps you were right . I mean about my not being romantic and — and all that . I mean , I 'm rather an ordinary sort of chap , and ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: sadlyWe are all rather ordinary sort of chaps .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: eagerlyNo , no . No , that 's where you 're wrong , Sandy . I mean Melisande . You are n't ordinary . I do n't say you 'd be throwing yourself away on me , but — but I think you could find somebody more suitable .EarnestlyI 'm sure you could . I mean somebody who would remember to call you Melisande , and who would read poetry with you and — and all that . I mean , there are lots of fellows ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I do n't understand . Do n't you want to marry me now ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: with dignityI do n't want to be married out of pity .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: coldlyI have told you that it is n't out of pity .

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: Well , what is it out of ? I mean , after what you said yesterday about my tie , it can n't be love . If you really loved me ——

sp.p: taken abackW-what ?

sp.speaker: BOBBY
sp.p: I say , shut up , Sandy . You know it is n't that at all .

I 'm an awful rotter . . . . Well . . . well — oh , damn !

sp.speaker: MRS

sp.p: Oh — er ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Jane is waiting for you .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: KNOWLEin a soft gentle voiceWhere is your father , dear ? In the library with Mr. Mallory ? . . . I want to speak to him . Just on a little matter of business . . . . Dear child !

sp.p: Oh ! How horrible !

div.stage: She walks about , pulling at her handkerchief and telling herself that she wo n't cry . But she feels that she is going to , and she goes to the open windows , and stands for a moment looking out , trying to recover herself
GERVASE comes in .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: gentlyPrincess !She hears ; her hand closes and tightens ; but she says nothing .Princess !

div.stage: With an effort she controls herself , turns round and speaks coldly

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Please do n't call me by that ridiculous name .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Melisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Nor by that one .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Miss Knowle .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Yes ? What do you want , Mr. Mallory ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I want to marry you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: taken by surpriseOh ! . . . How dare you !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But I told you this morning .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I think you had better leave this morning out of it .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But if I leave this morning out of it , then I have only just met you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: That is what I would prefer .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh ! . . . Then if I have only just met you , perhaps I ought n't to have said straight off that I want to marry you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: It is unusual .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Yes . But not unusual to want to marry you .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I am not interested in your wants .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Oh !GentlyI 'm sorry that we 've got to forget about this morning .Going closer to herIs it so easy to forget , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Very easy for you , I should think .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But not for you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: bitterlyYou dress up and amuse yourself , and then laugh and go back to your ordinary life again — you do n't want to remember that , do you , every time you do it ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You let your hair down and flirt with me and laugh and go home again , but you can n't forget . Why should I ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: furiouslyHow dare you say I flirted with you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: How dare you say I laughed at you ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Do you think I knew you would be there when I went up to the wood ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Do you think I knew you would be there when I went up ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Then why were you there all dressed up like that ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: My car broke down and I spent the night in it . I went up the hill to look for breakfast .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Breakfast ! That 's all you think about .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: cheerfullyWell , it 's always cropping up .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: in disgustOh !She moves away from him and then turns round holding out her handGood-bye , Mr. Mallory .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: taking itGood-bye , Miss Knowle . . . .GentlyMay I kiss your hands , Melisande ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: patheticallyOh , do n't !She hides her face in them .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Dear hands . . . . May I kiss your lips , Melisande ?She says nothing . He comes closer to herMelisande !

div.stage: He is about to put his arms round her , but she breaks away from him .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Oh , do n't , do n't ! What 's the good of pretending ? It was only pretence this morning — what 's the good of going on with it ? I thought you were so different from other men , but you 're just the same , just the same . You talk about the things they talk about , you wear the clothes they wear . You were my true knight , my fairy Prince , this morning , and this afternoon you come down dressed like thatshe waves her hand at itand tell me that you are on the Stock Exchange ! Oh , can n't you see what you 've done ? All the beautiful world that I had built up for you and me — shattered , shattered .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: going to herMelisande !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: No , no !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: stoppingAll right .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: recovering herselfPlease go .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with a smileWell , that 's not quite fair , you know .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , what about my beautiful world — the world that I had built up ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: What about your pretence this morning ? I thought you were so different from other women , but you 're just the same , just the same . You were my true lady , my fairy Princess , this morning ; and this afternoon the Queen , your mother , disabled herself by indigestion , tells me that you do all the housekeeping for her just like any ordinary commonplace girl . Your father , the King , has obviously never had a battle-axe in his hand in his life ; your suitor , Prince Robert of Coote , is much more at home with a niblick than with a lance ; and your cousin , the Lady Jane ——

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: sinking on to the sofa and hiding her faceOh , cruel , cruel !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: remorsefullyOh , forgive me , Melisande . It was horrible of me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: No , but it 's true . How could any romance come into this house ? Now you know why I wanted you to take me away — away to the ends of the earth with you .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Well , that 's what I want to do .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Ah , do n't ! When you 're on the Stock Exchange !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: But there 's plenty of romance on the Stock Exchange .Nodding his headOh yes , you want to look out for it .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: reproachfullyNow you 're laughing at me again .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: My dear , I 'm not . Or if I am laughing at you , then I am laughing at myself too . And if we can laugh together , then we can be happy together , Melisande .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: I want romance , I want beauty . I do n't want jokes .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I see what it is . You do n't like my knickerbockers .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: bewilderedDid you expect me to ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: No .After a pauseI think that 's why I put ‘ em on .She looks at him in surprise .You see , we had to come back to the twentieth century some time ; we could n't go on pretending for ever . Well , here we are —indicating his clothes— back . But I feel just as romantic , Melisande . I want beauty — your beauty — just as much .He goes to her .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Which Melisande do you want ? The one who talked to you this morning in the wood , or the one who —bitterlydoes all the housekeeping for her mother ?ViolentlyAnd badly , badly , badly !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: The one who does all the housekeeping for her mother — and badly , badly , badly , bless her , because she has never realised what a gloriously romantic thing housekeeping is .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: amazedRomantic !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: with enthusiasmMost gloriously romantic . . . . Did you ever long when you were young to be wrecked on a desert island ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: clasping her handsOh yes !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You imagined yourself there — alone or with a companion ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Often !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: And what were you doing ? What is the romance of the desert island which draws us all ? Climbing the bread-fruit tree , following the turtle to see where it deposits its eggs , discovering the spring of water , building the hut — housekeeping , Melisande . . . . Or take Robinson Crusoe . When Man Friday came along and left his footprint in the sand , why did Robinson Crusoe stagger back in amazement ? Because he said to himself , like a good housekeeper , “ By Jove , I 'm on the track of a servant at last . ” There 's romance for you !

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: smiling and shaking her head at himWhat nonsense you talk !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: It is n't nonsense ; indeed , indeed it is n't . There 's romance everywhere if you look for it . You look for it in the old fairy-stories , but did they find it there ? Did the gentleman who had just been given a new pair of seven-league boots think it romantic to be changed into a fish ? He probably thought it a confounded nuisance , and wondered what on earth to do with his boots . Did Cinderella and the Prince find the world romantic after they were married ? Think of the endless silent evenings which they spent together , with nothing in common but an admiration for Cinderella 's feet — do you think they did n't long for the romantic days of old ? And in two thousand or two hundred thousand years , people will read stories about us , and sigh and say , “ Will those romantic days never come back again ? ” Ah , they are here now , Melisande , for us ; for the people with imagination ; for you and for me .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Are they ? Oh , if I could believe they were !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: You thought of me as your lover and true knight this morning . Ah , but what an easy thing to be ! You were my Princess . Look at yourself in the glass — how can you help being a princess ? But if we could be companions , Melisande ! That 's difficult ; that 's worth trying .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: gentlyWhat do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Get used to me . See me in a top-hat — see me in a bowler-hat . Help me with my work ; play games with me — I 'll teach you if you do n't know how . I want to share the world with you for all our lives . That 's a long time , you know ; we can n't do it on one twenty-minutes ’ practice before breakfast . We can be lovers so easily — can we be friends ?

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: looking at him gravelyYou are very wise .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: I talked with a wise man in the wood this morning ; I 've been thinking over what he said .SuddenlyBut when you look at me like that , how I long to be a fool and say , “ Come away with me now , now , now , ” you wonderful , beautiful , maddening woman , you adorable child , you funny foolish little girl .Holding up a fingerSmile , Melisande . Smile !Slowly , reluctantly , she gives him a smile .I suppose the fairies taught you that . Keep it for me , will you — but give it to me often . Do you ever laugh , Melisande ? We must laugh together sometimes — that makes life so easy .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: with a happy little laughOh , what can I say to you ?

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Say , “ I think I should like you for a companion , Gervase . ”

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: shylyI think I should like you for a companion , Gervase .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Say , “ Please come and see me again , Gervase . ”

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: Please come and see me again , Gervase .

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Jumping up and waving his handSay , “ Hooray for things ! ”

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: standing up , but shyly stillHooray for things !

sp.speaker: GERVASE
sp.p: Thank you , Melisande . . . I must go .He presses her hand and goes ; or seems to be going . But suddenly he comes back , bends on one knee , raises her hand on his , and kisses itMy Princess !

div.stage: Then GERVASE goes out .

MELISANDE stays there , looking after him , her hand to her cheek . . . . But one cannot stand thus for ever . The new life must begin . With a little smile at herself , at GERVASE , at things , she fetches out the Great Book from its hiding-place , where she had buried it many weeks ago in disgust . Now it comes into its own . She settles down with it in her favourite chair . . . .

sp.speaker: MELISANDE
sp.p: readingTo make Bread-Sauce . . . . Take an onion , peel and quarter it , and simmer it in milk . . . .

div.stage: But you know how the romantic passage goes . We have her with it , curled up in the chair , this adorable child , this funny foolish little girl .

docTitle.titlePart: THE STEPMOTHER A PLAY IN ONE ACT

body.stage: The first performance of this play was given at the Alhambra Theatre on November 16 , 1920 , with the following cast :
Sir John Pembury — GILBERT HARE . Lady Pembury — WINIFRED EMERY . Perkins — C. M . LOWNE . The Stranger — GERALD DU MAURIER .
THE STEPMOTHER

A summer morning . The sunniest and perhaps the pleasantest room in the London house of SIR JOHN PEMBURY , M. P . For this reason LADY PEMBURY uses it a good deal , although it is not officially hers . It is plainly furnished , and probably set out to be a sort of waiting-room for SIR JOHN 'S many callers , but LADY PEMBURY has left her mark upon it .

PERKINS , the butler , inclining to stoutness , but not yet past his prime , leads the may in , followed by THE STRANGER , PERKINS has already placed him as “ one of the lower classes , ” but the intelligent person in the pit perceives that he is something better than that , though whether he is in the process of falling from a higher estate , or of rising to it , is not so clear . He is thirty odd , shabbily dressed ( but then , so are most of us nowadays ) , and ill at ease ; not because he is shabby , but because he is ashamed of himself . To make up for this , he adopts a blustering manner , as if to persuade himself that he is a fine fellow after all . There is a touch of commonness about his voice , but he is not uneducated .

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: I 'll tell Sir John you 're here , but I do n't say he 'll see you , mind .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Do n't you worry about that . He 'll see me right enough .

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: He 's busy just now . Well ——He looks at THE STRANGER doubtfully .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: bitterlyI suppose you think I 've got no business in a gentleman 's house . Is that it ?

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: Well , I did n't say so , did I ? Maybe you 're a constituent ? Being in the ‘ Ouse of Commons , we get some pretty queer ones at times . All sorts , as you might say . . . . P'raps you 're a deputation ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: violentlyWhat the hell 's it got to do with you who I am . You go and tell your master I 'm here — that 's all you 've got to do . See ?

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: unruffledEasy , now , easy . You ‘ ave n't even told me your name yet . Is it the Shah of Persia or Mr. Bottomley ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: The less said about names the better . You say , “ Somebody from Lambeth ” — he 'll know what I mean .

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: humorouslyAh , I beg your pardon — the Archbishop of Canterbury . I did n't recognise your Grace .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: angrilyIt 's people like you who make one sick of the world . Parasites — servile flunkeys , bolstering up an effete aristocracy . Why do n't you get some proper work to do ?

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: good-naturedlyNow , look here , young man , this is n't the time for that sort of talk . If you 've got anything you want to get off your chest about flunkeys or monkeys , or whatever it may be , keep it till Sunday afternoon — when I 'm off duty .He comes a little closer to THE STRANGERFour o'clock Sunday afternoon —jerking his thumb over his shoulder— just round the corner — in the Bolton Mews . See ? Nobody there to interrupt us . See ? All quite gentlemanly and secluded , and a friend of mine to hold the watch . See ?He edges closer as he talks .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: retreating nervouslyNo offence meant , mate . We 're in the same boat — you and me ; we do n't want to get fighting . My quarrel is n't with you . You go and tell Sir John that there 's a gentleman come to see him — wants a few minutes of his valuable time — from Lambeth way . He 'll know . That 's all right .

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: drawing back , disappointedlyThen I sha n't be seeing you Sunday afternoon ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: laughing awkwardlyThere , that 's all right . No offence meant . Somebody from Lambeth — that 's what you 've got to say . And tell ‘ im I 'm in a hurry . He 'll know what I mean .

sp.speaker: PERKINS
sp.p: going slowly to the doorWell , it 's a queer game , but being in the ‘ Ouse of Commons , one can n't never be surprised . All sorts , as you might say , all sorts .

body.stage: Exit PERKINS .
THE STRANGER , left alone , walks up and down the room , nervously impatient .

LADY PEMBURY comes in . In twenty-eight years of happy married life , she has mothered one husband and five daughters , but she has never had a son — her only sorrow . Her motto might be , “ It is just as easy to be kind ” ; and whether you go to her for comfort or congratulation , you will come away feeling that she is the only person who really understands .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh !She stops and then comes towards THE STRANGERHow do you do ? Are you waiting to see my husband ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: taken aback at seeing herYes .

body.stage: He is not sure for the moment if this upsets his plans or forwards them .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: I think he 's engaged just now . But he wo n't be long . Perkins will tell him as soon as he is free .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: contemptuouslyHis name is Perkins , is it ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: surprisedThe butler ? Yes .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: contemptuouslyMister Perkins , the Butler .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: with a friendly smileYou do n't mind our having a butler ?She picks up some work from the table and takes it to the sofa

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: shrugging his shouldersOne more parasite .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: interestedI always thought parasites were much smaller than Perkins .Sitting downDo sit down , wo n't you ?He sits down reluctantly .You must n't mind my being here . This is really my work-room . I expect my husband will take you into his own room when he 's ready .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Your work-room ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: looking up at him with a smileYou do n't seem to like our domestic arrangements .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: waving his hand at her embroideryYou call that work ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: pleasantlyOther people 's work always seems so contemptible , does n't it ? Now I expect if you tried to do this , you would find it very difficult indeed , and if I tried to do yours — what is your work , Mr .— er — Dear me , I do n't even know your name .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: bitterlyNever mind my name . Take it that I have n't got a name .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: But your friends must call you something .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Take it that I have n't got any friends .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh , do n't say that ! How can you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: surlyWhat 's it matter to you whether anybody cares about me ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh , never mind whether anybody cares about you ; do n't you care about anybody ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Nobody .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Poor , poor man !Going on with her workIf you can n't tell me your name , I wish you would tell me what work you do .WinninglyYou do n't mind my asking , do you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I can tell you what work I 'm going to do after to-day .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh , do !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: violentlyNone !

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: surprisedNone ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: No more work after to-day .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Wo n't that be rather dull ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well , you ought to know . I 'm going to be one of the idle rich — like you and Sir John — and let other people work for me .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: thoughtfullyI should n't have said my husband was idle . But there it is . No two people ever agree as to what is work and what is n't .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: What do you know about work — you aristocrats ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: mildlyMy husband is only a K. B. E ., you know . Quite a recent creation .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: not heeding herYou , who 've been brought up in the lap of luxury — never known a day 's discomfort in your life ——

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: My dear young man , you really must n't tell a woman who has had five children that she has never known a day 's discomfort in her life . . . . Ask any woman .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: upsetWhat 's that ? . . . I did n't come here to argue with you . You began it . Why can n't you let me alone ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: going to a side-table and taking up a photographFive children — all girls — and now I 'm a grandmother .Showing him the photographThere ! That 's my eldest daughter with her eldest son and my eldest grandchild . Is n't he a duck ? He 's supposed to be like me . . . . I never had a son of my own .THE STRANGER has taken the photograph in his hand and is holding it awkwardly .Oh , let me take it away from you . Other 's people 's relations are so uninteresting , are n't they ?She takes it away and puts it back in its place . Then she returns to her seat and goes on with her work .So you 've made a lot of money ? How exciting for you !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: grimlyI have n't got it yet , but it 's coming .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Soon ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: To-day .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: You 're not married , are you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: You want to know a lot , do n't you ? Well , I 'm not married .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: I was thinking how much nicer it is when you can share that sort of news with somebody else , somebody you love . It makes good news so much better , and bad news so much more bearable .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: That 's what you and your husband do , is it ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: noddingAlways . For eight-and-twenty years .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: He tells you everything , eh ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Well , not his official secrets , of course . Everything else .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Ha ! I wonder .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: But you have nobody , you say . Well , you must share your good news with me . Will you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Oh yes , you shall hear about it all right .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: That 's nice of you . Well then , first question . How much money is it going to be ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: thoughtfullyWell , I do n't quite know yet . What do you say to a thousand a year ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh , but what a lot !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: You think a thousand a year would be all right . Enough to live on ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: For a bachelor , ample .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: For a bachelor .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: There 's no one dependent on you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Not a soul . Only got one relation living .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: enjoying a joke of his ownA father . But I shall not be supporting him . Oh no . Far from it .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: a little puzzled by this , though the is not going to show itThen I think you will be very rich with a thousand a year .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Yes , that 's what I thought . I should think it would stand a thousand .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: What is it ? An invention of some sort ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Oh no , not an invention . . . . A discovery .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: How proud she would have been !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Your wife if you had had one ; your mother if she had been alive .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: violentlyLook here , you leave my mother out of it . My business is with Sir John ——sneeringlySir John Pembury , K. B. E . If I want to talk about my mother , he and I will have a nice little talk together about her . Yes , and about my father , too .

body.stage: LADY PEMBURY understands at last . She stands up slowly , and looks at him , horrified .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: A thousand a year . You said so yourself . Yes , I think it 's worth a thousand a year .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Who is your father ? What 's your name ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Did n't I tell you I had n't got a name ?BitterlyAnd if you want to know why , ask Sir John Pembury , K. B. E .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: in a whisperHe 's your father .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Yes . And I 'm his loving son — come to see him at last , after all these years .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: hardly able to ask itHow — how old are you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Thirty .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: sitting down on the sofaOh , thank God ! Thank God !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: upset by her emotionLook here , I did n't want all this . I ask you — did I begin it ? It was you who kept asking questions . I just came for a quiet talk with Sir John — Father and Son talking together quietly — talking about Son 's allowance . A thousand a year . What did you want to come into it for ?

body.stage: LADY PEMBURY is quiet again now . She wipes away a tear or two , and sits up , looking at him thoughtfully .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: So you are the son that I never had .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: What d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: almost to herselfThe son whom I wanted so . Five girls — never a boy . Let me look at you .She goes up to him .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: edging awayHere , none of that .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: looking at him earnestly to see if she can see a likenessNo — and yet —shaking her head sadlyPoor boy ! What an unhappy life you must have had !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I did n't come here to be pitied . I came to get my rightful allowance — same as any other son .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: to herselfPoor boy !She goes back to her seat and then saysYou do n't mind my asking you questions now , do you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Go on . There 's no mistake about it . I can promise you that .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: How did you find out ? Did your Mother tell you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Never a word . “ Do n't ask questions , sonny —— ” “ Father 's dead ” — all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Does Sir John know ? Did he ever know ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: feeling in his pocketHe knew right enough .Bringing out lettersLook here — here you are . This was how I found out .Selecting oneThere — read that one .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: taking itYes — that 's John 's writing .She holds it out to him .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Are n't you going to read it ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: shaking her head patheticallyHe did n't write it to me .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: He did n't write it to me , if it comes to that .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: You 're her son — you have a right . I 'm — nobody .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: putting it back in his pocketOh well , please yourself .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Did Sir John provide for your mother ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well , why should n't he ? He was a rich man .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Not in those days . . . . But indeed — why should n't he ? What else could he do ? I 'm glad he did .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: And now he 's going to provide for his loving son . He 's rich enough for that in these days .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: He 's never seen you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Never . The historic meeting of Father and Son will take place this afternoon .With a feeble attempt at what he thinks is the aristocratic mannerAfraid the Governor will be in the deuce of a rage . Been exceedin ’ my allowance — what ? Make it a thousand , dear old Gov .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Do n't they call that blackmail ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: violentlyNow look here , I 'd better tell you straight that there 's no blackmail about this at all . He 's my father , is n't he ? Well , can n't a son come to his father if he 's hard up ? Where are your threatening letters ? Where 's the blackmail ? Anyway , what 's he going to do about it ? Put his son in prison ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: following her own thoughtsYou 're thirty . Thank God for that . We had n't met then . . . . Ah , but he ought to have told me . He ought to have told me .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: P'raps he thought you would n't marry him , if he did .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Do you think that was it ?Earnestly to him , as if he were an old friendYou know men — young men . I never had a son ; I never had any brothers . Do they tell ? They ought to , ought n't they ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well — well , if you ask me — I say , look here , this is n't the sort of thing one discusses with a lady .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Is n't it ? But one can talk to a friend .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: scornfullyYou and me look like friends , do n't we ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: smilingWell , we do , rather .

body.stage: He gets up hastily and moves further away from her .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I know what your game is . Do n't think I do n't see it .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: What is it ?

lg.l: Falling on your knees , and saying with tears in your eyes :
“ Oh , kind friend , spare me poor husband ! ” I know the sort of thing .
And trying to work me up friendly before you begin .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: shaking her headNo , if I went on my knees to you , I should n't say that . How can you hurt my husband now ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well , I do n't suppose the scandal will do him much good . Not an important Member of Parliament like him .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Ah , but it is n't the outside things that really hurt you , the things which are done to you , but the things which you do to yourself . And so if I went on my knees to you , it would not be for my husband 's sake . For I should go on my knees , and I should say : “ Oh , my son that might have been , think before you give up everything that a man should have . Ambition , hope , pride , self-respect — are not these worth keeping ? Is your life to end now ? Have you done all that you came into the world to do , so that now you can look back and say , ‘ It is finished ; I have given all that I had to give ; henceforward I will spend ’ ? ”Very gentlyOh , my son that might have been !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: very uncomfortableHere , I say , that is n't fair .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: gentlyWhen did your mother die ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Look here , I wish you would n't keep on about mothers .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: When did she die , proud mother ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: sulkilyWell , why should n't she be proud ?After a pauseTwo years ago , if you want to know .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: It was then that you found out who your father was ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: That 's right . I found these old letters . She 'd kept them locked up all those years . Bit of luck for me .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: almost to herselfAnd that was two years ago . And for two years you had your hopes , your ambitions , for two years you were proud and independent . . . . Why did you not come to us then ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: with a touch of vanityWell , I was getting on all right , you know — and ——

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: And then suddenly , after two years , you lost hope .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I lost my job .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Poor boy ! And could n't get another .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: bitterlyIt 's a beast of a world if you 're down . He 's in the gutter — kick him down — trample on him . Nobody wants him . That 's the way to treat them when they 're down . Trample on ‘ em .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: And so you came to your father to help you up again . To help you out of the gutter .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: That 's right .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: pleadinglyAh , but give him a chance !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Now , look here , I 've told you already that I 'm not going to have any of that game .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: shaking her head sadlyFoolish boy ! You do n't understand . Give him a chance to help you out of the gutter .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well , I 'm ——! Is n't that what I am doing ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: No , no . You 're asking him to trample you right down into it , deeper and deeper into the mud and slime . I want you to let him help you back to where you were two years ago — when you were proud and hopeful .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: looking at her in a puzzled wayI can n't make out what your game is . It 's no good pretending you do n't hate the sight of me — it stands to reason you must .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: smilingBut then women are unreasonable , are n't they ? And I think it is only in fairy-stories that stepmothers are always so unkind .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: surprisedStepmother !

lg.l: Well , that 's practically what I am , is n't it ?
I 've never been a stepmother before .
Could n't you let me be proud of my stepson ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Well , you are a one ! . . . Do you mean to say that you and your husband are n't going to have a row about this ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: It 's rather late to begin a row , is n't it , thirty years after it 's happened ? . . . Besides , perhaps you are n't going to tell him anything about it .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: But what else have I come for except to tell him ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: To tell me . . . . I asked you to give him a chance of helping you out of your troubles , but I 'd rather you gave me the chance . . . . You see , John would be very unhappy if he knew that I knew this ; and he would have to tell me , because when a man has been happily married to anybody for twenty-eight years , he can n't really keep a secret from the other one . He pretends to himself that he can , but he knows all the time what a miserable pretence it is . And so John would tell me , and say he was sorry , and I would say : “ It 's all right , darling , I knew , ” but it would make him ashamed , and he would be afraid that perhaps I was n't thinking him such a wonderful man as I did before . And it 's very bad for a public man like John when he begins to lose faith in what his wife is thinking about him . . . . So let me be your friend , will you ?There is a silence between them for a little . He looks at her wonderingly . Suddenly she stands up , her finger to her lipsH'sh ! It 's John .She moves away from him

body.stage: SIR JOHN PEMBURY comes in quickly ; big , good-looking , decisive , friendly ; a man who wears very naturally , and without any self-consciousness , an air of being somebody .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: walking hastily past his wife to her writing-deskHallo , darling ! Did I leave a cheque-book in here ? I was writing a cheque for you this morning . Ah , here we are .As he comes back , he sees THE STRANGERI beg your pardon , Kate . I did n't see ——He is making for the door with the cheque-book in his hand , and then stops and says with a pleasant smile to THE STRANGERBut , perhaps you are waiting to see me ? Perkins said something ——

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: coming forwardYes , I came to see you , Sir John .

body.stage: He stands close in front of SIR JOHN , looking at him . LADY PEMBURY watches them steadfastly .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: tapping his cheque-book against his handImportant ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I came to ask your help .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: looking at his cheque-book and then back with a smile at THE STRANGERA good many people do that . Have you any special claim on me ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: after a long pauseNo .

body.stage: PEMBURY looks at him , undecided , LADY PEMBURY comes forward .

lg.l: All right , dear .
lg.stage: Meaning that she will look after THE STRANGER till he comes back .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: I 'll be back in a moment .He nods and hurries out

body.stage: There is silence for a little , and then LADY PEMBURY claps her hands gently .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: with shining eyesOh , brave , brave ! Ah , but I am a proud stepmother to-day .She holds out her hand to himThank you , son .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: not seeing it , and speaking in a hard voiceI 'd better go .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: May n't I help you ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: I 'd better go .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: distressedYou can n't go like this . I do n't even know your name , nor where you live .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Do n't be afraid — you sha n't hear from me again .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: gentlyNot even when you 've got back to where you were two years ago ? May n't I then ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: looking at her , and then nodding slowlyYes , you shall then .

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Thank you . I shall wait . I shall hope . I shall pray .She holds out her hand againGood-bye !

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: shaking his headWait till you hear from me .He goes to the door , and then stops and comes slowly back . He says awkwardlyWish you 'd do one thing for me ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: That fellow — what did you say his name was — Perkins ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: surprisedThe butler ? Perkins — yes ?

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: Would you give him a message from me ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: STRANGER
sp.p: still awkwardlyJust to say — I 'll be there — at the Mews — on Sunday afternoon . He 'll know . Tell him I 'll be there .He squares his shoulders and walks out defiantly — ready to take the world on again — beginning with PERKINS on Sunday afternoon

body.stage: LADY PEMBURY stands watching him as he goes . She waits after he has gone , thinking her own thoughts , out of which she comes with something of a shock as the door opens and SIR JOHN comes in .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: Hallo ! Has he gone ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: What did he want ? Five pounds — or a place in the Cabinet ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: He came for — a subscription .

sp.speaker: PEMBURY
sp.p: And got it , if I know my Kate .CarelesslyWhat did he take from you ?

sp.speaker: LADY PEMBURY
sp.p: with a wistful little sighYes ; he took something from me . Not very much , I think . But just — something .She takes his arm , leads him to the sofa , and says affectionatelyAnd now tell me all that you 've been doing this morning .So he begins to tell her — just as he has told her a thousand times before . . . . But it is n't quite the samePrinted in Great Britain by R. & R. CLARK , LIMITED , Edinburgh .
